review_content: Botella 0,33l Color negro con espuma de color café, cremosa, alta, resistente, espectacular. Aroma malta tostada, frutos secos, café. Sabor un firme amargor prolongado con notas dulces, malta tostada, frutos secos, café

Guinness Foreign Extra Stout 

Rich fluid pour. Chocolates and roasted malt aroma. Dark foamy Head, like a milkshake. The head to a discernible degree remains throughout the drinking in the glass.  Like a 85% cocoa bar in taste. Not bitter or at most an aftertaste that is restrained enough to make a person think well of Stout beer.  Solid opaque brown to almost black color tastes like it looks, similar to the chocolate bar and lingers long enough to enjoy the brew, and want to see it duplicated in any other “next beer”. 

A definite go to Stout that’s affordable and accessible and has the Guinness name.

Bottle in West Orange, NJ
Very disappointed! Not what i expected. Aroma is great, but it's weak, thin, and not very exciting. Was expecting much more.
Lion Stout is miles above this.
Very satisfying after a day of coding and depression. As heavy as Yangtze river, and ohh that opaque look.

Bottle of 33cl, in a Trappist glass; from the fridge.

A strong taste in a dark mantle, that could qualify this Guinness.

Stronger taste than the usual extra stout, both refreshing and full of taste.
Favorite of all the Guinness. Most flavorful, not sweet, slightly bitter. Would pair well w/Sam Adams Cherry Wheat. Drinkable everyday, except 7.5%: cuidate mi amigo
Black pour with an off-white head with minimal lacing. The aroma is a light roasted malt note with coffee and a roasty    flavor profile. It is a bit thin.
Deep black color and a nice tan head. Nose is dark chocolate, caramel, roasted malts. Tastefollows the nose, some dark coffee as well.

Couleur très foncée et légère mousse noisette typique des Guinness
odeur de fumée et  de malte torréfié, café
en bouche malte torréfié très présent, café , belle amertume, un peu chocolaté, une bonne Guinness

275ml bottle brewed by Banks, Barbados, 7.5%. Poured black with a lasting tan coloured head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, liquorice, toffee, molasses and black treacle. Quite heavy sweetness, moderate roasted bitterness. Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation. More roasted bitterness to finish.

Colore marrone caffè; schiuma nocciola a grana media, persistente.
In bocca caffè, cioccolato, liquirizia.

Pours a dark black at first glance but ruby red at the bottom of the glass if you really look. This is what all Guinness should be. Velvety malt taste on the mouth with a little fruit after it warms up a bit. First sip straight out of the fridge isnt a good one. Gotta let it warm up. My favorite beer.

Bottle from Ken's, enjoyed at home over a game of chess. Pours a deep brownish black with a big tan foam that leaves a little head. Nose is chocolate, brown sugar/caramel, banana. Taste is chocolately sweetness with a nice roasted coffee finish. Full-bodied, prickly carbonation, with a satisfying roasted aftertaste and a gentle boozy warmth. It's like Guinness on steroids, very nice.
just like guiness draught, guiness extra stout is also a dark beer just like guiness draught

Lovely bottle design with blue and yellow trim livening the usual Guinness black and white livery. 

Pours like black oil into glass. Browny pink-tinted head with decent head but fading more quickly than standard Guinness. 

ADDITION! Tried a second bottle which had been 60 mins longer in the fridge and it had the more of the solid head and wobbly charm of a draught Guinness. TIP, put in fridge two hours before drinking. 

The colour is an enticingly opaque dark black with some hints of ruby. An inviting brew to  enjoy on a winter evening.

Aroma is chocolaty and coffee notes, strong on malts, sweet and heavy.

Flavour is nice and full with a hoppy, bitter first taste mellowing into a malty aftertaste. You don't necessarily taste the 7%+ ABV.
Mouth feel is treacly and velvety in the aftertaste. A nice long finish!

A nicely unusual and full of flavour stout from a mainstream brewer. It's great that Guinness has these gems in its locker with this and its cousins, the West Indies Porter and the Nigerian-brewed Foreign Extra Stout which uses sorghum rather than barley, I believe.  

Price-wise quite reasonable at not quite 2€ from Darmstadt Asiamarkt below Galeria Kaufhof.

Not a session beer but one to sip on and savour on a wintry night. Or to be swigged as your daily beer in tropical climes as seems to be the case down West Africa way...

Whole box from Internet, not so pricy... you know this year Chinese economy is fragile...beer itself is 10 months old as being sold with discount, some bottles are tunning sour, while the blatant bitterness, the long lasting subtile sweetness and the feeling of thickness have never seemed to be ruined or perished...Anyway, this beer is worth drinking.

33 cl bottle, Irish version. Poured in to a Snifter. Near black with a creamy lightly tanned head. Sweet aroma with coffee, liqourice, brown cookies, tar and herbal hoppy notes. Taste is sweet. Medium to full body. Dry, herbal bitter finish. A classic!

300ml bottle from Asda. Black with nice sized beige head. Plenty of retention and lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, but what I wasn't expecting was the smokiness coming through. Thick body and low carbonation. Creamy sweetness to start and then a deep coffee bitterness with hints of smokiness. The alcohol comes through strong at the end. Lovely with bags of depth and flavour but definitely not an easy drinking stout, very much one to sip.

33cl bottle thanks to @simontomlinson and EuroSwap 2/2020. Pours dark brown with beige head. Aroma has roasted and sweet malty flavor. Taste is well balanced, full, malty with smooth finish. Very nice standard for its type.

Au visuel, couleur très foncée, noir avec mousse onctueuse persistante un peu marron
Au nez, odeur de café, de torréfaction
En bouche, bonne amertume avec une bonne longueur, principalement un goût de café un peu corsé. Carbonatation fine mais suffisante
Meilleure que la Guinness de base grâce à son goût plus prononcé et sa carbonatation.

Bottle from ASDA.

Aah, this is the stuff !  Has an enticing aroma of raisins and malt-loaf.  Pours pretty much completely black with a “lively” beige head.  Plenty of character in the taste.  Dark fruits, chocolate, molasses and roasted malts.  Alcoholic strength hides itself well – until it hits the back of the throat !  A sweet and fruity finish to round things off.  Far better than “normal” Guinness.
Black body with tan head.  Hoppier than normal Guinness with a strong malt aroma.  Full taste, malt roast and toast.  Long finish.

Creamy tan head stayed on a jet black still body.
Sweet malt aroma.
Medium bodied, sharp on the front with a cloying back & clean aft.
Malt, oat, burnt, roasted, nutty & liquorice tastes with a long tangy finish.
First Class from the Macro!

Pours a dark brown colour with a beige coloured head 
Notes of roasted coffee and roasted toffee caramel and vanilla
330 ml bottle. Pours black with frothy mocca head. A: roasty malt, coffee beans, T: light carbonated, medium body, strong coffee taste, harsh bitter,
Pours a very dark brown with a fair tan head.......aroma of mild fig, metallic, roastiness......taste is smooth, slightly thicker body, fig, touch of earth, mild bitterness.
A nice variation on the normal Guinness. Light aroma of fruit and malts. Rich black color. It starts off with some sweet fruits like raisins and dates. Rich and creamy with a bitter finish.

Deep dark color topped by a tall thick root-beer float of a head which leaves disconnected strings of lacing. Head retention is great, forming a mound-cone top. 

Aroma is sweet, dark fruits, molasses, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate. Rich.

Feel is smooth with a medium-full body.

Taste repeats the aroma, a rich interplay of molasses, coffee, chocolate, roasted malts and a tannin bitterness. The finish is dry, with the tannin and bitterness lingering. Despite the overall dry finish, the aftertaste has a touch of sweetness returning to the mix.

Overall, a great, robust stout. Watch the alcohol, though, because it is hidden well, but will sneak up on you.

Aromat: wyraźne nuty kawy, palonosci
Wygląd: barwa brunatna, nieprzejrzyste, ładna piana i lejsing
Smak: dominuje palonosc, kawa, delikatnie popiolowe, przyjemna goryczka
Podniebienie: ciało niskie, wodniste, szorstkie

Bottle. Pours dark cola brown with loads of beige head. Aroma of prunes, chocolate  and bran breads. Wow, deep bitter chocolate, toast, roasted malts, very dry bitterness. Long dry finish, with residual roasted malts. I remember liking this when I was younger. I sure did miss this one. Why it's not distributed more throughout mainland Europe is strange.
Strong bitterness on the initial taste, with a medium carbonation, just about right. Classic Guinness flavour, coffee and caramel notes present
Beer is revealed bright tones of roasted barley grain and firm bitterness. The finish is powerful, dry, with a touch of roasted malt.

[Butelka 29.11.2020] Barwa brunatna, klarowne, nieprzejrzyste. Piana obfita, drobno i średnio pęcherzykowa, długo utrzymująca się. W aromacie zdominowane przez kawę, popiół, mocno palone. W smaku wytrawne, dużo popiołu, gorzka kawa, wysoka paloność. Goryczka średnia, nasycenie średnie do wysokiego, ciało średnie.

33 cl bottle (BBD 2019-08-31), bought from The Forest Hotel (B93 8JA), drunk at home 2020-01-26.

Appearance is a deep brown with a thick, dense coffee coloured head that lingers for a long time. No visible carbonation, although it's so dark you can't really tell. Nice looking - love the colour of the head.

Aroma has plenty of coffee notes and some dark chocolate, with maybe a hint of fruitiness - cherries? Something rich. It's good, if slightly fainter than I'd like.

Taste is lovely. Milk, rather than dark, chocolate notes with some dried fruit hints as well. A surprisingly bitter finish with roasted notes.

Palate is surprising. Medium to full bodied with a surprising amount of in mouth carbonation. Thick but also with a surprising clean juiciness. Decent length finish too.

Overall, this is a huge improvement on standard Guinness. Maybe the bitterness on the finish is slightly too much and leaves it a tad unbalanced, but this is worth finding as an excellent cellar stand by.

Bottle found in Montserrat. Pours carbonated dark brown with modest light beige foam, medium fake chocolate cake made tinny by too much carbonation. Flavour is molasses with coffee notes. Okay and full mouthfeel. Not exceptional but certainly a reliable and tasty enough stout.

Wow i don't expecting such great beer.. This beer has nothing common with the ordinary "Guinness Draught".. This one has much better mouthfeel and flavors and amazing finish.. The beer is so lively in your mouth and give you the pleasure you want..
Anyway many coffe notes and some chocolate too.. The finish has a long coffe durection and that is the stronger thing here in my opinion.. The carboration tickles your togue and your mouth and make this beer even better..
Overall one surprisingly great beer from "St. James's Gate" brewery.. For sure i buy it again and again in the future!
Bottle thanks to stevoj pours out dark brown topped with a small tan head . Nose is sweet roast malts nutty kick. Taste is more of the nice sweet chocolate roast malts nutty kick.

Pours the expected dark dark guinness color you always expect and with similar sticky dark cappuccino head. Aroma is quite sweet, malty and molasses with dark brown sugar, dried fruit, high roastiness, and maybe just a touch of spice/bitter from hops. Taste is less sweet and more balanced, roasty dark malts, a hint of brown sugar, and a great hop bitterness at the end that couldn't be better for a stout. This is the guinness everybody should have, wonderful dry dry stout.
Pours black with full, tan head.  Aroma is molasses, roast and dried fruit.  Taste is raisin and brown sugar, moving to rich roast.  Finish is raisin, roast and brown sugar.  Good stout.

330ml bottle in 2015. It’s one of those beers that I always dismiss and think I must be misremembering how good it actually is. However, it is just flipping great. While I do like the Nigerian one, the Irish original has more roasty and coffee character and less sweetness. It’s looks fantastic; pitch black with a dense brown head. So much rich roasty character to this beer. I hate to say it, but when people say that the best Guinness is in Ireland, I have to point out that the best Guinness isn’t actually sold in Ireland!!
$2.69 bottle, TWSP. Pours dark with a small beige head. Chocolate, caramel, raisin nose. Roasted coffee beans, cocoa, raisin, glue flavor. Finishes with a bit of char and ash.
Une Guinness médiocre, au goût désagréable dès l'attaque. Franchement, des stouts bien meilleurs il y en a à la pelle.
I love Guinness but this is not good. It tastes like someone has added meths just to make it stronger and so ruined a fantastic beer. Poured most of it away.
Talvez seja uma excelente cerveja para quem gosta, mas eu não fui capaz de gostar. Achei exageradamente amarga. O aroma é bom, mas para o meu paladar, não deu certo.

330ml bottle brewed in Dublin at 7.5%. 50/50 head, Guinness feathered/microbubble style, somewhat mottled from off-white to darker, coffee colours, moderate duration, mushrooming. Practically black, with tints of red where the light can penetrate. Bitter roast and sweet burnt caramel notes in the aroma. Alcohol faintly detectable but hidden very well for the ABV. Thick, creamy, coating the mouth and lingering. Low carbonation. Treacly sweetness into dark coffee bitterness and back again, both painted with rich, broad brushstrokes on the palate. Luxurious, but doesn't treat your tastebuds with kid gloves. Strongly recommended, but not as a daily drink that's for sure.
Thick. Strong malty body. Nice roasted boogie. Leather. Licorice. Farm. Espresso.

Deep black pour with massive 5 inch thick caramel colored pillowy fluff head. Aroma of sweet fruits and cocoa. Hints of coffee and caramel in the nose. First taste is great balance of tart hoppy sweetness and roasted barley bitterness. Fluffy head still remains after several swigs. Beer also laces my signature Guinness 250 glass nicely. Notes of dark chocolate, anise and lots of dark candied fruits like raisins, dates and figs. 75 IBUs and this one retains a great deal of smooth drinkability. Deliciously well done. Nice medium thickness in the mouth. Crisp, thirst-quenching, suitable for dessert or paired with grilled meats. In many ways superior to the quintessential Extra Stout. If stouts are your thing, high recommendation for FES.
My favorite Guinness. Do not like it cold, please. Alcohol is high in number but not in affect to me for some reason.

Jet black pour, beige head. Nose is roasted malts, coffee and earthy notes. Taste is decent amount of roasted and earthy notes, some sweetish booze and faint licorice. Light bodied with soft to normal carbonation, drinks well below the ABV.
A lovely mix of flavours.  Great strength . Nice bite on palate.  Very impressed. Second tasting even better.  Aroma not so good.  Lots of hops and mollasses

Overall: It's a beast of a beer. Big bold flavors, most of them built up versions of what you get in Guinness draft, but the balance is very different. Draft is a drink, this is a meal. I like it, but understand that not everyone will. I remember trying it early in my craft beer journey and thinking, it's too much, too challenging. Now days I find it much more drinkable and enjoyable, but a slow sipper. I also find it... nutritive. Something about it seems like it just might be good for me in some way. It's an impressive amount of taste for a 7.5% abv beer.

So I've been trying to find this beer forever, literally for as long as I've been a beer geek, over 20 years. I had long assumed I would need to travel out of the US to ever try it, so imagine my surprise when I was shopping in my local Publix, and saw a lone bottle of Guinness, with a slightly different label (reminiscent of the old 90s labels) sitting by its lonesome on the clearance rack. I approached for a closer look and couldn't believe my eyes when I saw Foreign Extra Stout. $1.99. Snatched it the fuck up. Typical appearance, black, opaque, modest tan head. Nose is roast, caramel, restrained. Flavor similar, semi-sweet, notes of roasted barley and coffee. Lightly acrid. Medium bitterness. Soft finish.

Fridge clean-out rating day!   Yep - I have never rated this!  Hel-lo, 330ml bottle I forgot about and left in the fridge for ... ahem.  I am pretty sure I bought it at an off-license in Finchley.  Looks amazing - opaque thick-looking black pour,  large and lasting creamy foamy light brown head.  I just got back from a trip to Ireland and I have a new respect for the St. James Gate offerings when handled and poured properly - this is a 5.  The aroma is sweet molasses and wheatgrass, some alcohol and a little tar - pretty solid for a bottle that's (ahem) years old,  Taste follows, but it's showing its age - a little soy sauce and acidity - if that acidity is on purpose, well done.  Light, airy body, solid carbonation, building dry bitterness and rope in the long-ish finish.  Three for three on old stouts today!

Color negro, totalmente opaca. Espuma beige, cremosa aunque un tanto irregular, un dedo de espesor y excelente retención. Aroma a maltas tostadas, frutos negros, vino tinto y alcohol, ligera vainilla al atemperar. Sabor a maltas tostadas y café ligeramente amargo, final de amargor un tanto herbal y seco, agradable hasta que en el regusto aparecen desagradables maltas quemadas. Textura acuosa. Carbonatación media.

Aunque el sabor no ofrece los matices que ofrece en aroma, la recomendaría si solucionaran el regusto tan quemado.

I like this drink and sometimes drink it.
Since this is a strong stout 3 or 4 is the most you can have then you feel rough-bad next day.

Every month I normally attend a nightclub where they normally have this drink in , I remember 2 months ago I think I had 7 and at the end of the night , I felt so bad I was about to fall over and my friend and my mum had to drag me to the car , then later mum had to help me take my shoes off and i was sick but needed help , lucky I survived as my mum pushed me on my front so lucky I did not die on my own vomit. Next day all I remember was I brushed my teeth 3 am in morning , felt sick , terrible all morning , had to take pain killers to help my headache , also did not feel like eating much , later in afternoon i felt a bit better .

In future I wont have 7 as it is too many and I almost died , probably only 3 or 4 .

KEN
Recommended by a Nigerian colleague. Have to say that I'm impressed. A little overpowering though.

Bottle- great stout with a bit more bite than the regular Guinness. Nice an DARK with the perfect rocky head. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A very big stout with a rich and rounded aroma, bitter malty and coffee notes and a massive punch. Great value.

Bottle from a local Asda. Pours very dark beown, nearly black with medium frothy head. Aroma is coffee and chocolate, quite intensive. Taste is light tarty with bitter aftertaste. Full body, long finish, medium carbonation. Quite nice, drinkable.

(11.2 oz. bottle) - Nice frothy head which lasts a lot longer than a lot of modern beers. Ultra dark mahogany body. Nose of dark cocoa, almost wine-like. Wish it was a tad bit more aromatic. Chewy body. Flavors of roasted malt hit you up front, followed by a hint of plums. There is a hop character in the backbone. But, it's not fighting with the malts. In the end a bitter palate lingers. Most definitely not the Guinness, which has been tamed down for the American market. Reminds me of Australian Sheaf Stout, which I haven't seen in a long long time, though perhaps a tad bit drier. A shame they didn't produce this as a standalone in their regular lineup.

I have to confess I've heard about this one for years, and always wanted to try it. But, since I've never made it to Africa, haven't had the chance. Maybe that's clouding my figures. But, I'm really enjoying it. Glad I didn't waste a bottle going into the corned beef today. 

If you see one of those commemorative half cases near you buy it, because you might not see this in the US again for a long time!!
Pours a very dark black color with a fluffy tan head. Some caramel flavor with coffee notes in the background. Not as bitter as Guinness draught. Very good beer.

Wow...this is better than I thought it would be.  Don't see why I would want a regular Guinness Extra Stout over this.  I cook a lot with these stouts too, so may have to try this one out in a slow roast or something to see if it makes a difference.  Thicker than their standard stout, more flavor and better balance.  Chocolate stands out more, just all around better. Oh, and it gives you a nicer buzz too  :)  Up there with my favorite sweet stouts.  Will definitely get again.

Acquired this one from a friend that frequents Haiti regularly. This stout poured a black colour with a light brown, creamy head. Scents include caramel, smoke, ripe fruit, alcohol and a bit of paint thinner. In a good way. First swig was quite different than what we’re used to. Flavours of molasses, toasted coffee, smoke and fig. Finish is slightly sweet with lingering flavours of caramel and brandy.
In Belize aus der Flasche, malziger Geruch etwas röstmalz, säuerlich röstmalz im Geschmack, ganz nette kleine Kaffee nuss Note, nicht übel
275ml Flasche in der Belize Version. Kork und Röstmalzduft. Etwas Port. Kräftig röstiger Malzantrunk. Bitter Schokolade und ein Hauch Rauch. Etwas kratzig hinten raus.
Excellent beer I found on Paradise Island in the Bristow Wine and Liquor, Bahamas.   Good rich flavor, easy to drink.  Would definitely buy again.

Aspect : Bière noire avec une mousse peu persistante et marron.

Odeur : Café

Gout : Gout grillé suivi de café. Alcool bien équilibré.

Palais : Bonne carbonatation, bière assez épaisse, très bonne longueur en bouche.

Général : Très bonne bière noire, équilibrée et agréable.

Jolie robe noire.
Une Mousse de couleur noisette de longue tenue.
Le nez est du café.
En bouche c'est un goût de café avec un fin aqueuse.
Bitter without being too sharp. Definitely prefer it to the standard weaker Guinness.
Dark brown color with tan head.  Coffee and alcohol aroma.  Taste is sweet coffee with an alcohol bite.

330ml bottle from Bien Manger. Pours opaque black with a decent-sized tan head that leaves some pretty lacing. Aroma is nuts, milk chocolate, toffee. Taste is light to medium sweet, dark fruits, cocoa, roasted malt, oats. Dry, moderately bitter finish.
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnień z degustacji w ramach uzupełnienia profilu.

Bottle at home. Pours opaque black with a thin dissipating head. Aromas of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Taste is intense, with a fair bit of chocolate and coffee and some burnt notes. Nice long bittersweet finish. Very different from draught Guinness (which I also love). You also don't notice the high alcohol content in the taste which is a big plus. Excellent stout!

Excellent Imperial stout to me.  Pitch black with rather creamy head. The nose is more chocolate than Guinness Draught. The taste is on the nuts, chocolate and fudge. Very nice balance with some round body. But still the dryness is strong with the alcool amount working well here. Carbonation is really different to the Draught version, no nitro here. Excellent really.

Pours an opaque black colour, with a rapidly dissipating head.  The aroma is of raisins and roasted malt and the flavour is bitter/sweet once again of raisins, coffee and toffee with a bitterness that is long-lasting and lingers on the palate.  Overall, an excellent stout.
Una guinness con un corpo più pieno rispetto all'originale, sapori più intensi e con maggiore gradazione alcolica.

Bottle picked up at off license near the hotel.  Black pour with thick, foamy beige head. Aroma is smoky, ashy with a hint of chocolate. Taste is roasty, campfire, mild sweetness. Mild, sweet bitterness lingers.

12 oz bottle. Smells of toffee, caramel, chocolate. Pitch black color in the glass. This is different than the regular Guinness stout, much better. Tastes of chocolate and coffee, with a nice bitter hop kick. Finishes a little sweet and bitter, a nice mix.

Pours a big and lasting head and boasts a generous aroma with both sweet and roasty components: coffee, caramel, malt whiskey. On the tongue, the sweet side is rather subdued - bitterness prevails (more or less). The taste is intense - incredibly so for a Guiness - and the finish brings the whiskey component back. To be honest, this isn't just a surprise version of boring old Guinness, but a truly good stout! I didn't think I would say so. :-)

Tastes of deep roasted malt, theres a kot of toffee and chocolate tastes in this drink with a nice roasted aroma. Pours almost black with a Brown head and excellent lacing. If there was a perfect drink out there I'd say it was this.
Pours reddish black with a thick, smooth cream head. Aroma of malts. Taste is fairly light for a stout, not a lot of mouthfeel. Palate has a wide variety of spice notes including cloves. Good beer.
Lots of bitter and sweet chocolate. Dry and silky. Full bodied. Outstanding balance.

Bouteille 33cl le 02/10/2018. Verre saveur bière 15cl. DDM : 28/06/2019.

Mousse : Couleur beige tirant vers le marron, sur 3mm, bulles moyennes.
Liquide : Noir, opaque.
Nez : Malt grillé, fumé, chocolat, café, un peu floral, alcool?.
Bouche : Malt torréfié, brûlé, fumé, café, un peu d’acidité.
Palais : Carbonatation faible, longueur correcte.

From the bottle. Dark brown with a sudsy, creamy head that clings to the glass. Chocolate, slightly burnt toast, and mineral water notes in the aroma. Taste is bittersweet with a nicely interwoven undertone of chocolate and berries. Body is medium—rich, creamy and smooth. It definitely has a leg up on the normal version. Pretty good overall.
Schwarz, klar, ausgeprägte und stabile Krone. Intensive Röst- und Kaffeearomen, dabei aber nicht zu vollmundig-malzig.

Robe noire, belle mousse fine. Nez très torréfié. En bouche, puissant goût torréfié, café, amertume. Un peu trop amer pour moi. Très légère pointe d'acidité. Cependant, c'est infiniment supérieur à la version de base. Au moins, ça a du goût.
Big bottle (Cameroon version). Pours dark brown-black. Aroma is roast, fruits, ash. Flavor is bitter, sour, slight sweetness, roast, malt, fruits. Finish is acidic and ashy. Overall: drinkable.

650ml bottle. Pours dark brown colour. Beige head. Bread, cocoa, roast in the aroma. Roasted malts, bread, cocoa, alcochol in the taste. Roasted malts in the aftertaste. Rather medium bodied, bit sweet brew.
650ml bottle as Cameroon. Pours dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma is roasty, sweet, coffee, molasses. Taste is malty, bit sourish, roasty. Feels off. Medium body, fizzy carbonation. Off
Smaczne mocne piwo choć bez większych fajerwerków. Kawa, czekolada, z czasem wychodzi alkohol ale nie jakoś mocno. Dość proste ale smaczne.
7% ABV metallic first taste. Slight coffee on the back of tongue. Smell of chocolate. Smooth going down.

Smooth roast and chocolate aromas.
Taste is initially burnt sugar, chocolate persists throughout, a nice dark fruit on the finish. Bitterness alco comes through on the finish.
Beautiful combinations of flavour and aroma. Tastes much lighter than its 7.5 abv tagline
Brewed under license by phoenix brewery. Pours dark black with a creamy caramel head. Flavourfull, by far the best beer in Mauritius. Biterness is balance with a sweet aftertaste.

275 ml bottle, brewed under licence by Belize Brewing Company. Pours a very dark chestnut brown with a huge dense tan colored head. The aroma of rather mildly roasted malt, toffee, some dough, hints of mild coffee. Medium to medium-full body with a soft carbonation, a light to medium sweetness and a light bitterness along with some noticeable alcohol. The flavor starts with sweetish roasted malt - nuts, caramel - and is followed by quite some burnt notes - burnt wood, ash, firestone, ash. Rather harsh and not very balanced. In addition quiet alcoholic.



Aroma: 6 
Appearance: 4 
Taste: 6 
Palate: 4 
Overall: 10

J'ai toujours un certain respect lorsque j'ouvre une bouteille de Guinness. Cela me rappelle d'innombrables et inoubliables soirées au pub. Mais cela c'était avant... Depuis j'ai pris de l'âge, je sors moins, mais j'ai aussi appris à connaître la bière. Et même s'il existe comme un petit rappel tel la madeleine de Proust, cela n'est plus tout à fait la même chose. Impossible avoir le même rapport avec la Guiness, depuis que j'ai découvert les stouts de De struise, De Molen et autres.... D'autant plus ici que je m'attaque à la Foreign Extra Stout, dont la composition change selon les pays. Et même si l'équilibre global de ce stout est plutôt bon, celui-ci manque à la fois de complexité et quelque peu de caractère. En verre, le noir est total avec une mousse beige nappant à peine la surface. Le nez est surprenant, pas totalement équilibré sur les arômes, le fumé et le fudge est assez présent, prenant l'ascendant sur le café et le chocolat. L'attaque est déconcertante. Peu puissante, sur une amertume fraîche, le caramel et légèrement fruitée. Le malt torréfié y est très peu présent. La deuxième bouche gagne en ampleur avec des beaux arômes de café qui arrivent. L'arrière bouche d'une ampleur correcte (sans être exceptionnelle) est sur des arômes de café francs et présente une belle amertume. La suite présente un bon élancement avec une amertume qui gagne en intensité et des arômes de charbon qui viennent accompagner ceux de café sur une longueur appréciable. Bien mais pas sensationnel. Les madeleines n'ont pas toutes le même goût
Fles 33cl thuis. Krachtig, bitter. Lekker. Typisch. (7-2008).----------------.

This is the only beer I've ever thrown away and the fact it has such a high rating makes me lose respect for this site. It is putrid. Colour is black, body is thick and sticky, strong coffee tastes but not in a nice way, like that over strong coffee you let brew too long. Sickly sweet and over bitter all at once. I love Guinness and all it's other incarnations but there's a reason this shipped as far away as possible. Anyone who likes this likes the flavour of vomit in their mouth and knows nothing about beer.

On tap in Dublin. Pours a jet black with a beige head. Aroma: roasted malt, toasted grain, ash, mild cream and coffee notes. Taste: roasted malt, espresso, toasted grain, mild bitter cocoa and charcoal flavours. Medium bodied. Medium bodied. Moderate bitterness that lingers. This is quite good.

Bouteille de 33 cl achetée chez Super U. Robe noire opaque avec une mousse brune épaisse. Arômes de malts torréfiés, pain grillé et café. Texture huileuse, carbonatation moyenne, faible amertume. Notes de café grillé et de malts, légèrement résineuse. Finale sèche et amère portée sur le grillé.

This is Guinness Original on steroids. Robust coffee aroma with strong cocoa presence. Taste: sweet malts, oats, dark chocolate, espresso with hints of dark fruits and mild bitter hop finish. Wish I could find it on tap.
Dark brown some foam. Aroma molasses. Tastes char chocolate. Some grassy bitter. Great not as super as antwerpen

Une Stout à la portée de tout le monde, même les non fans de la première heure. On est surpris à la première gorgée par l’amertume prononcée dès l’attaque, qui ensuite, au fil de la dégustation s’amenuise pour les notes plus « subtiles » de grillé, noisette, café caractéristiques du style. Une « gentille » stout pour le marché africain ?

330 ml bottle,bb 10/01/2019.
Black,nice beige head.
Nose - dark fruit in front and dark chocolate in the background.
Taste - roasted malt,dark fruit and cocoa.
Surprisingly good.

Tried this beer at the airport. Even though it’s a strong one, I didn’t have any problem with finishing it, no alcohol taste or something like it.  Very coffee taste, very dark appearance, and will get you drunk in no time!

33cl bottle into pint glass. Very dark brown almost black with a beige foamy head, stays throught the drink. Aroma is roasted malt, taste of roasted mals, coffee, dark chocolate. A pleasantly bitter drink.
Colour is black with cream coloured head, aroma of dark berries, very boozy aroma, chocolate. Flavour is boozy, treacle.

Barwa czarna z brunatnymi przebłyskami, piana beżowa.
Aromat słodowy: gorzkie kakao, nuty melasy i czekolady.
W smaku pół-pełne, czekolada, kakao, kawa w tle, goryczka średnio-niska ziołowa.
Light malty aroma. Pitch black in color with huge long lasting brown head. Taste is roasty, notes of coffee and dark chocolate
Ppurs,almost black. Aroma is more dark fruit than cocoa, fairly restrained. Taste is sweet, malty, hint of hops, medium mouthfeel. Better than expected.
C'est pas mal sans être extra à mon goût. La stout n'est pas mon style préféré mais une fois de temps en temps ça change. Bon gout de stout de chocolat café, l'alcool n'est pas trop présent.

#2000 ! My #1000 beer was Omnipollo / Buxton Yellow Belly Peanut Butter Biscuit Stout. On the label, they said it was "brewed to celebrate all things new, open minded and progressive." It was about prejudices. During a tasting, I like to take in account the beer itself of course, but also all the circumstances (Where does it come from/How did you get it/The place you are tasting it and eventually people who drink with you). This tasting was also about prejudices. This beer comes from Café des Promenades. This bar is a PMU, a usual french bar despised by french beer geeks. There are more than 40 bottles in their bar with some good trappist ales and... this beer. Beer culture is spreading everywhere. Cheers. 

Sunday, February 18, 2018. Bottle, 33cL. 7.5%. Purchase ("Café des Promenades", @Airvault (240m from home), FR). Home. A sparkling black beer with a big beige foamy head ; good retention ; ok lacing. Roasted malt, caramel, black chocolate notes and prune notes. Medium round sweet, a bit sugary, warming background, light dry bitter. Good body, light to medium texture, soft gaseous, sweet roasted toffee finish. Overall, good !
dedzinaata karamele un mazliet ogle. dirzgan ladzigd bet svaks balance, nepareiza karbonizacija tadam alum

Czarne, nieprzejrzyste piwo z czerwonymi przebłyskami, dobra piana. Aromat niestety zdominowany przez masło, w życiu tak mocnego diacetylu nie czułem. Gdzieś tam przez to przebijają się nuty palone ale na prawdę trzeba się zaciągnąć. W smaku lepiej, ale dalej czuć masło, pojawiają się ciężkie, długo zalegające nuty palone, mocno kawowe. Gdyby nie masło piwo byłoby prawdopodobnie bardzo dobre.
A lovely strong dark black stout from Guinness. Packs loads of flavor and a really pleasent drink. Tastes roasted and hints of dark chocolate and small tastings of roasted nuts. A great drink!
(trop fumée-café (avis et notation de jeunesse, à réessayer))

11.2 oz bottle to a snifter. Pours a dark brown with a thin ecru head. Minimal lace. Nice roasted malt, light chocolate and light molasses aroma. Modestly sweep flavor with more molasses and faint chocolate malt. Body is medium and not as dry as your basic grocery store Guiness. Fairly impressive.

1/20/18
Had with Abby after watching The Little Mermaid: Ariel’s Beginning. 
Had this bottle since August I️ think. Last one of the 4 pack I️ bought to celebrate the GMAT. 

Jet black with a huge brown head that fades in a few minutes. 

Nose is big dark toasty malts. Coffee, chocolate, molasses. 

Taste is caramel, chocolate, coffee, molasses and some hops. Big and complex. More bitter than sweet. Delicious. 

Palate is medium. Very drinkable. Bitter chocolate/hop finish. Wish it were just a bit thicker. 

Overall, this is awesome! Stands up well to what I️ remember. Easily one of my favorite stouts!
Noire opaque, avec une mousse beige bien persistante. Des arômes de torréfaction et des saveurs de café en bouche, c'est clairement une Guinness.

Rich coffee roast on the nose and palate. Same in the taste. Nutty and bitter with a long finish. Treacle undertones. Don't like normal Guinness on draught or can but this is proper stuff.  Turns out Guinness can make decent stout.
This is really, really good! Looks like a regular Guinness, smells better, and tastes awesome. Nutty chocolate flavor with a smooth, nice finish. By FAR my favorite Guinness.

Pours coffee brown with a thick, frothy tan head. Aroma offers roasted malt, yeasty, molasses, and subtle mocha notes. Flavor delivers roast malt, molasses, chocolate and quality coffee tones, just like a fine stout should. Mouthfeel features firm, smooth body and jazz fizz. My goodness, this is good Guinness!
Pours a thick black fence black with a thick beige head. Nose is roasted malt and coffee. Body is full. Taste is raisiny, coffee, bitter chocolate. Bitter aftertaste. 11.2 oz bottle Brewed in Ireland

My favourite variety of Guinness tried thus far. The extra strength and the increased coffee bitterness really make this a phenomenal brew. I sometimes stop and wonder how this is not more popular, but then I realise that the world is not a fair and just place. Lol. Always had in bottles from supermarket. Pours with lovely tan head.

Opaque black with thin foamy tan head
Aroma is malty grainy musty leathery tobaccoey chocolatey all blended together 
Flava roasty molasses grainy with distinct black licorice notes
Feels thick creamy yet lively fizzy foaminess 
Finishes rich long roasty tangy slightly bitter with notes of licorice and wood

Bottle from BevMo! in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is herbal licorice, smoky bits, charred fruit, leather. Taste is sweet, mild smoke, dark chocolate. Really great...a bit messy / unstructured but still one of the better versions of Guinness.

330ml bottle, Irish version. Pours black with a huge beige/tan head, great retention. Aroma of roasted malts and dark fruits and a bit of chocolate. Taste is pretty much exactly that as well, there's also a subtle warmth from the alcohol, some liquorice and a dry fruity roasty bitter finish. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Not bad.

Bottle at Den Engel, Leek. Pours a deep ruby brown to black colour with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted Irish barley, chocolate, dark fruits, some raisins, slight coffee and subtle leather. Taste of roasted barley, chocolate, dark fruits, some coffee, slight leather and subtle cream. Medium bodied and moderate carbonation. A lingering, dry, roasted fruit bitterness in the finish. Very complex, recognisable Guinness characteristics of the roasted barley and chocolate as well as dark fruits, leather and coffee. Good for its style in a traditional way but there’s better, more modern stouts in the market at this strength now.
jet black , toasted aroma ,  hints of chocolate, tastes more complex than standard Guinness  with a higher ABV

Part of the Guinness 200th anniversary variety pack. Black with a tan head that quickly disappeared. Aroma is traditional Guinness of roasted barley with a bitter hops and spices. Taste is bitter hops and slight spice.
Ciemnej barwy. Piana brunatna, trwała, zdobi szkło. W aromacie palone słody, czekolada, ciemne suszone owoce. W smaku wytrawne. Doochodzi kawa. Alkohol dosyć dobrze ukryty.

Pours dark black with thin tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, dark chocolate and coffee with some hop bitterness. Taste is smooth, a rich combination of coffee and chocolate with a firm hop bitterness. Roasted bitter finish. Much heftier than standard Guinness.

Definitely not as smooth or delicious as a regular Guinness 

Seems more bitter and larger after taste. It’s fine but I’ll pass next time 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Prawie czarne nieprzezroczyste piwo z średnią pianą. Aromat kawy, przypieczonych tostow, również dość dużo chmielu. W smaku kawa, trochę czekolady, lukrecji, czarnej porzeczki, oczywiście obecne są nuty palone. Klasyka stylu

Pours black, big brown head. Aroma of raisin, caramel, choc, butterscotch. Taste of same with great body and rich flavors of coffee and dark chocolate. Definitely Mich better than US Guinness Draught. Wow.
Backlog, ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnień z degustacji oraz przepisana z profilu na Untappd. Niczym się nie wyróżnia, przeciętny stout.
Pours jet black with coffee coloured head. Aroma chocolate and dark fruit. Taste matches. It isn't as smooth as regular Guinness but is much more full flavoured. Nice stout.

Initial mouth feel is suprisingly thin and refreshing, giving way to the familiar full body expected from stout, roast malt flavours (leather, chocolate,tabacco), and a strong, pleasant bitterness. Well balanced, satisying but not too heavy; still one of the best stouts on the market. Shame the standard(e.g draft/weaker ) vers is so insipid in comparison!
Bottle in Nattitangou, Republic of Benin. Black color, malty, roasted, chocolate,maybe some vanilla notes

Backlog from Irland. Bottle at Guiness Storehouse. Roasted aroma of caramel, chocolate, vanilla and light coffee. Some herbal, citrus hops. Moderate sweet with a bitter roasted finish. Medium body and creamy texture. A descent one... the hyped atmosphere here might have gotten me.

Bottle from ?, maybe the supermarket, been a long time since I bought it. This I must say is a very pleasant surprise. it is all that lovely cuddlyness that a normal Guinness gives you but refined and made more butch and adult. The product description is quite spot on here, there is a roasted barley taste there, with some added herbs I would say. It is bitter and yet sweet too and quite crisp with a little fizz on the tongue. I think this is very decent indeed, glad it isnt too hard to find.

I poured it from the bottle into a glass. It pours black with a small, brown head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee, and dried fruit. The taste is dark chocolate, coffee, raisin, and prune. As it warms, some smoky flavor comes through. It's pretty smooth and really flavorful. This is really good stuff.

On tap in Molly Malone's. Pours black, creamy, with a great cascade foam effect. Aroma is mild, stoutish sourness, milky, liquorice, sweet, watery. Body is thin, could be more full. Taste is watery, creamy, mild roasted like notes, watered mocha. Good beer, but very watery and light. With a thicker body it could be great.

#1555
Bottle. Dark brown to black, smal tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate, pralines, liquer. Taste is neutral with bitter finish. Chocolate, pralines, touch of cherries, old paper. Medium body with watery texture, high carbonation. 
Better than ordinary Guinness, but still average stout.

Bottle 0.33l. Dark brown colored. AROMA- chocolate, roasted malts, pralines, touch of nuts and alcohol. FLAVOR- neutral, lightly bitter, roasted malts, chocolate, touch of cardboard. Medium bodied. 
Not bad for commercial brew.
33cl from bottle. The classical Guinness but much more character. Slightly darker, not as smooth, but more complex and malty
W aromacie słodkawe, owocowe, palone. W smaku wytrawne, lekko palone, lekka czekolada, kawa.

Bottle. Pours hazy very dark brown with stable creamy tan head. Clear aroma of malt, fruit and roast, with notes of yeast. Sweetish flavour of malt and dired fruit, with notes of roast and yeast and touches of hops. Roasty and estery aftertaste with malty notes. Creamy mouthfeel. A very nice Foreign Stout. The fact that it is mass produced does not change a thing here.

Comes in the well known dark bottle, Guinness Special Export Stout is a beer with its own unique taste. Can I find the classic Guinness taste in this Foreign Extra version?

 Pours the expected pitch black colour with a tan whitish head that didn’t last too long, with little lacing. 

A very strong aroma of dark cocoa, coffee and roasted malts. The smell is quite strong on the nose. 

The taste was powerful. Now I know why in Africa they use the slogan "Guinness gives you power!" It was a very strong tasting stout, with a long bitter aftertaste, that had a bite to it. Overall a good strong stout, tasting of roasted malt with traces of coffee. As you would expect with a Guinness stout the flavours are complex and well balanced, making it one of the worlds richest tasting beers. Still not as good as a pint of the real black stuff beside the Liffey, Dublin town.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a dark brown with a large tan head. 
 The aroma is smoky sweet malt. The taste is smoky malt bliss.

Bottle. Opaque black with brownish head. The aroma has notes of milk chocolate, molasses, toffee and chocolate cake. Sweet and bitterish flavor with notes of milk chocolate, coffee, molasses, licorice, a bit alcoholic. Medium to full-bodied. Nice.

Bottle. Deep brown black with a beige head. Milk chocolate, molasses, caramel, coffee, toffee, fudge. Sweet, chocolate cake, coffee liqueur, caramel, bread, toffee, mild bitterness. Medium full bodied, smooth. Very nice.

Bottle. Black beer with a brown head. Rich malt and toffee aroma. Rich caramel and roast flavor with light coffee. Medium-plus bodied. Rich caramel lingers with black licorice, roas , and light coffee.
Piwo wypite jakiś czas temu. Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnień z degustacji, w ramach uzupełnienia profilu.
Irish draft beer in Shamrock bar in Novi Sad, Serbia. Expensive but very good, worth it. So milky soft in mouth, not so drinkable, pretty color and foam, special pouring technique.
330ml bottle from Today's Local, Reading. Very dark brown colour with tan head. Roasted malt, black coffee, toasted bread, dark chocolate.

Good beer with excellent aroma. A classic, muar be tasted for all beer lovers.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Asda. Pours darkest brown with thick foamy tan head. Aromas of caramel and light treacle , roasty chocolate malts come though. The caramel with the sparkle gives an initial Cola-like sensation. Once it’s acclimatised a bittering roast malt comes to the fore. The body is soft with a medium to gentle dry sparkle. This is almost spot-on but the depth of flavours I found a little disappointing.

(Brewed in Ireland) Big foamy head and very dark, almost balck. Sharp tasting and surprisingly light body. Sweet toffee in the finish, a little carbonated. Goes down shockingly easy for such a strong dark beer. A little on the sweet side.

Bottle. Pours dense cocoa black with a medium brown foam residing perfectly. Scent is medium notes of cocoa and porter. Taste is medium notes of rum cask. Light porter properties. Finish is dry and nice. Great beer.

33cl bottle at home. Pours a pitchblack head with a medium tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruit. Taste is sweet, medium bitter with a soft dry finish. Notes of roasted malt, chocolate, bit of coffee, cream, bit of hops. Texture is oily, medium bodied with medi carbonation

Dégustée dans un verre "Mille et une bières",belle robe brune surmontée d’une fine mousse café moyennement persistante avec une faible carbonatation.Le nez nous offre des arômes de chocolat ,café .La bouche nous amène sur des saveurs à l’image du nez avec une légère pointe d’amertume très agréable qui reste en finale mêlée à une bonne sensation de "grillé".Un excellent stout!!! 18/20.

Dégustée dans un verre "Mille et une Bières".
Température de début 8 à 9 °.
Très belle robe ébène surmontée d’une généreuse mousse de couleur café plutôt persistante; très faible carbonatation.
Nez particulièrement agréable sur des arômes de café et de torréfaction.
Le goût est tout aussi plaisant : saveurs chocolatées et grillées avec une pointe d’amertume.
La finale est longue et savoureuse.
Un stout très réussi.
Mention "Excellent"
18/20

330ml bottle. Pours jet black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate ice cream, roasted malt, coffee and brown sugar dates. Silky smooth rich mouth feel. Taste is milk chocolate, milky coffee, dates, brown sugar, roasted malt and some hop bitterness. Good bitter, coffee finish. This is bloody awesome stuff !

Jet black with strong and thick and dark brown color foam. Aromas of smokey, coffee and dark chocolate with sweet vanilla hints and cream. Palate, full body with creamy texture leaving soft coffee finish. Taste, is somewhat mroe sweet than bitter with cocoa and black chocolate notes as well as cream and touch of light hops? Overall, nice beer, lovel aromas and texture, taste is fine, not excelent though.

Opaque, foamy. Full body, flavorful, nice heat and carbonation, lingering aftertaste. 
Bitter, not so dry, crisp, great balance. 
Roast barley flavor, smoky. 
Best Guinness to my taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottles from B&M and Sainsbury's Team Valley, Gateshead. Inky black with a thick, rocky tan head of foam. It has a sweet, rich liquorice, chocolate and plum flavour with brine notes and a warming, chocolate, roasted, leather and oak finish. Very Good.

Pours black with a full, foamy, thick tan head. The aroma consists of toasted malt, hazelnut, toffee, and hints of chocolate and espresso. Heavy bitterness in the taste. Here I find an interesting blend of toffee, licorice, toasted malts, and chocolate, which I’d say is are evenly balanced. I do get a some slight floral elements as well. The aftertaste is a long and lingering slightly toasted toffee. Its light to medium in body, with an oily texture, and some fizzy softer carbonation. An stout that is different than most others, I wish I had tried this one sooner.

Bottle. Pitch black with the classic Guinnes head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and a little bit of coffee. Taste is malts, liquorice and dark chocolate. Aftertaste is full of hoppy bitterness. Very balanced. Neither too sweet, alcoholic nor bitter. Great.

Nose: weak coffee and malt

Taste: medium full bodied, roasted malt, dark cholocate and coffee, average carbonation, simple bitter sweet beer!

Aftertaste: medium long

It’s good but it must be serve from a cask! IMO, a bottled or canned Guinness rating will be lower.

Bottle. Dark, stouty brownish-black pour with a medium tan head, above average retention. Nose is dried fruit, roast, caramelly malt, cocoa. Mouth is medium-full, creamy on the palate, roasty bittersweet, some soot, coffee, toasted nuts. Reminds me a lot the first Guinness I had back in 1988 (when it wasn’t in pub draught cans yet, and was mainly available bottled under the name ’Extra Stout’)... although that was bit more bitter than this. PS: Fuck Valentine’s Day. The only saint I recognize is the one whose day is 26 days from now.

Bottle from Asda. Pours dense black, with a big tan head falling to a rim of froth. Nose is sweet, creamy, and also bitter burnt malt. Taste is bitter-sweet, a little creamy, well balanced. Palate is light, short, but decent. Good stuff, but get the Nigerian if you can, it’s quite a bit sweeter and better for it.

Bottle. Pitch Brown-Black in colour. Very Malty; roast/burnt malts, espresso coffee, liquorice, chocolate, toffee. Hoppy; earthy hop bitterness. Smooth. Full bodied. Sweet roast malts balanced by tangy sour bitter hops. Increasingly dry throughout. Long burnt bitter malt/hop aftertaste. (2011-04-26)

Deep black with a thin but creamy head that has a tan colour. Aroma is a bit of toasted malt. Taste is mostly burnt toast and malt with a slightly tart finish. Taste brings out a whole lot of booze. Carbonation is pretty high.

Bottle pour into tulip glass from Signal Variety. Appearance is pitch black with finger-width light brown head with poor retention and nice speckled lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, earthy European hops, vanilla. Taste is rich, sweet-over-bitter roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla. Palate is full bodied with thick texture, average carbonation and finish as taste. Overall, really strong across the board.

Une pièce au puzzle de Guinness, c’est toujours amusant, mais on se demande parfois à quel jeu 
on joue … Il est curieux de voir comment cette brasserie peut décliner un stout en supposant des
goûts établis en divers lieux !!! Ici, nous avons donc la version continentale de la "foreign stout", 
qui s’appelle "foreign extra" et qui titre à 7,5 % abv, que je voulais personnellement comparer à la
version spécifiquement belge de la "special export" (attention on se perd vite chez Diageo .. mais c’est grand !!), et qui titre à 8 % abv .. Cette dernière, on ne la trouve qu’en Belgique !!
Niveau abv donc ici de 7,5 %, en format 33 cl, dont la bouteille est très différente de la Belgique.
Mon exemplaire était à 10 mois de sa date limite. 
Couleur noir profond, à l’opacité forte.
Mousse brun grisâtre assez vilain, mais avec un peu de structure ferme en haut, et stable à 12 mm
(si on fait un versage vigoureux .. dans un verre de 50 cl de préférence).
Arômes de chocolat, café, brindilles au feu, pointe de violette .. étrange !!
1ère bouche souple à l’ensemble sur du foin brûlé.
Arrière-bouche longue, avec ce champ brûlé au loin...
2ème à l’ensemble vraiment curieux, entre le porter et le stout.
Arrière-bouche au fumé assez fin, et comme proche de votre nez .. c’est amusant.
Le reste est du pareil au même ..
Aucune évolution sur la longueur, et c’est voulu par le patron, figurez-vous !! Je dirais même que c’est un peu en-dessous, mais il ne faut pas lui dire ...
Jambes assez collantes.
Alcool qui ne fait pas son niveau, et de loin !!
Finale en-dessous de la longueur.
CONCLUSION : assez navrant, mais on a ici littéralement "édulcoré" la foreign pour en faire 
un produit passe-partout, pas trop méchant, pas trop charbonné … assez cool même pour que Madame
y mette le bout des lèvres … Mais que cherche-t-on chez Guinness ? Poser la question, c’est y répondre .. on cherche à vendre, point final.
Quand vous passez par la Belgique, prenez-vous la version belge "special export" de 8 % abv,
vous goûterez la différence, parce que Diageo n’a pas osé se moquer de la Belgique .. Ils savent en tous les cas que les belges aiment une bière bien calibrée en abv, et la belge fait réellement ses 8 %.

33cl in Niamey. BB 01/07/2017.
Brune foncée, presque noir, col épais retenant un col épais moka voire café au lait.
Arôme garde un bouquet grillé malté assez cara pils-pâle avec une touche de grillé perdurant.Rétro finement chocolaté noir.


Palais est réchauffant avec de suite une attaque des 7.5%, le tout est assez soyeux est crémeux avec un caractère chocolaté bien présent. Fine amertume arrive en fin de bouche avec un rebond d’un chocolat noir amer. Soyeux avec une certaine épaisseur de bouche.
Trouve cette version plus aboutie que la base plus légère irlandaise. Se retrouve proche de la version belge.

Drinking from a 0,5 l bottle. 
In the aroma caramel, malt. 
The clear black beer has a medium brown head. 
In the taste beans, chocolate. 
Low carbonated.
Noire comme la nuit. Noisette, café au nez. En bouche, torréfaction, malt grillé, un peu de choco noir. Amertume légère qui s’étend. Bonne.

tres bonne stout ,bien noir avec un bon gout boisé ,vraiment une de mes préféré mais je n ai pas mis le maximum car pour moi la guiness pression est vraiment au dessus par son onctuosité et sa mousse si particuliere que je n ai pas retrouvé avec cette bouteille.

330ml bottle [A big thanks to Aziz!]. Quasi black colour with average to huge, thick, frothy, fairly lasting, moderately lacing, beige head. Minimally musty, grainy, slightly chocolately, dark malty aroma, hints of liquorice. Taste is dry, roasty dark malty, slightly chocolately, subtle sweetness, a touch of treacle and malt lozenge, some liquorice, chalky impurities; chalky, mineral finish. 
Earlier Rating: 10/7/2012 Total Score: 3.3
330ml bottle. Clear darkest brown colour with a reddish tinge, small to average, frothy to creamy, lasting, lacing, beige head. Slightly roasty dark malty aroma, a nuttily touch, underlying dark fruit notes, bitter hoppy overtones. Taste is initially roasty dark malty and converges over salty to dry and bitter hoppy.

Yau, rosty with a flower touch. Äußerst ansehnlich kommt unser ölige Genosse daher. Braun gekrönt und very dark. Mmmmhhhh. Der erste gut gekühlte Schluck läßt erstmal den Eindruck eines staubtrockenen Gesöffs zurück. Yepp !!!! Später wird’s dann filigraner, ein bisschen Beerenflair hier und angehonigte Rauchwolken da. Nett. Und schön bitter bleibt’s trotzdem. Klasse Stoff für den Stouthead. 0,33l Flasche aus Düsseldorf. Nicht billig 🙄.

330ml bottle. Thick dark brown pour with a dark mocha head. Oak and sweet smoked bacon aroma, with faint dark malts. Flavours of roasted malts, a touch of sweet cream, and a roguish hint of asparagus.

Perfect pour. Looks like regular Guinness with trademark tan head and jet black body. Aroma of nut, chestnut, dark roasted nuances and toffee. Coffee and vanilla on the palate. This is the best Guinness I’ve had, but very rich and probably best to have one to start the night with (savour and enjoy) before moving on to session regular Guinness. Can’t wait to get some in for my wife at Xmas as she’s only had regular Guinness. If you can session this, you’re hardcore!

Lukt: Kaffe og kirsebær.

Utseende: Sort.

Skum/kullsyre: Tykt skum.

4/20 fairly disgusting. Prefer normal Guinness which is creamier. This is really flat, sour tasting stout. Not a nice taste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bouteille. Je ne me rappelle pas avoir bu de la Stout et ... je découvre une bière tout à fait différente de mes apéritifs habituels et qui me plait. C’est une bière très noire à belle mousse brune mais qui retombe assez vite. Les arômes sont de ce qui m’a le plus impressionné (surpris) : café, moka, fruits noirs (pruneau), caramel, grillé, fumé ... L’entrée en bouche est impressionnante aussi avec une belle et bonne effervescence. Je retrouve bien sûr le café moka, un peu de piquant, d’autres choses que je vais découvrir plus tard car je pense bien reprendre de ce breuvage et surprise : une belle amertume. La longueur est exceptionnelle et les saveurs persistent dans la bouche. Vais-je reprendre une autre bière après CELA ?
Total black body with a thick brown head.Aromas are bread,caramel,coffee,liquorice...the grat thing is that you can taste them. It bitter and sweet at the same time...Loved it

Bottle from nightshop drank at Girl Scout place. Almost black with fizzy dark brown head. Licorice, lots of dark bread, overripe plums, spices, rum, vanilla and burnt sugar. Medium sweet and bitter. Bit over medium bodied with quite some fizzy carbonation.

The archetypical (even historically first ever) ’foreign stout, tasted many years ago in the original Irish version and revisited last year in its Burkinese version (from a bottle) and Togolese version (from a can), both of them received from Ruben, cheers. Lightly and irregularly lacing, moussy, pale greyish beige head with good ’edge retention’, slowly dissipating in the middle but leaving thin veils of foam; very dark mahogany brown colour but black in general appearance, limiting its maroon hue to the edges. Aroma cannot hide pasteurization - the first thing that springs to my nostrils - in a cooked vegetable-kind of way and also reveals a whole lot of tin can-like iron, overseeing less unpleasant aspects of diluted coffee grounds or even ’green’ coffee beans, pistachio nuts and peanuts, industrial beef stock cubes and even some gravy, haemoglobin, something sulfuric (egg yolk or even further than that), soggy brown bread, old dusty closets. Sourish and sweetish onset, roasted barley sourishness with dried fig sweetishness but both subdued and surrounded by a somewhat beef stock-like umami edge, softish carbonation, smooth oily mouthfeel, gliding effortlessly over the surface of the tongue, leaving behind a trail of malt bittersweetness, nothing too thick or layered here, just a fairly pleasant evolution from sweetish nuttiness towards toasted bitterishness, roasted in the very end but gently so, while at the same time delivering an unmistakable metallic, iron-like flavor, but not more so than in other variations on this theme I had and not more so than in a regular European draught Guinness. Finishes with ongoing ’nuttiness’ and the aforementioned increased roasted bitterness, supported by - as announced on the can - spicy hops but not to the point that they become obvious over the roasted barley; warming, almost rum-like alcohol is there as well producing a sedative glow in the back, nothing astringent or anything like that, but still perhaps a bit too obvious for a 7.5% beer. The metallic edge remains palpable but in a mild, not too obnoxious kind of way. I do not tend to have high expectations from African beers - as long as the international craft beer revolution has not reached it - but this is, all things considered, an enjoyable stout. It has a thicker umami effect and more ’moelleux’ feeling to it (but equally strong iron) than the widespread Guinness Draught you’ll find in any overly commercial Irish - or other - pub in Europe; in fact, I think I like this one, certainly the African versions, better.  Feels less industrial than some other of Guinness’ stouts, quite filling and tasty, surely among the best African beers I had so far (which still doesn’t mean a lot, obviously) but lacks some of the ’exoticness’ of the Nigerian version I had ten years ago, which differs from other African (or any) Guinness stouts in using roasted sorghum, whereas this one apparently uses the classic roasted barley.

Aroma- dark bread, roasty,caramel, 
dark brown, nice foam, tall and smooth. Taste- sweet - light, bitter - medium, like Graham bread (personally I don’t like), bitterness from dark malt, body - full, creamy, carbonation flat.

330 ml bottle. Pours very dark brown with beige, lasting head. Sweet aroma of cacao and chocolate. The taste starts very sweet, dried fruits, giving away to coffee and a long, bitter finish. Medium carbonation, a bit oily. Quite good in overall, but too sweet for my taste.

33cl. Bottle. Black body, small lasting brown head. Aroma of molasse, chocolate, liquorice, light roasted malt and coffee. Flavours of roasted malt, coffee, light dried fruit notes, some liquorice, Good bitterness overall. Medium bitter finish.

Vierte negra opaca con espuma cremosa de color beige de muy buena retención. En nariz destacan granos tostados, malta chocolate, en un fondo con ligeros toques a vainilla y crema de whisky, ligeramente ahumada, tabaco. Sabores de entrada a malta tostada, agrio característico sin ser muy prominente, de final seco y ligeramente amargo con cierto retrogusto a palo de regaliz.
Dark brown body with a light brown head. Aroma is malty, caramel. Taste is sweet and light bitter. Light roasted coffee.

Bottle at home in Barbados, 17th August 16. Can’t believe I have not rated this before. Pours a thin black ale, some visible carbonation. Aroma is roasty, ashy, slight metallic. Taste is complex from the start, ash, tobacco, cocoa, roasted malts, liquorice. Really nice stuff.

330 ml bottle from Meinl am Graben, Vienna, bb 04/02/17.

Black body, with a big, creamy, lacing, brown-beige head.

Aroma of tiramisu, caramel, coffee, cocoa powder, some vanilla, slight dark fruits.

Tastes of coffee, caramel, cocoa powder, vanilla, some wood, some liquorice, slight dark fruits.

Medium, very creamy mouthfeel, with an average carbonation.

Finishes roasty-bitter, quite dry, with coffee, cocoa powder, liquorice, wood, subtly sweet, a bit alcohol warming.



Tasty. Quite sweet, but well balanced, with enough roastiness and a lovely coffee/caramel combination. Great smooth, creamy palate. Very good style example, fully aromatic, but really quaffable at the same time. Another proof that this is one of the very best macro breweries.
Bottle - Pours black, creamy tan head. Curious aroma of coffee, burnt pancakes, chocolate syrup, and funk. The flavor is better, and somewhat typical of stout, maybe a little on the sweet side.

17/VII/16 - bottle @ home, preGF tasting - BB: n/a (2016-765) Thanks to Alengrin for sharing this new country tick!


Clear dark brown to black beer, big creamy irregular beige head, pretty stable, adhesive, leaving some lacing in the glass. Aroma: very roasted, coffee, mocha, caramel, very malty, grains, wort. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: sweet start, alcohol, sweet, caramel, bit malty, dark chocolate, little sourish. Aftertaste: bitter hops, metallic, bit sweet, alcohol, grains, malty, more alcohol.

Has similar roasted flavours to Guinness original, but a less bitter lighter fruitier taste. Flavours are of blackcurrant, coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa, malt and some mild brandy type flavours. Good stuff would try again.

Price paid: £1.89.

Aroma: roasted dark malts, red dried fruits.
Appearance: jetblack and brown head.
Taste: smoky notes, roasted dark malts, red fruits, bitter chocolate, bonfire, semi-dry.
Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, roasted finish.
Overall: Great FES, really smooth and balanced.

From 330ml bottle. Black with big head. Tastes of liquorice, malty, raisins and chocolate. Good body and much a much nicer stout than Guinness Original

Bouteille 33 cl - couleur marron trouble, texture épaisse, farineuse, mousse légére et onctueuse beige, odeur sur le grain de café, goût sur le café, le caramel dur, amertume présente en fin de bouche, pas trop fan

Bottle 0,33L. Black color with big, long lasting, creamy head. Aroma of chocolate, sweet dark fruits, caramel and a touch of alcohol. Taste starts light bitter, but suddenly become vinous (reminds me of red wine) and than becomes moderate to heavy bitter again. Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Way better than the regular one...
Smager meget som draught’en, men den forskellen er at den ikke er nær så "flødeagtig" i det. Den har også mere smag af lakrids. Helt klart bedre.

Pas trop fan de cette stout un peu seiche. le grillé est léger, les arômes traditionnels de caramels et café sont peu présent
Belle couleur sombre mais mousse un peu légère.
If you ever thought Guinness would be nicer if it were concentrated down, this is the drink for you. Spicy, nutty and absolutely delicious.
Au nez chocolat et café, plus complex au goût qur la guiness des pubs français. (Plus de café?!) Terreux et amertume parfaite. Sucré et alcoolisé...perfect

(Bottle from DuffMan. Thx Tony!) Une présentation quasi impeccable. Un nez de mélasse brûlée, de légère réglisse, de café, de charbon de bois et de vanille avec une timide touche citronnée. Un goût de malts noircis, de café vieilli et de chocolat sans sucre. Un corps arrondi mais souple. Une finale amère de torréfaction. Bien content de boire cette bière. Une surprise des plus intéressantes.

Black beer with a brown head. Richy, bitter malt smell. Chocolatey malt taste up front but there’s a dash of tangy, fruity hop in there to balance it a touch and some dark chocolate which comes through slowly just when I thought the flavour had petered out. Rich, tasty stout.

Served in a snifter from a 330ml bottle. Pours almost black opaque colour with a thick dark beige head which is slowly diminishing leaving nice lacing in the glass. Aroma is roasted malts, smoke, dark chocolate and molasses. Taste is ash, dark chocolate, molasses, smoked prunes, slightly sour finish. Oliy texture with soft carbonation. Extremely nice stout!
Bottle from saveur-biere.com. Color is dark. Head is medium and brown. Body is thin to medium. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter. Aroma is liquorice, caramel, chocolate, roasted.

Taste: rich toasted malt, slight fruit and spiced licorice notes with gentle hop in background. Dry toasted aroma.
Black and opaque, with a dark creamy head.

Bottle. Stunned it’s not rated, it’s often the only decent beer in a local shop. Nose is dark chocolate, toast, roast malt, light smoke. Taste is slightly sour, ash, chocolate, hint of blackcurrant and licorice, caramel, hint of yoghurt, prunes. Mouthfeel is oily. 

It’s one of the few drinkable beers from St James’ Gate these days.
Bottle - dark and dense with large frothy tan head. Only faint aroma - good mouthfeel, thick and silky, full of flavour with good bitter finish.
Bottle @ a local watering hole. Black body with a medium head. Roasted notes, earth, coffee.
Top 10 for my favorite stouts. I love the bite that comes with it and the taste of barley. More complex than normal Guinness. I finally found it locally.

33cl bottle at the Gentse Kano en Kajak Organisatie in Ghent (7 IV 2016). First things first. I was handed an overdue bottle, almost two years after the expiration date. I always let my beers mature past the best-before date, yet I expect a fresh beer bottle when buying one. One can imagine that this appreciation thus is rather different, opposed to a normal foreign extra stout. Let’s have a go. This classic extra stout has a very smarmy, oily character. This Irish version from St. James’s Gate pours a thick greasy liquid, really sticking to the glass, pitchblack and with a firm brown, cassonade collar on top. Good looking for sure. The scents are infiltrated with strong smoked ham notes, full of smoky malts. The taste has lots of coffee, bitters, some caramellish and dark sugar features. Very oily, medium to strong bodied. A great malts sensation, with lots of roast, from a bitterish almost imperial stout brew. This is a perfect strong black beer!

Bottle. Thanks to my buddy Trevor for bringing me this (and an entire box more!) from Belize. Shame I don’t get the country tick though (oh well, the shitty green bottles lagers will give me that!). This pours very dark, with a lasting creamy beige head. Aroma is dark bready caramel, undertones of roast and prunes. The plate is the same, but more assertive on the roast end, with some subtle medicinal notes in there too (God knows how old this bottle is lol). Moderate roasty bitterness. Rather oily texture, with a nice full body. Better than expected!
Bottle. Pours black. Aroma of dark chocolate, roast malt and coffee. Bitter and sweet taste with some smokiness.
Bottle. Black with a dark foam. Aroma: burnt barley and sugar, cofee. Taste: very burnt, prunes, a little cream cheese, sourness with sweetness, bitter aftertaste.

Great brown-beige top which is pretty longlasting, creameaness as guiness draught but more choclate notes and very pleasant bitterness. Aroma of bitter chocalate but doesnt seem much better than the regular guiness, could be stronger. Apart from that very good beer, good for session drinking but still having the taste. I would reccommend

Bottle. Gorgeous looking black with fluffy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, anise, slight tangy note. Taste is sweet chocolate, smoke, malt. The bitterness carries it through, knocking out the sweetness. There’s a faint sour citrus note I’m getting. Medium-bodied, smoothly carbonated. Always enjoy getting a bottle of this, Guinness like my uneducated palate used to know, bitter and roasty.

From Hipercor. In Teku glass. Watching True Detective 2x03. Much better than the more common Guinness Draught. That one I cant finish. This one Ive enjoyed. Addictive aroma and good taste and mouthfeel
Thick treacle colour on bottle pour into bishop finger goblet. Tan head lively and creamy. Rich burnt coffee smell. Mmm warming coffee and treacle in mouth . Excellent.

Why oh why was my former rating nuked? I’ll settle that score later... but here i sit relaxing in the shade at theresort and this glorious elixer is brought to me. Straight from the bottle is the Centeal American way. So turn your noses up if you woll but if you do, you are a knuckle draggin biscuit suckin hick. Dark syruppy malt nose. Bitterness follows suit and stays steady.
Bottle bought in an asian supermarket in Berlin - Color is pitch-black, head brownish, texture oily. Aroma a bit smoky, malty, strong taste of liquorice. Rather dry finish.

Bottle at bar. Black color, beige head. Bitter taste with roasted malts, nuts, espresso, chocolate and a bit of wood. Bitter finish with roasted malts, nuts, chocolate, espresso and wood. Very nice stout.

Bottle at #x shitty tasting in Belgrade. Really dark brown, lingering foam, Guinness color is best I can say. Malty syrup, a little roast. Enough of a guinness stout flavor but really quite syrupy and sweet. Body is really strange but flavor is quite fine. Dry malty finish, solid. Tasty.
Black pour, small tan head. Aroma of prune, raisin and lychee. Flavor of alcohol, raisin, chocolate, and a hint of burnt coffee.

Bottle.
Appearance: Intense black color with a dense, frothy, light brown foam.
Smell: Very malty and sweet.
Aroma: Intense notes of chocolate and coffee. Hints of citrus, ripe banana and smoke.
Taste: First, there is only the sweetness, which gets more and more intense. At its height, the bitterness kicks in and balances the sweetness perfectly. There is a light sourness all the way through. This gives some freshness.
Palate: Beer has a full body and has a creamy and sticky mouth feel. The carbonation is just right. The pleasant bitterness is quite long lasting.
Overall: For people who like the standard Guinness Draught, this is a very nice change for special days. It has the typical Guinness character with a special kick.

0.33 l bottle from ’Saveur Bière’, brewed in Ireland, bottled in July or August 2015. Clear, very dark red to black with a medium large, dense, almost stable, brown head. Faint, roasty-malty, slightly fruity aroma of dark chocolate, coffee and raisins. Sweetish, roasty-malty taste of dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, licorice and hints of raisins, followed by a short, roasty-bitter finish. Medium to full body, creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. The aroma lacks a bit of intensity but otherwise this is quite good.
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of coffee, caramel and toffee. taste is coffee and grains.
Bue en bouteille. Belle couleur noire. Goût fruité, de vin rouge, de chocolat noire, de caffée. Une bonne stout.
Nice coffee and strong caramel tones, a rich intricate body with pleasant aroma and a beautiful dark color. One of my all-time favoties!

Bottle 0.33l at the Weird shitty tasting at Beerville Bar Belgrade Serbia.Bottle from Delhaize Maxi store Belgrade.Pour it almost clear dark color with small white head.Aroma quite light coffee.Taste really light, watery, some roasted feel on the back, quite easy drinkable.
Smoky aroma, smells like indigowoad root. With a little indigowoad root taste and a little sour. Dry finish.

Butelka 330ml. Ciemnobrunatny wrecz czarny w kolorze z palona brazowa piana ktora redukuje sie do malej obreczy. W zapachu dominuje kawa.karmel.Smak ma swietne polaczenie slodowo goryczkowe. Dominuje kawa karmel czekolada palone cukry. Schlodzone jest fenomenalne.

Bottle bought in an asian supermarket in Berlin - Color is pitch-black, head brownish, texture oily. Aroma a bit smoky, malty, strong taste of liquorice. Rather dry finish. Doesnt feel like 7.5% at all. Excellent.

Black color and huge head.
Strong roasted malty aroma.
Taste is bitter and sour.
Long finish!

Bottle: Pours black and oily with a lovely deep tan head like a good gypsy tart. Muscovado sugar and liquorice aroma’s, malty and chocolate flavours with mild bitter finish, medium dry. Excellent stout.

A little sweeter than the draught. Bit of the licorice flavor. ---Rated via BeerBuddy for iPhone.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle served in a tulip glass. Slightly chilled. One finger medium tan head, Plenty of lacing. Beer is dark. Aroma has malty notes of toast and hay. Beer is robust with light sweetness and medium bitterness. Primarily roasted malts with light notes of chocolate and coffee as well ass nuts and toast. Medium bodied beer with an almost oily texture and average carbonation. Lightly bitter finish. Overall great stout. Didn’t even know existed.

Dark brown color with tan head. Aroma is liquorice, coffee, chocolate. Taste is similar, with roasted malts, some milkiness, surprisingly watery for this ABV. Surprisingly high carbonation as well. A classic, but not my favourite.

Good stuff this dark choclatey no bitterness smooth creamy head.
Cadburys choclate with espresso nice
Bottle from the brewery. black pour with a coffee coloured head. Aroma is milk chocolate with caramel and hops. Very smooth and rich, nice complexity.
Pitch black pour, huge head. Sweet taste and aroma of Molasses, wood, black liquorice. Fairly bitter, thick body with a dry mouthfeel.

Black body, small lasting brown head. Aroma of molasse, chocolate, liquorice, light roasted malt and coffee. Flavours of roasted malt, coffee, light dried fruit notes, some liquorice, Good bitterness overall. Medium bitter finish, slightly dry.
Bottle. Black with a brown head. Aroma is molasses, chocolate, cereal. Palate is a bit too dry, loads of coffee and dark chocolate. Decent but a bit all over the place.

Bottle->English pint. Black with massive tan head. A: choclate malt, lite nuts, grains. T: chocolate and roasted malts, underlying hop bite, grains. Good. Not as smooth as standard Guinness, but more interesting.
330ml bottle. Thick and black with a thin but lasting tan head. Aroma is chocolate, liquorice and leather. Taste is slight coffee and a lot of roasted malt but with a good bitterness to balance

Black with a thin vanishing head, lacings. Malty, caramel, cane molasses, light roasted. Average to very sweet, with a bitter lingering finish. Light carbonation , full bodied. A sweet and different but still enjoying stout.

275 ml bottle. Brewed in Saint Lucia. Opaque black liquid topped by a small tan head with clinging lace. Roasted malt nose with caramel notes. Bittersweet roasted malt upfront. Chewy, tannic, chocolatey, herbal hop notes. Much more assertive and complex than regular Guinness. Very tasty and enjoyable.

0.33l pullo irlannista. Muhkea kahvimainen pehmeä vaahto, mustanruskea väri. Kevyttä paahteisuutta tuoksussa, tulee jopa porterit mieleen. Savuinen, kalaisa, pehmeän samettinen, liukas. Paahteisuus jälkimakuna. Hyvää kamaa, joskaan ei kovin moniulotteinen.
Very nice dark appearance. Bigger hints of coffee and roasted barley than draught Guinness
Bottle. No label taken - Pours dark brown. Tan head. Nose/taste of sweet chocolate, roast, milky chocolate and vanilla - medium body.
It ha a taste of litte small lepricon that jump around in your mouth. Really pleasant. A good brew!
Bottle in France. Dark brown body big tan head. Nose sweet and roasty and malty. Taste is chocolate, malts, cocoa, roasted. Vanilla in the finish.
Noire, mousse chocolat.Nez chocolat au lait et café. Bouche café et chocolat, malts grillés. Amère , corps onctueux, légère acidité. La réfèrence ...

FTA. This is a reminder to self not to purchase it over and over again. Only Guinness I can drink is the one that comes form tap in at least England. All others are equal to Corona and other similar trademark names.

33cl bottle at our holiday home in France. Dark brown with a small tan head. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Medium sweet and bitter tones. Roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, ripe dark fruits and herbs. A tasty stout.

Amazing beige head and perfect lacing.
Black coffee and chocolate in aroma. 
Chocolate flavor. Sour and sweet taste.
Medium to high body.
Very good stout.

Sampled in Ireland with Linh, Scarlett and family. Pours a deep blackish brown body with thick tan head. Mouthfeel is medium with notes similar to other Guinness variants - light cocoa, soft roast and faint lactose/milk character. This seemed to have a bit more sweetness behind it.
