Bottle at Brussels. Interesting but kinda old school but I guess that should be expected with an old classic. Full bodied, creamy roast coffee and barley.
Pours black with a really thick tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee and a little chocolate. Taste is of charcoal, peat, roasted malt, toffee with just a hint of bitterness.
Dark brown coloured with a beige head. Aroma of alcohol and chocolate with roasted notes. Acidic flavour of coffee and prunes.
I prefer Draught, but at $2.50 for a pint of it, you can’t complain. Smells of coffee and malt, pours a deep black (they call it the black stuff for a reason) Tastes like Draught but a little watery.

33cl bottle from speciaalbier Leiden. 
Thick creamy tan head. Clear black pour. It’s of chocolate. Very nice.

Bottle shared thanks to Deanso. Pours near black with a big tan head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, sweet malt, fudge, light chocolate and some light dark fruity notes. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light moderate bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Ok non è la guinness alla spina che si può bere nei pub di dublino, ma tra quelle prodotte in bottiglia della guinness è la migliore.

Une de mes préférées ! En grande part d’un point de vue sentimental je dois avouer...
Le nez est sucré, chocolaté et fruité genre fruits confis.
En bouche, on retrouve la guinness draught mais portée avec bien plus de sucre, d’alcool et un fort arôme de pruneau !
Ceux qui aiment pas les stouts peuvent détester celle-ci.

330ml bottle from Asda. (£1.25) This is very good. Rich coffee and chocolate. Yum! The slightly harsh finish is followed by a lovely warm glow. This is by far the best Guinness I've tasted. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Foam: nice light brown, medium lasting, lingers.
Colour: very dark brown, opaque.
Aroma: roasted coffee, dark chocolate, malt, caramel, fruit, vanilla, a hint of smoke.
Taste: roasted sweet malty, chocolate first then some fruits, liquorice, little oily, dry smoky/roast bitter/hoppy long finish, medium carbonation, medium to high body, pretty good beer anyway.

Pours dark brown with a brown head. Dark and sweet from the nose. Thick flavored, like drinking chocolate but with a kick. Finishes with sweet cocoa and a bit of bitterness. I preferred this highly over a non-draft Guinness as it isn’t watery, though I have to admit that a properly poured Guinness is quite delicious.

Pours a dark brown with a proud, well-retaining light khaki head. I’m picking up a lot of chocolate and brown sugar glaze on the nose. Pretty thick with some faint carbonation. Liqueur-filled chocolate flavor. Finishes with unsweetened cocoa powder. Vastly different than any Guiness I’ve ever had. This one’s actually good!

Beautiful pitch black color. A little layer of creamy almond foam. Nice bitter toasted/roasted smell. It smells of nice barley roasted till perfection. It has however a little hint of iodine. You can also smell the alcohol. The taste is great. Smokey flavor of the roasted barley, combined with a perfect sweetness. This beer is in extraordinary balance. Almost better than regular drought Guinness.
Noget skuffende udgave af en Guinness Stout. Smagen og eftersmagen er helt som den skal være - mørk og brændt. Men konsistensen og oplevelsen virker for tynd som vand!
Butelka, piwo legenda.Czarny kolor, bardzo treściwe, piana mocna.Aromaty chmielu, wanilii, orzechów i whisky. Smak czekolady, kawy, palonego jęczmienia. Kremowe, syte. Piwo doskonałe.

I’d been a "purist" as far as Guinness is concerned prior to picking this up, but a good friend insisted it was good so I gave it a whirl. Smell of toasted malt goodness, but kind of muted and watery. Taste is truly a work of beauty with coffee, chocolate, licorice and a light carbonated touch alongside the malts...much stronger flavor than the usual Guinness! Surprisingly quaffable and not super heavy for a stout. Slightly over-cabonated for my tastes, but is an excellent beer that I was pleasantly surprised by regardless. Very good.

Barring more obscure beers found at specialist suppliers this is my favourite alcoholic drink at the minute. Its quite potent and creates an immediate and lasting impression. Lovely burnt coffee aroma and taste with a lovely thick feel to it. If the head was more substantial I would give it full marks. Far superior to standard guiness and even better than the west Indies porter.

Bottle from off licence somewhere in London. dark brown, rich beige head, good lacing. Very easy drinking beer. Some roasted malt, coffee and chocolate in aroma, but wait, also a bit if sour cabbage, but not bad, just a hint, and I hate this smell in beer. Taste is very coffee, chocolate smooth mouthfeel and a bitter sweet delicate finish.

One of only a handful of beers to gain the 5 rating, not my favourite but in my top 5, Guinness Foreign extra stout is not only the ultimate Guinness and Ultimate stout, but arguably the ultimate alcoholic drink ever conceived.

It’s nose is powerful, an formidable presence, igniting the senses with unrivalled hop and Roasted Malt’s, Toasted Espresso and Burn’t Barley in perfect unison.

It pours a heroic grade stout of Dark but not draught black liquor, thick, and cloudy, developing a small, quickly clearing tan head which sizzles slightly before standing as the dark ruby knight it is.

In the mouth, it instantly gives way to a very harsh, full, bitter, malty weight and amazing grittiness which leaves the mouth feeling very malty.

It tastes pretty much as you expect from Guinness but amplified with no trace of velvet smoothness present in draught.
A dominating storm of roasted caramel, Galena hop, roasted malt barley, coffee, liquorice and ginger light the moth and taste buds on fire as it’s cocoa like element adds the charismatic hits of almond, hazelnut, and smoked wood tones.

The Finish is very powerful, bitter chocolate, and toasty nuttiness, fulfilling, thirst quenching, challenging and perfect.
Black brown colour with small firm head. Smell and taste of roasted malts, plums, and hints of coffee. Dry aftertaste with little bitterness.

* Bottle. Pours black, with a frothy cream coloured head. * Aroma is strong, roast malt, burnt toffee, chocolate. * Palate is full body, medium carbonation, very fine bubbles. * Taste is sweet malt, toffee, dark chocolate & coffee. * Finish is thick & rich, malty, chocolate. * Overall: Very rich, sweet, toffee & chocolate, compared to Guinness Original.
Butelka 330 ml. Bardzo ładnie się prezentuje, czarne/ciemno brązowe, piana gęsta, długo się utrzymuje, w smaku czarna kawa, gorzka czekolada i lekka kwaskowość.
Origin: Bottle. Vessel: Pint Glass. Supplier: Guinness Storehouse (Dublin). Sweet first giving way to roasted bitterness.

Bottle 0,65ltr: Opaque black colored brew with an sweet bitter taste with an well hidden sournesh. Hints of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and caramel. This one is brewed at Guinness Cameroun and bought it in the Hague at Africa Products Shop, Spui 231. Handy with an Nigerian girlfriend to find this kind of shops, extra handy if they sell African beers for foreign ticks.
330ml Flasche. Rabenschwarz und klar. Grosse, dunkle Schaumkrone. Starkes Kaffeearoma. Süsser Nachgeschmack mit einer leicht bitteren Note.

0.65 l bottle from local supermarket in Paris. Colour is black and the head is light brown and won’t die away. Yes, Extra Stout is better than the common version called draught. This version has more hops than the one available in Ireland. Probably to hide the high amount of alcohol. The result is a nice dry taste combined with the usual Guinness experience. No, I’m not working for them.

huge light brown frothy creamy head. excelente lacing. mostly lasting. flat sparkling thick black body. aroma: light coffee, black chocolate, heavy nutty malt, caramel. if: moderate sweet light bitter. ff: light sweet moderate bitter; long duration. palate: oily texture, metallic finish, lively carbonation, médium body. dulçor de caramelo. toque metalizado no paladar surge como fedeito. background de café, bem balanceado. espuma lembra areia movediça. 70s

12 oz bottle. Clear, dark brown color, medium beige head. Nose of char, roasted malt, coffee grounds and a bit of sherry.Taste has some roasted barley, black coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Fresh carbonation, medium mouth feel. Some sweetness perfectly checked by the bitterness. Loads of flavor, yet balanced and somehow drinkable. Alcohol completely hidden. Strong and good.

Pours black with a khaki head. Roasted malt, earthy hop, caramel, toffee and a sweet funk aroma. Chocolate, earthy hop, sweet funk, caramel, toffee and roasted malt flavors. Medium full body and moderate carbonation. Chocolate, malt and herb finish.
In bottiglia da 33cl. Aroma di torrefatto e liquirizia non molto intensi. al palato corpo rotondo, alcool percettibile e sentori di liquirizia e torrefatto puliti ma non molto intensi.
Interesting but kinda old school but I guess that should be expected with an old classic. Full bodied, creamy roast coffee and barley.

This is a world class beer using an old Irish recipe which has the wort/mash exposed to wild yeasts. This along with the use of high quality barley malts and enough hopping to please an American palate makes this beer a surprise find from the Guinness Brewery which is owned by the Diageo Group (read Smirnoff). The beer is made to transport and because of this cellars very well and even bottle conditions which producing a great Irish stout.

The way Guinness should taste! 

I pick up a hint of dark fruit such as cherry or raisin in the aroma along with a slight peatiness. Very full bodied and creamy. Gorgeous beer.

Flasche (33 cl) vom Asia-Mekong-Supermarkt, Berlin. - Pechschwarz; dunkelbeigefarbener Schaum. - Nase dunkelmalzig (Mokka) und sirupartig süß. - Antrunk süßsäuerlich dunkelmalzig. Die Röstaromen sind etwas flach, das breite dunkle Malz dominiert, aufgelockert durch deutliche Säure, lakritzartig. Hopfenherb aber wenig hopfenaromatisch. Mild rezent, weinig schwer, weich im Mund. Im Abgang noch mehr fülliges dunkles Malz, durch genügend Hopfen im Hintergrund bitter abgerundet. - Sehr malzbetontes, schweres Stout, weniger gut gehopft und weniger komplex als bessere Stouts.
330ml bottle. Roast malt and licorice aroma and flavour with some caramel. Thick medium longevity tan head coats the glass marking each sip. Mouth feel is dense, carbonated, mildly bitter and dry.
Decent stout not as dry as regular Guinness stronger in alcohol and flavour coats the tongue not a session beer but nice as one of two at home nice oily mout feel and roastiness

Sweet caramel aroma hinting of burnt sugar and super sweet dates. Lovely thick cappuccino mocha head and extremely dark ruby liquid. Flavour is burnt grains and dark fruits, otherwise quite clean. A little watery but easy going for its strength and satisfyingly nutritious seeming.

Bottle @Guinness Storehouse. Definitely the best out of the Guinness? production. Loved the appearance and the taste, hints of coffee and chocolate, not so much the slight alcoholic touch it delivers.
Good Stout. And there is coffee and cocoa. Good body, thus easily is drunk despite the degree.
Negra, boa formação de espuma. Aroma de chocolate ao lei, café leve, leve tosta. Sabor idem. Boa carbonatação. Corpo médio. Baixo amargor. Aftertaste doce, agradável. O álcool não aparece.

stout bier, zeer mooi zwart bier met schuimige beige/bruine kraag.
aroma van zoete candy, karamel en gebrande mouten.
smaak: alcoholisch, vol moutig, caramel, zoet, lichte toffee tonen. gebrande mouten en koffie. redelijke body, afdronk is lang bitter. ... ff alle gekheid op en stokje,,,, is dit niet gewoon dezelfde versie als de http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/rate/9155/ ?

I could have sworn I tasted and rated this beer, but I was evidentially wrong. I purchased a four-pack at my local Wegmans and brought this delicious brew home to enjoy. The beer poured a pitch-black color with a dark tan head. The head laced all kinds of goodness around the inside of the glass. The nose is bright and full, with notes of cream, vanilla, sweet hops and a light hint of whiskey/alcohol. The body is quite big and full. You almost have to chew this beer. The alcohol content kind of sneaks up on you a little bit. The flavors include cream, chocolate, roasted barley, toasted bread, sweet malts, caramel and a hint of coffee. This is definitely a stout to savor and enjoy.

Bottle at home. Pours dark brown to black with a foamy tan head. Aroma is roasty with some dark chocolate also. Flavor follows and is very smooth. This is a very nice beer, better than the regular stuff.
Pours basically black with a brown head. Sweet malt aroma and a big sweet malt taste with a roast finish.

Licorice aroma with moderate amounts of roast on the nose. Dark brown appearance with a thick tan head. Flavor is sweet with moderate bitterness on the end note. Fruity ester level is high. Medium full body with medium carbonation. Overall, it matches the style well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a nice dark color with a nice frothy .head. Aromas of caramel, coffee and earthiness.Tastes of bitterness with a full body.I did not like this Guiness as much as the other regular one.

Bottle in Germany. Clear, dark brown color, medium beige head. Aroma is nicely cocoa, roasted malt, toffee and coffee. Rather dry taste with a high bitterness. Aftertaste has some nice whisky-roasted barley notes, chocolate. Fresh carbonation, medium mouthfell.

From 275 ml bottle since I had no glass at hand. Nice roasted coffee aromas. Strong, astringent bitter coffee taste that leaves a long lingering burned flavor in the mouth. High carbonation but still a lightly creamy mouthfeel. Definitely differs from the Irish version of it! Good beer though.

Aroma is dark roast coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Roasted coffee, coca, vanilla bean, and caramel for flavors. Definitely more roasted and stronger than regular Guinness. I really enjoyed this one.

Pours a dark brown to black with a slight tan head. The aroma is very pleasant of the roasted barley. Its consistency is somewhat thick and oily leaving residue on the sides of the glass. It is smooth and slides over the tongue but much of the flavor is lost. Most of the taste comes after you swallow when the faint flavor of the roasted barley hits the back of your throat. It isn’t harsh but lacks a fuller flavor that doesn’t linger in your mouth for very long. It was OK but I would have preferred a fuller flavor.

Many bottles all over St. Lucia. Brewed in St. Lucia. Certainly the best Guinness I’ve had, as I’d heard and expected. Dark pour, much bolder flavors than the usual Guinness I’m used to. Slightly sweeter in the finish, but stronger/bolder up front. Really enjoyable; wish it was easier to find in the states.

Bottle from The Beerhive. Black body with a medium beige head. Light lacing. Aroma of fig, pumpkin and treacle. Flavour of soy sauce, dark chocolate and tangy black cherry. Tastes quite boozy for 7.5% ABV. Medium body with an oily texture. Soft fizz. An interesting, well balanced beer - much better than the regular Guinness.
Black body with a brown head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted, caramel. Taste is bittersweet, caramel, chocolate, roasted, maybe some plums. Medium body with medium carbonation.

Déjà très peu habitué et amateur du style, c’est encore moins accessible qu’une Draught, toujours cette lourdeur et ces arômes grillés café, pas mon truc. Pour être franc, je ne l’ai pas finie. Bouteille achetée en grande surface en France, bue le 18/12/2013.

Bottle at Vieux Fort Airport, St Lucia. Brewer in St Lucia. Big roasty aroma, dark chocolate, tree bark, black licorice, burnt caramel, touch of coffee. Roasted malts, burnt flavors, licorice. Full mouthfeel. Decent
Mørk brun/svartb farve med beige skum. Lukt av røstet malt. kaffe og sjokolade. Smak av røstet malt. kaffe og sjokolade. Import.
330ml bottle. Very nice stout. Good level of bitterness to match the sweet chocolate malt flavours.

Dark nearly black with light tan head. Aroma is light roast coffee and ethanol. Roasty burnt-bitter flavor. Acetic bitter in the finish. Are these inconsistent? Did I get an "off" one? Perhaps if someone else is serving one of these I’ll try it again, but I’m not giving Diageo any more of my money. I remember it tasting better than this. Nice glass bottle, I’ll save that one for homebrews.

Bottle. Asda. Nearly black. Thick tan head. Dark fruit. Black treacle. Some woodiness. Light sour notes. Taste is metallic, tangy bitter, that lasts an age. Quite dry, too. Viscous palate. Finishes tart, dry, and very bitter.

Bottle, stable dense brown head, deep brown head with some red hues, aroma of dark chocolate with brown bread and cocoa, flavor of dark chocolate with some roasted notes, cocoa and chocolate cake, light pleasant bitterness, extremely smooth, medium bodied. Highly enjoyable stout.

Kindly shared by Jaghana.
Couleur noire, légère mousse beige. Nez malté toasté et fruité (mûres)!. Gout malté, grillé avec forte note fruitée, mûre voir vin rouge. Corps cremeux. Fin longue un peu grillée, fruitée, réglisse. 
Earlier Rating: 3/25/2014 Total Score: 3.3
Couleur noire, forte mousse brune cremeuse. Nez leger de malt grillé. Gout de malt, grillé, note de chocolat avec une bonne amertume longue. Peux de carbonation.

Bottle 65cl from Paris. A dark beer with copper head. Nose is intense on roasted notes, vinous with soy sauce touch. Aroma is on roasted notes, vinous with licorice touch, creamy, black current touch, roasted coffee, soy sauce. Finish is intense on roasted notes, dark coffee, still soy sauce notes.
Earlier Rating: 7/13/2009 Total Score: 3.7
Bottle 33cl. Very dark beer with a heavy head. This beer is too bitter, with a huge roasted aroma. Quite alcoolic too, it’s a bit roufh yes.
Bottle. Pour is with a head, aroma is caramel, malt, sweetness. Taste is malty, alcohol, toffee, bitterness, some sweetness, light bitter finish, body is medium, carbonation is soft. Good
I would say I prefer "classic" Guiness from Ireland, but this one is also good and reminds me the true one. Crafted is from far better though

Ottima Stout. Buona interpretazione, completamente nera con una testa al colore del cioccolato fondente. Si lascia bere, perché in bocca non è cremosa o densa e l’alcool è nascosto bene. La carbonatazione è lieve, e porta alla bocca orzo e liquirizia, qualche richiamo di vaniglia ad in finale secco e amaro, addimicato e tostato. Buona birra.

11.2oz. bottle from Cash Wise in Watford City. Appearance: 2 fingers dark brown head that lasts, dark brown-black color, great lacing, opaque. Aroma: roasted grain, chocolate, molasses, light grassy hops. Palate: medium-full body, soft carbonation, creamy and oily texture, bitter and dry finish, decent booziness. Taste: sweet malt, into boozy notes, then into a full bodied malt profile that turns roasted and slightly astringent, finishing with bitterness and light alcohol. Overall, palate is awesome, big tastes and aromas, very well balanced.

Bottle, black need with light cardboard colored head. Aroma is oats and yeast, faint raisin. Taste is dark roast, raisin, bittersweet chocolate, molasses, faint metal, black coffee, malt vineager, finish is faintly dry, but not strongly. Palate is smooth, not thin, good carbonation.
Poured from a bottle. Pours pitch black with a creamy tan head. Aroma and flavors of roasted coffee and chocolate. Probably my favorite Guinness they make.

650ml bottle served in a tulip.
A: Pours a deep black color forming a nice and huge beige head. Fizzing carbonation going up and some lacings left around the glass. Medium retention but the head never disappears completely
S: Good. Roasted malts. Coffee notes. Wood. Ginness hops. Alcohol
T: As the nose, roasted malts, coffee notes, wood notes, dark chocolate notes, earthy hops. A sweet upfront and a roasted bitter (considerable) aftertaste
M: Creamy body. Good carbonation. Sweet upfront. Molasses sensation. Aftertaste is dry and bitter
O: Absolutely drinkable. Great beer. Recommended
[ BA Review @ 6/23/2012 ]

Backlog rating on 11-21-2012 (Bottle) The appearance is a large frothy tan head that mostly diminishes, dark brown opaque body, very little carbonation observed, and a fair amount of lacing. The aroma is roasted malt, coffee, hint of hops, semi-sweet, dark fruits, and molasses. The flavor is molasses, roasted malt, bitter, hops, and a dry roasted finish. The mouthfeel is smooth and this beer is medium bodied. This beer is most quaffable and the ABV is well masked. I like how the flavors come together to make an enjoyable tasting beer.

330ml bottle from Asda - Opaque, pitch black body with a huge pale tan head and excellent lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and vanilla. Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla and slightly bitter dark fruit. Medium body and medium carbonation. I like this, but having said that, I do most stouts of this strength.

Rerate as the one below was the wrong one. 330ml bottle from an import shop in Xiamen. Pours black with an off white head. Aroma of roast malt and chocolate. Burnt chocolate toffee taste. Bitter finish.

330ml bottle from Tasty Life, Xiamen. This is the 6.8% version specially brewed in Ireland for the Chinese market. Pours black with a dissipating beige head. Roasted aroma of chocolate and toffee. Bitter sweet finish. Will be going back for more.

Edited for typo
33 cl från Guinnessbryggeriet. Delar denna med Linda. Svart färg. Doftar rostad malt, kaffe, choklad och rostat bröd. Smakar bränt bröd och lite mjölk.

"i’m not the type who thinks any form of Guinness is the be all end all of dark beer. quite the opposite usually. i think the average guiness i have rated is about a 3, with the best being a 3.4 (which is an "average" rating for me). that said, this one is hands down THE best Guiness I’ve ever had. More flavor, more hops, more balance. Just a good, high quality stout. Lots of roasted malt, chocolate in more abundance than usual, and a bitter hoppiness that a few friends thought was "off" but i enjoyed. my new favorite, easily. 2nd time - just as nice.
0,3l Flasche. Schwarzes Bier mit bräunlicher Schaumkrone. Angenehmer Duft nach Röstaromen. Schmeckt nach Röstaromen, Schokolade, Vanille undgeröstetem Getreide. Vollmunig und ausgewogen.
Tremendously rich flavor of coffee and roasted malt with some sour-sweet fruits intermingled. Long, deliciously bitter finish.

See:
Black, one finger tan head. No swirling carbonation like normal Guinness. 

Smell:
Dark fruit, fruit cake mix, dates, molasses/brown sugar. 

Taste:
Sweet molasses, rich fruit, hint of peppery spice. 

Pallet:
Rich, thick, well carbonated but not too lively. Longish bitter finish. 

Lovely, complex stout. Much richer, sharper and flavoursome than standard Guinness.
Bottle. Black with a tan head. Aroma is malty and chocolate. Flavour is similar, a little bitterness, but more gentle malt.

From a 330ml bottle (only 99p from B and M!)
I drank this chilled because its very refreshing like that on a hot day.
Nice rocky light brown head and all the taste that you’d expect from Guinness but sweeter. Be careful if you have a lot of these lying around. Its far too easy to drink.
Pitch black color, creamy head...strong aromas of roasted malt and some balanced hops. Mouthful, creamy, a bit bland but an overall pleasant beer.
Jet black, with nice capuccino-coloured head/ Strong aroma of roasted malts, a bit spoiled by the alcohol. Subtle chocolate in flavour.

33cl bottle on 20-Jun-2021 enjoyed in a shaker. Dark brown with a small beige coloured head.  Aroma of malt, chocolate and coffee. Taste of roasted malt, barley, raisins, coffee and caramel. Bitter, nutty but with some acidity.
Bottle. Thick ebony color liquid. Capuccino color head. Full body, light carbonation. Roasty taste. Medium to high bitterness. Creamy and full. Coffee aroma and taste. Very good one.

Immediate chocolate notes with alcohol which pours dark as expected.

Definitely more bite than regular Guinness varietals. definitely a bit more sharp in the hops and definitely more expensive than Regular guiness 

Rich and satisfying but the chocolate notes seems to have a tad raw element possibly artificial.

Better than Guiness varietals that have come along, good but nothing to rave about. Would love to try the real deal in Dublin one day as part of my bucket list of beers

Dark as hell, medium sized tan head. Chocolate, coffee, roasted malts and some cocoa. Slightly sweet. Thin body, soft carbonation. Better than regular Guinness. 

(Dobro Pivo Pri Ščurku 0,33l bottle)

Very dark brown color, almost black, average sized brownish head. Some lacing. Medium to full body, soft carbonation. Aroma of coffee, roast and malts. Medium sweet, light bitter taste. After mediocre Guinness Extra Stout and Guinness Draught, this is really a nice surprise.

Another one that I’ve forgot to rate. Pours a deep black color, topped with a frothy tan head. Pleasant roasty aroma with some caramel in the back as well. The taste is slightly sweet in the beginning, creamy, followed by some roasty notes and decent bitterness. There’s some caramel as well. Nice aftertaste, lasting. Great.

11.2 oz. bottle, consumed on 8-14-14. Weak aroma features scents of chocolate, Tootsie Roll, toffee, artificial chocolate, Playdough, and chocolate-covered pretzel. Pours a nearly black dark brown with a moderate amount of taupe head. Produces extensive, long-lasting, good lacing. Dry flavor dominated by roasted malts. Flavors of banana bread, tar, and caramel. Drier and more bitter in taste than the aroma suggests, but, upon multiple sips, it does sweeten to taste like that artificial chocolate that is present in the aroma. Typically English/Irish yeast strain evident in the flavor. Medium body. Smooth and lively in the palate. Overall, Guinness Foreign Extra Stout is reasonably enjoyable but too simple. Also, that cheap, artificial chocolate element in the aroma and flavor pulls it down. It definitely is a lot better than the more commonly consumed varieties of Guinness.
Hopfig malziger Beginn mit süßlichen Beinoten. Vollmundig malzig, wenig schokoladig. Gelungen! 11/9/10/10/9/11

Purchased in a 33cl bottle and at 7.5%ABV. This is the version brewed in Dublin. The colour is black with a big tan head. Lots of roasted malts and a little caramel in the nose. The flavour is full and smooth with roasted malts dominating with hints of coffee. Slight metallic hints. The initial sweet caramel flavours fade fast leaving a long and pleasing bitterness. A brilliantly-made beer that does not have the complexity of some craft beer imperial stouts but is nonetheless a deeply satisfying drink.

(bottle - 330 ml) Dark brown pour with a tan head. Roasty and slightly fruity aroma. Lots of malts and a bit of mocha under it all. Definitely get some raisin notes. Flavor is roasted chocolate and dark fruits with a slightly sweet and creamy finish with a bitter aftertaste.

Transfer from BA review on 10-14-12-
 Poured from bottle into pint glass

 Appearance – Pours a deep-deep brown nearly black color with a thick tan head. The head has fantastic retention, very slowly fading over time to give a great level of lacing.

 Smell – The smell is of sweet dark fruits and bitter roasted malt. There are other notes of a caramel sweetness as well as some aromas of dark chocolate.

 Taste – The taste begins with roasted malt and some caramel and dark fruit flavor. The sweeter flavors lose some ground in the taste while the roasted flavors grow more and more bitter. Some light coffee flavor enters the profile with a bitter herbal hop flavor. This creates a quite roasted off bitter flavor at the end of the taste; a rather off aftertaste of these flavors lingers on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the average to just above average side in terms of its creaminess and has a carbonation level that is on the average side as well. The average carbonation is good at hiding some of the non favorable flavors at the end of the profile, but not great for the roastier flavors of the foretaste; which the body does a nice job of enhancing.

 Overall – The taste and feel start out great, but that off bitter-herbal-roasted flavor that is left on the tongue really bring the brew down.

Backlog, Aruba 2006, bottle from supermarket. Pitch black color, thin foamy tan head, good lacing; aroma roasted malts, coffee, cardboard, licorice; taste moderate bittersweet, roasty; medium body, oily texture; more bitterness in aftertaste, coffee notes.

Black with a foamy yellow-brown head. Sweet stout, a bit of raisin and light roast. Very light malt aroma, with some molasses. This is nice, and despite being stronger easier drinking that normal Guinness.

Bottle @ Lake Victoria Hotel, Entebbe.
Actually I kinda like it. Nice dark and roasty, full head, pretty dry and bitter. Your best choice on the road in Africa!

Had a few bottles of this in Belize. Assume it was 355ml (12oz). Didn’t pour it but it looked the usual Guinness colour which is a colour in itself. Perhaps a little more treacly than usual? Anyway, aroma and taste were both good. Aroma was of coffee, strong malts and molasses. Again, a bit of coffee in the taste. Quite bitter. Reasonably thick mouth feel. Not bad.

Bottle in Shanghai, China. Pours black with a tan head. Mouthfeel was not as creamy as the standard Guinness. Roasted malt, coffee notes. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A tall tan head sits on top of a thick pouring and very dark black body with deep garnet highlights. The head hangs on well and maintains a small covering on top of the beer as I drink. The glass holds on to some nice lacing as well. The aroma has dark roasted and toasted malt notes. Within this I get a hint of coffee, some sweetness a touch of something fruity and a very slight boozy note. Its aroma comes alive here on the tongue. The dark roasted malt brings a full bodied hit of toasted barley notes with sweet touches of toffee that play well off the slight sweet boozy notes. Holding the sweetness in check are some dark roasted coffee notes and mild hop bitterness. The palate has a creamy, slightly slick and full mouth feel and soft carbonation.

dark black coloured with almost no foam; roasted malts, nougat, licorice and dark chocolate aroma; medium-bodied and slightly oily palate; sour and bitter, long dry bitter and roasty finish with notes of herbs and licorice - an excellent version of this beer
Earlier Rating: 3/18/2002 Total Score: 3.7
very dark colour, giant creamy head, deep coffee and black chocolate aroma, roasted, full-bodied, oily, sweet, alcohol presence followed by a long and quite rough bitter finish
Muy buena cerveza,fuerte,se siente bien pura al paladar y los granos tostados.bien oscura
Bottle. Pours pitch black with a creamy tan head that left sticky lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate. Rich flavor of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, molasses and had a dry finish
Good flavor on this brew. Aroma is sweet and the color is a pitch black with a nice brown head.

Aroma: toasted malts, coffee, light chocolate. Appearance: dark brown/black, medium beige creamy head. Taste: medium bitter. Palate: initial sweets remain, toasted notes, coffee, chocolate, very malty but then turns very bitter in the average-long finish. Overall: fantastic Foreign Stout, excellent palate, lovely transition from sweet to bitter. Bottle from Sainsbury’s, Pimlico.

Clear dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of malt, chocolate and bitter.
Earlier Rating: 4/20/2013 Total Score: 2.7
Black beer with a creamy tanned head. Coffee, chocolate, vanilla and a bit tarnotes aroma. Coffee, vanilla flavour with some tarish notes.

65?cl bottle shared@kevnic2008’s exotic Kurstadt tasting 12/07/2014. Very much like the continental EU Foreign extra stout, near-unctuous yet dry, with that fresh blend of sharp charred malts, confident earthy bitterness and only mild sweetness of cough drops for balance. Hard to pinpoint the ghostily present exotic element here, only it reminds me of brown soap...
Slightly sourish-fresh, smooth and easy to drink,. Malty, fresh. Dry with a slight malty bitterness. Nice! 12/12/11/12
Chocolate aroma. Black colour with poor head. Coffee flavor with long bitter aftertaste. Thick creamy body with low carbonation.
Sehr dunkelbraunes Bier mit ordentlicher beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, Karamell, süß. Geschmack süß, kräftig malzig, Malzbonbons, leicht bitter.
7.5% 330ml bottle. Very dark brown/black with rich dark head. Strong hoppy flavour, some sweetness, some toasted barley going on. Great stout!

Excellent Irish stout, subtle aroma with hints of chocolate and coffee, full stout flavour with coffee being most prominent note, palate is lighter than expected but excellent mouthfeel. Looks fantastic in a tulip glass. Love this Stout

Aroma: caramel, chocolate, coffee, roasty, 
Appearance: Deep opaque black. Towering tan foamy head.
Taste: light sweetness, medium bitterness, salty, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, sticky, average carbonation, bitter, long finish, 
Overall: This was pretty nice. Sort of like a tamed down russian imperial. Lots of roasted malts, coffee, raisin, plum. Much more going on than traditional guinness stout. Poured from bottle.

Intenzív, pörkölt aroma lengi körül e mélyfekete színű főzetet, melynek ízében felfedezhetők a Guinness Draught-tal való rokonság szálai azzal a cseppet sem kárára váló eltéréssel, amit a komló rendkívül határozottan érvényesülő karaktere, az alkohol nagyobb százalékban megtalálható jelenléte és némi tejes, édeskés zamat okozta különbség nyújt. Azoknak, akik a Guinnessben nem találták meg számításaikat, mindenképpen érdemes kipróbálniuk.

Poured from 330 ml bottle. 

Opaque, pitch black with a huge pale tan head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and vanilla.

Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla and slightly bitter dark fruit. 

Medium body and medium carbonation. 

I enjoy the low ABV versions of Guinness, but this version is so much richer. This is like the Guinness I remember from the days when it was first imported into the U.S. and only available at the Dubliner in Washington, DC. That may be attributable to nostalgia, a faulty memory or both. :-)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

33 click bottle. Pours a dark brown with a tan head that lasts. Aroma of chocolate and alcohol. Taste of sweet syrup and bitter hops. Palate is smooth with a oily texture. Overall good strong stout, but even better in Ireland.
Bottle at home, Oulu. Originally rated 17052012. Colour is almost black with small head. Aromas and flavours: Grain, chocolate, some coffee and roasted malts.

Sou suspeito para falar, pois nao e meu estilo favorito de cerveja. Cerveja preta ( cevada torrada e lúpulo forte) com media formação de espuma, essa de coloração creme, levemente adocicada com o final forte. Baixa carbonatacao, aroma suave mas intenso devido a cevada torrada. guinness, sempre guinness.

Pitch black color. Chocolate and coffee present on the aroma. Classic Guinness taste, with roast profiles, traces of coffee, chocolate, with a dry trendency. The mouthfeel is quite creamy and silky. Bitter ending.

St. Barth Beer No. 11. Wish I had a grabbed a few to bring back. A more intense version of the standard Guinness with more chocolate notes and a bigger bitter bite to finish. Bottle - St. Barthelemy, FWI

330 ml bottle. Pours black with a creamy, beige, long lasting head. Sweet aroma with notes of roasted malt, chocolate and vanilla. A rich, sweet flavor with bitter finish. Oily texture, soft carbonation. Nice.

Black bodied. Simple perhaps but a nice dark sweetness to this. Thicker than expected. Brown sugar, bit simple again but it’s appealing to me somehow. Drinks easily, short aftertaste. Not bad at all! (33cl bottle from an Asian food store in Tours)
caramel, cereal, toast, roasty, coffee, smoke, black, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness,

poured from a chilled 11.2 ounce bottle into a 12 ounce english pint shaped glass. oddly, reading the bottle’s back label, it states "malt liquor" to the right of "product of ireland". it also says "enjoyed by millons around the world".
what TF ever, man, this is super tasty so make that millons plus 1.

330 ml bottle. Smoky and roasted aroma. Has a milk chocolate like reducing head which doesn’t hang in there (unlike the standard Guinness). The liquid has a black tar like appearance. The taste is very bitter, malty, dark fruit and dark chocolate like leaving a slight burning sensation at the back of your throat after the swallow. It is also very full bodied and chewy. Overall an excellent foreign stout that would go great with beef stews or heavy puddings.
Bottle, pours black with a beige head, slight bitter coffee taste, dry finish, a nice stout

11.2 ounce bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a near black with a velvety head of khaki colored foam. Good retention. The aroma is fairly muted. I get some faint dark chocolate notes, but I’m really struggling to get much character from the aroma. The taste has some fruity notes along with some roast and char character. There just really isn’t much going on with this beer, unfortunately. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Moderate carbonation.

330 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 8/29/2012. Pours pitch black color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense tan head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, toast, dark bread, molasses, light char, raisin, plum, herbal, floral, and herbal/roasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good complexity of dark/roasted malt and moderate earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, toast, dark bread, molasses, light char, raisin, herbal, floral, light pine, and herbal/roasted earthiness. Fair amount of earthy herbal/roast bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, toast, dark bread, molasses, herbal, floral, light pine, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice flavor balance and complexity of dark/roasted malt and earthy hops; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a creamy, smooth, and lightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent foreign stout. All around great complexity, balance, and robustness of dark/roast malt and earthy hops flavors; and very smooth to sip on. A very enjoyable offering.

Flaska på Barbados. Svart med moccafärgat skum. Rostade toner i doften tillsammans med choklad och kaffe. Sältan i smaken är delikat, därtill kaffe, choklad, röda bär och torkad frukt. Mjuk och rund munkänsla.
toast, black, hazy, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, creamy, oily feel, lively,

Bottle - Trinidad version brewed by Carib and drank, lots of them, by the pool! Poured a black color with brown edges and an off white head. Roast, chocolate, some brown sugar sweetness, dark fruits, and a lighter coffee finish ... extra points for drinking by the pool in 90+ degree weather in March.

Roasted coffee notes with a bitter finish. Sort of like Extra's big brother. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle from Steve consumed St Patricks day 2014
Pours dark black as night with a giant frothy chocolate head it looks like a beer float 
The aroma is awesome strong spicy malt chocolate and coffee
Wow nice and smooth lots of taste in between a stout and an imperial stout
Steve was right this is fantastic 
And why can we not get this in Canada?

Pours a dark brown with a thin foamy head. It doesn’t stay for long, and there’s little lacing on the glass. Smells of chocolate, malt and bread. Big taste of coffee, chocolate, dark fruit and licorice. A bit of bitterness. Medium mouth with some oil. Just a nice solid stout.
C’est vraiment autre chose que les cannettes en fer sont goût caféinée est excellent un bonne brunes

Not sessionable like the dry stout, but quite a lovely beer. There is some nice honey, molasses and caramel along with the coffee and chocolate you expect in a stout. I’m surprised I don’t have a rating for this one already.

Pours completely black, with a big brown head which very slowly disappears. Aroma of alcohol, coffee, cocoa, caramel and smokiness with some spicy and orange notes. Tastes of coffee, followed by roasted malt and a strong bitterness. Medium smokiness and hints of paprika.
I find a lot of strong stouts overpowered by taste of alcohol, this is, however, incredibly nice.

Bottle: Deep, thick, & black, almost like used motor oil with only a hint of deep ruby shining through the very edges, topped with a creamy tan head that recedes over the course of a few minutes. Aroma has toasted malts & barley, very faint toffee sweetness, & a little bit of red wine. Taste has a bigger combo of roasted malt & dark fruit; prunes, raisins, & some bitter roast. Light caramel & toffee flavors in the finish along with a slight floral bitterness from the hops. Surprisingly dry finish. Decent, easily accessible beer from Guinness, though I still prefer the weaker Draught for its drinkability.

There is a reason this beer remains one of the most recognizable in the world...and one that can be found more places in the world than any other beer I know. In Asia, where light lagers rule, this is the one other style that is available. The one I’m drinking now came from a 7/11 in Bankgok...the only non-light lager on the shelf. Just sayin...
Pours tar black with a soapy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee. Roasted malt flavor with dark chocolate, dark fruit, coffee, and hint of Belgian sugar. Very nice beer.

She pours a pure dark black color and leaves the same colored body with a two and a half finger tan foamy head. The head must have lasted at least a good three minutes. What a show I had just watching the intricate bubbles pop out from the sides of the glass into the head while a light foamy lacing appeared as the head dissipated.
The smell has a great combination between the chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and barley.
The taste has all of the previously mentioned smells in the flavoring combined very nicely. 
On the palate, she sits a medium on the body with a slight watery feel. It still felt pretty good on the tongue.
Overall, I’m pretty much blown away because I didn’t think this was going to be this good.

Bottle from Asda Queensferry. Pours completely black with a thick tan head. Strong malty chocolate aromas which carry on over to the taste. Also picked up a hint of demarra sugar in the taste too. Soft carbonation and oily mouthfeel which goes down nicely. Horrendously overlooked as the best beer Guinness produce, very nice.
Bottle: Poured a black with tan colored head. Sweet strong caramel malt aroma. Nice roasted malt, caramel and molasses hints.
Dark pour with good head. Malty, chocolate with a mild sour aroma. Similar to aroma. Good beer

Almost black with an aroma of roasted coffee. Palate is bitter-sweet as is to be expected at this gravity. A fantastic beer and the best offering from a mega-brewer to cross my lips. An absolute life-saver in the Caribbean.
330ml bottle from supermarket. Dark brown almost black, with a thin tan head. Aromas of roasted coffee and malt. Big on those flavours too. Full bodied, long bitter finish. Very nice.

Bottle poured a deep dark brown hue w/ a large frothy tan head and sticky lacing. Big bold malty molasses aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish of short duration. Tastes are molasses, brown sugar, roasted malt, and licorice. Big bodied, soft carbonation, balanced mouthfeel, and a warm roasted finish.

Can’t dock this classic 7.5% alcohol Extra Stout for it’s uniqueness, legendary time & place for consumption. Only problem is haven’t been able to find it since the Christmas 2012 St. James Gate, Dublin brewed 11.2 oz. bottle combo 12 pack. Prior to that it was readily available. Still have a dozen [just cracked one - with KerryGold Dubliner cheese - for this review] in the canning cellar.

It’s the absolute most discrete, refined, delicate, character Guinness Stout. Makes the Canadian brewed for USA market Extra Stout seem like cat pee.

Well worth keeping the antennae up for it’s re-emergence. But with the Christmas canned combo 12 pack not containing it (instead funk & wagnels newbees) it may have fallen victim to Left-protofascist European Union export controls. It’s almost worth weeping over. Join Eurosceptic UKIP ;-)

For some reason I had never tried Foreign Extra until this evening. I was expecting it to be sweeter however I was pleasantly surprised by how much the taste reminds me of draught Guinness but with a much heavier body and a more noticable roasted bitterness. A lovely stout!

Expecting something lactic and vanilla smelling, got dark fruit and especially toffee. Looks like the regular bottled Guinness, only thinner. Bitter relative to dry stouts but predominantly baked doughy malt. Thick and gooey body. A real confection that inspired a beer genre.

Bottle from Sainsbury’s, not sure why I haven’t had this one yet. Aroma is earthy mineral, dry roast, some alcohol and caramel. Opaque black like priests’ socks with a big greyish tan head. Flavour is big woody, rum, bozzy, roast barley and berries. Fullish boozy plate with some medium carbonation. Finish is lingering roast and sweet berries.

330ml bottle shared with jeevan. Dark brown, near black pour, thin tan head. Big roasted aromas... coffee and malt. Some dark sugar. Taste has roasted bitterness. Full bodied, long bitter finish. Pretty good.

Appearance- very dark, almost black, light brown tinges at the base. A thick, beige, rocky head which hangs around. Aroma- dry roast, milk chocolate, cappuccino, dark malts. Taste- dark roasty malt, espresso, chocolate, very bitter dry finish, hints of sweet dark fruit and liquorice. Slightly chewy mouthfeel, a bit of booze is detectable. Good stuff.

Pours a deep dark color with a medium tan head. Nose is dark fruits. Aromas are roasted malts, coffee and caramel. Long and bitter finish. Rather drink the draught (lighter and more easy-drinkable) version.

Good looking 0,33 l bottle. Pours black and oily in the glass. Creamy light brown head. Dark berriefruits and toffee on the nose. Starts first with this fruity elements, shortly followed by dark creamy chocolade. Tastes only light alcoholic. Smooth dark malty, fruity sweetness. Yes!
Smells and tastes like whiskey. Not like the guiness I'm used to. Heavy beer to get down probably from the off taste. Didn't enjoy this. Had from draft at Los Amigos in Jaco Costa Rica

Bottle date: unk

One in a three part Guinness-off

A: Pours a dark, nearly black-brown ale with a three finger head of mocha color and loose meringue quality. This falls to a thick quilt of the same leaving spotty lacing.

S: Vanilla, clove, sweet and dark malts, maple, brown sugar, hints of cinnamon and butter. This has the best nose of the three IMO. Complex and nearly like a Dubbel.

T: Roasty, toasty and leaps and bounds ahead of the other two offerings from Guinness. This beer is yummy. Caramel, toasted bread, hints of bitter hops, nicely integrated hazelnut flavors. Finish is long and strong with the flavors. 

M: Medium body with low carb. Dry finish. Nothing special here.

O: By far my favorite of the Guinness offerings here in the states. I dig it. Well balanced, great nose and flavor.

Serving type: bottle

07-08-2011
Great stout. Aroma is coffee and roasty malt. Taste is very dry and balanced.
Better than their extra stout, this has a little more depth to it with a rich coffee taste that doesn’t have a lot of bitterness to it.

Bottle, black with a fine thin beige head, light red fruit tartness and coffee on the nose, umami dryness, burnt-bitter, hints of gravy and plum, some roast coffee and a sourish almost acrid bitter finish.

Good mix of hops and barley very easy to drink.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A black beer with a tan head. Very thick and creamy body, like a complete meal. Some coffee, dough and malts in the aroma and flavour. A bit bitter taste, but a very nice beer.
Finally had this brew in bottle at wob cap hill. Big malt up front. Way more than reg guinness. Still full bodied and smooth, but with a slight skunk taste which I’m not crazy about.
coffee, toast, black, cloudy, frothy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, full body, thick feel, lively,

330 ml bottle from Shinanoya @ Shibuya. Pours dark brown with a nice brownish head - and that head stays. Aroma is completely unbelievable - sweet dried dark fruits, roasted bread, melon. Love it! You get the same flavours also in taste - plus many more. There is some burnt bread, dried fig fruit - ending up in a long, bitter and dry aftertaste. I like this on much more than usual Guinness, too bad this one is not so easy to find! Will definitely drink it again!
good. thick body, lightly sweet on the finish and mid-palate. classic flavors, creamy and tasty.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown beer with a medium sized, beige head on top that leaves fairly quick and leaves little lacing. Aroma is light coffee, chocolate and molasses. Flavour is bitter with chocolate notes and has decent carbo going on. Flavour lasts long and bitter. Thick, creamy and oily mouthfeel. Quite ok.
Can from Bohemia shared thanks to hornydevil. Pours dark with a tan head. Big roasty aroma. Tastes like ash. A bit too roasty for me.

Appearance: Black with 3 finger thick tight tan head.
Aroma: Toast, grassy/hay, caramel/toffee.
Taste: Low sweetness and sourness, high bitterness.
Palate: Thick smooth texture, light/medium body, low carbonation, very astringent and very bitter lingering finish with tobacco like taste.
Comments: Tasty and nice glass lace. But extremely bitter finish.
This poured a darker brown with a beige head. aroma was of over roasted and burnt malt withnot much else. Flavor was of feet, and very bitter over burnt black patent. Hard to chocke down.

this brew has body, dimension and taste so it’s gotta be at least a 4. flavor of bubblegum like a guinness but with a roasted chestnut bite and bitters like a citrus but not citrusy. tastes dark indeed with just the right highlight of smoke. fuller body that is creamy and makes you want to chew it. the good stuff!

Pours black, tan foam one finger head. Aroma is milky coffee, dark chocolate with alcohol kick. Any sweetness is overpowered by astringent bitterness. So much so to make it unbalanced. Very mild coffee notes, more burnt malts. ABV is not well masked. Nice carbonation for a Guinness but overall disappointing

This is my favourite beer at the moment. The aroma, taste, basically everything about it is awesome. Lovely coffee overtones with a slight hint of chocolate and a lovely slight bitter finish makes this an awesome stout

I thought this beer was similar to another Guinness (Draugh) but some features change like for example its bitterness. It’s similar to coffee but less intense. It has almost the same aroma, resin and chocolate and its body is creamy with its particular black color.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Created a monstrous sizing of creamy foamed head while the stout was a pitch black color. Aroma is strongly influenced by roast malt with a background of heavy whipping cream. The flavor is rich with a deep roast malt profile that tastes like the regular Guinness except on steroids because much more alcohol is detected. This is much easier to drink than the regular extra stout but then again this isn’t a good session ale like the regular Guinness. Glad they only sell this in a 4-pack because I felt like a goner after drinking my 4th.

Old rating, 0,33l bottle from Citti Markt Flensburg @ home:

Fyldig sødmerik lukt med preg av mørk malt, humle, sjokolade, kaffi, vanilje. Fyldig sødmerik smak med preg av mørk malt, humle, sjokolade, kaffi, litt karamell, gras og vanilje. Middels bitterhet som set litt. Grei.
Pours black with a tan head. Lots of espresso notes in the flavour - full bodied mouth feel.
Bottle from B&M. Pours black with big tan head. Lovely rich coffee flavours with quite a crisp bitter finish. Nice balance between the malt and hop flavours. Very tasty.

Bottle at home 
Pours the blackest brown , good grey foam 

Smell is sweet , coffee
soft carbo . Cold coffee , but less bad than the draft version . This has a decent amount of taste , yet still feels light . Ok i guess . But ill never be a guiness fan ..

Opaque. Thick head with good retention. Nice lacing. Not much aroma. A little bit of coffee. Coffee and chocolate undertones in the flavor. A little subtler than the more famous Guinness stout. Smooth, creamy on the palette. Very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black with beige head. Roasted malt flavour, burnt and coffee. At taste is smooth with roasted and coffee favour.

The most amazing Irish stout beer that I tasted, and one of the greatest to me, also the first stout tasted. Anyway, this beer have a very nice aroma, including chocolate, coffee and caramel. The appereance is black, very black in deed, a clear, but with a little hazy/cloudy semblance, the head is very large, frothy and creamy, being this, maybe the great atractive of this beer. It have lower sweetness and a lightly sour touch for the taste, being a good combination to keep and producing a great sensation in the mouth. 

Full bodied, with a thick/creamy texture and very fizzy, with a bitter and and a little astringent finish, giving a cool sensation after the drop. Very drinkable and great for a cold winter afternoon or a rainy day in the summer. 

Oysters and Guinness is a combination of world-class!
Pours black with a creamy tan head. Roasted malt, hops, licorice, chocolate. Smooth, creamy, sweet and bitter.

Bomber. Pours jet black with a mocha colored head. The aroma is huge roasted malts, bitter coffee, earthy hops, and some chocolate. The flavor is somewhat bitter and astringent. Coffee and roasted malts steal the show, but lingering chocolate in the finish. Nice brew and easy to drink

draft from guinness factory, dublin. pours black with tan head. aroma of coffee, hay, leaves. tastes of chocolate, coffee, cherries, bread, hay. elegant roast. palate is full, silky, and chewy. best guinness and stout i’ve had.
Full flavoured and full bodied. Just the right amount of bitterness poking through the roasty malty body. Well done.

Bottle in Mexico. You know we all always complain about big companies and their capacity of making great beers. Well this is the exception to the rule. Great roasted hops aroma. Very good looking, thick and solid in mouth. Nice smoked taste and palate even if there is a léger alcoholic kick back there. Some standard chocolate and coffee notes also. For winter yes, but good for all seasons.

creamy yet roasty somewhat acrid aroma -- not unpleasant, just assertive. some bread-like notes. color is black, with a thick, rocky tan head. bitter roast flavor. dark roasted coffee flavor. fairly heavy on the tongue. bitter and rich. bitter finish. bitter aftertaste. not easy to perceive anything beyond the roast and bitterness. a very special brew.

BOTTLE 33CL Irish.

Head: coffee, big, frothy, avg. retention. Colour: virtually black.

Aroma: fairy rich, roasty, slightly smoky/peaty, coffee, malty, some alcohol, sweet, licorice, vanilla.

Taste: pretty dry, even slightly salty, raosted with a decent bitterness.

Delicious, dry and roasted stout with and intense aroma and taste.
Black with a small head. Full-bodied and heavy in the palate. Has a light aroma.

0.33l bottle. Pitch black body, light brown head. Aroma of milk chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Taste of chocolate, coffee, cream, reisin and some vanilla. Medium-full body, very nice creamy texture. The finish has a nice hop bitterness.
Alcohol is too noticeable and body could be thicker to me. Smooth, yes, but a bit lacking in chocolatey and/or coffee (typical stout flavor) for me. Not as good as the regular Guinness Draught.

DATE TASTED: August 1, 2013 ... GLASSWARE: Guinness pint... OCCASION: watching scrapbooking with Shan--sweet memories... APPEARANCE: velvet black body, dense and appreciable; thick brown head that laces beautifully, as a doily,, almost symmetrically around the glass--a full three fingers... AROMA: nice lactic impact; hops are less profiled--oat, peat and sugars are prominent... earthiness is present... coffee, chocolate and robust roasted beans... PALATE: high and hard, warming and medium-bodied; full at the throat...meanwhile, a brilliant lacing, symmetrical and ornate, covers the glass in its entirety... TASTE: slightly chocolaty and pleasantly milky; unlike the draught, a hardened smoky finish that demands attention; hops are well-placed, coupling with the malts to present a substantial, complex stout... OVERALL: the less-requested Guinness again reminds me why the road less traveled in beer circles often makes the more rewarding difference...this beer delivers with a welcome heft and an ABV that belies its enjoyable sip. A shame this beer does not accompany the "three beers strong" mix pack--trade the Harp for this? In a heartbeat...

1/08/2011: Guinness Foreign Extra Stout... Aroma: Smokey; roasty malt; just a hint of butter. Appearance: Very dark; average dull tan-colored head. Flavor: Roasty, slightly meaty smokiness; tinge of alcohol poking through; herbal bitterness in the finish. Palate: Medium-bodied; smooth. Overall: Wow, this beer was nothing like I expected and is really pretty good, if not great; I look forward to having another one soon!



11.2 fl. oz. bottle (Best before L0244GF001 08:19; 7.5% alc/vol.) enjoyed at Peaches in Yellow Springs, Ohio. Rating #1000 for this beer.
Pours a thin black with off white head. Aromas of lactose and chocolate. Some nice bubblegum too. Chocolate and milky flavours. Coffee finish. Good stuff

Thanks Cards04 for sharing this, even though I brought it from Ireland to share with you. Well, anyway, have you ever read James Joyce’s Ulysses? Neat book. Long, though. This beer is dark black with off-white head, but hell, what stout isn’t? Sweeter, a bit hoppier, and more flavourful than regular Guinness. Nice, but not world-changing, just town-changing, I’d say.
This is the best offering from Guinness, similar to the regular Extra Stout, roasted malts, coffee, fuller body, perhaps a little sweetness in the finish.
Bottle. Black body, creamy head. Smoky and coffee aroma. Smoke in the aroma, coffee also, full. Nice bitter aroma. Good.

Une bouteille de 330ml meilleure avant le 26/01/14. Une superbe robe noire avec une mousse beige collante. Un nez fort invitant de malt grillé, de rôti, de chocolat. C’est riche et agréable. La bouche est agréable avec ses notes de mélasse, de malt rôti, de malt grillé, c’est très rôti. La texture est riche. (Bue à Paris).

Bottle at Fado. Billed as a "Product of Ireland" so presumably a proper St.James? Gate brew. Dark pour but without the cascade. Lots of lace. Noticeably higher ABV. Bit more dark syrupy caramel. More liquorice too. Otherwise, what I would call, a proper Guinness. Bizarre that after the millions of Guinness drafts I?ve had, I somehow missed this. Definitely a bigger mouthful. Good stuff,  but ultimately feels like a a syrupy Guinness.

This is a great beer. It had been a while since I had it due to the availability of draft Guinness, and I love this beer. More roasted flavor with som additional hop flavor makes this a more complex, and rougher beer than the ordinary excellent Draft.
I did not really enjoy this. I prefer normal Guinness. This beer had a strong bitterness to it. I guess this style of stout beer is just not for me.

Bottle at Guinness storehouse, Dublin

Had this a number of times pre rating
Thick, dark ruby brown with fluffy tan head. Fairly sweet, full bodied, roast barley, burnt toast, umami richness, hops and chocolate in nose, smooth, low carbonation. Slips down far too easily. If only all Guinness was like this.

330ml bottle. Pours a black colour, with frothy foam beige head leaving some lacing and aroma of roasted malt & honey. Taste is sweet molasses, chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits with a lingering bitterness. Initial milky mouth feel, medium bodied, medium carbonation, dry roasted bitter finish. Quite OK.

Cannot get this; where I live we get Canadian Guinness. Having it in England and it is brewed in Ireland. Wonderful. One of the best stouts ever. The aroma in the glass the next morning is like waking up to an Elizabethan garden. I kid not. Amazing next morning aroma.

(Bottle): Pours deep black with a tan head. A sweet, chocolate and coffee aroma. A great balance of bitter and sweet in the taste, almost like a chocolate coated coffee bean. Has a malty, bready, licquorice finish and a long lasting bitterness on the tongue. Prefer this to the draught guinness.
Not particularly different from the special export at least that I can tell from memory.  Sweeter than I remember, though the sweetness is more molasses than chocolate.
Very malty aroma. Fantastic Black colour. Nice smooth bitterness. Great thick mouthfeel.

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours black with a beige head, aroma of chocolate, nuts, honey, caramel, some coffee, flavor of chocolate, malt, some coffee, medium bodied

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Black, opaque, beige head. Wine, a little roast, a little fruit, a little sugar and coffee aroma. Roasty, coffee, bitter taste. Full body, fizzy, roasty dry finish, less creamy than the usual Guinness.

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Dark brown to black with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate, licorice, dark fruits and light roastiness. Sweetish and slightly acidic flavor with some chocolate, light roastiness, a bit of fruity notes and a drier finish. Medium-bodied.

Black with foamy off white head and lots of lacing. Aroma is slightly sweet, molasses, citrus, rich fruit, fig. Taste is roasted chocolate, prune like deep fruit, some toasty malt, smoke and bitterness on the finish.

A - Black as night, 2 finger of dark mocha head that turns to a lighter color as it starts to slowly sink.

S - Roasted cocoa, molasses, a smoked turkey cold cut kind of aroma(good), earthy coffee grinds, brown bread, caramelized brown sugar.

T - Charred molasses, toasted brown sugar, roasted malt comes in strong toward the middle, sugary coffee coats the entire mouth, unknown peppery spice, has a sour fruit characteristic toward the finish. Finishes very dry for all the malty sweetness.

M - Full bodied, luscious feel, moderate creamy carbonation, alcohol is present but fits and plays well with all of it’s counterparts.

This is the Guinness that you dream of. A full and robust stout. Complex and extremely tasty.

Serving type: bottle

03-17-2011

Pretty good for Guinness licoriius flavor dark body thin fading head enjoyable though lots of body

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a black brew with a medium light brqon head with regular to poor retention, Aroma is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with dark fruits(mostly prunes), roasted malt, caramel and Vanilla, médium bodied, flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate to low bitter, bittersweet finish

Aroma of burnt, charcoaly malts and a little aniseed. Texture is a bit watery and the flavour does not come through so well. Overall the mouthfeel is quite rough and unrefined. The bitterness is prominent and the alcohol is also present. There’s a bittersweet, treacley background in there somewhere.

[Bottle from Riviera Restaurant, Selsey] Dark brown with a light brown head and a light fizz.  Fruity up front, then coffee, roasted malt and smoke develop,  A little dryness too.  The finish Is on the bitter, burnt side, but overall it’s a very decent stout, worlds away from the standard Guinness!

Bottle: &nbsp Deep brown, nearly black, moderate frothy beige head, fairly nice lacing. &nbsp Apple skin nose, roasted 

malts, slight ash and campfire. &nbsp Ash and campfire are more noticeable on the tongue. &nbsp Smooth, but not coating, 

roasted malt flavor. &nbsp Low hop, moderate malt base. &nbsp Fairly enjoyable. &nbsp Apple or Pear fruit skin flavor is 

fairly assertive, after the roastiness. &nbsp Semi-sweet lactose finish. &nbsp It reminds me of a milk stout for some reason. 

&nbsp Better than I anticipated.
33cl bottle.  Large tan head atop cola-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, roast, cocoa, light smoke.  Taste is moderately sweet, roast, cocoa, some smoke.  Smooth medium-full body.

Pour is a black with a large tan head.  Aroma is a nice roasted malt with a little smoke in there.  Flavor is again a nice roasted malt with some molasses and I get more smoke.  Finish is bitter but leaves a nice char on the tounge.  Way heavier than your regular Guinness but a excellent malt profile.

12oz bottle at Vintage.  Deep brown black body, big beige head, steady.  Sweet chocolate berry aroma.  Rich and full of flavor, but relatively smooth and clean on the palate.  Roasty aftertaste, bittersweet.  Probably the benchmark Caribbean Stout.  Excellent roasty chocolate and coffee notes, pungent dark fruit tones, merging excellently.  Really enjoyable, expertly executed.

Black and opaque with a full, rocky, tanned head. Smell of roasted malt, biscuit and coffee. taste: Sweetish, roasty coffee, hints of caramel and nuts. a little bitterness in the background. Full body and long lasting taste with a flat carbonization.

Appearance: Brown/Black with reddish brown head.
Aroma: Molasses, coffee and toffee.
Flavor: Molasses/burnt sugar, mocha with just a hint of licorice.
Plate: Full bodied, thick, rich and smooth.
Overall: Great Stout - defines the style.
Bottle at the Grove, Huddersfield March 2013. Rich dark chocolate, black pour, decent carb, moderate bitter with sweet malt notes through, nice

Has great taste. Drink all night long. Has a decent weight. Last all night long but doesn't fill you up.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is sweet and dry like a red wine. Like just like a red wine. Which is weird. 

Appearance is really nice. Sludge colored with a great cream head. 

Taste is very sweet and dry. It drinks a lot like a light bodied wine for better or worse. I don’t really care for it. 

Mouthfeel is pretty good. Dry. Smooth.

Overall I think this is just not the beer for me. It brings a lot to the table though and I think others would appreciate it.
Black with a persistent coffee colored foam ... Chocolate and coffee in the nose and a malty hoppy taste without any thick molasses creaminess ... Long refreshing finish

Bottle. Almost black color with medium beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, dried black fruits. Taste, roasted malt, milk chocolate, coffee, licorice, dried fruits, toffee, biter hops, alcohol. Bitter hoppy finish.

This is an entirely different ballgame. Pours opaque black coffee brown with a massive and sustained caramel-beige head - like stiff whipped cream. Nose is coffee, treacle, brown sugar. Flavors carry through - the slight sour note associated with Guinness -  near burnt toast finish. Chewy beer with a mouth coating viscosity. The nose and appearance are the notable features. The flavors is just fine just doesn’t add many layers to the experience. And the fact that this sheds a whole new light on Guinness
0,33L bottle. Sour smoky, too much alcohol on taste. Dirty , filth. Stranger Guinness. Sour mead with alcohol. Not so good.

drank from 11.2 fl oz brown glass bottle at Zane's house, potent aroma, strong color, smooth palette, barley notes complements the hop blend

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

11.2 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured Deep, Black with a beautiful frothy tan head and lots of lacing. Aroma of coffee and toasted malts combined with some dark fruits. Very well balanced taste tangy hops and malt sweetness, the ABV is noticeable. some chocolate notes. Very good beer, loving it.

11.2 ounce bottle from Ireland served in a snifter. As almost anyone reading this already knows, this is a near black brew with a towering, creamy, beige-hued head with very good retention and attractive lacing.

Smell: Sweet caramel and dark roasted barley nose with hops, mild alcohol esters and a hint of coffee.

Taste: Richer than I remember, this has a load of dark, roasted barley with a bit of dark fruit and toffee, a hint of coffee, and a touch of smokey molasses. Eventually, some earthy/herbal hops join in, making for a good sweet/bitter balance.

Mouthfeel: Medium+ body; medium-light carbonation; nicely soft and creamy 

O: Surprisingly satisfying and flavorful given the standard/common Guinness.

This pours jet black with little or no head. This is a sweeter version of the proper guinness. 

This doesnt have the creamy complex taste of the original Guinness.

This is a pale copy of the original.

Not recommend.

Bottle from winter variety pack into pint glass.  Dark black color with a finger of fluffy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt sweetness with some coffee, dark fruit, earth and chocolate notes.  Taste is a more intense take on the aroma with a pleasant hop balance.  Rich body, creamy with roasty finish.  Tastes like pushing Guinness to the next level.  My new go-to Guinness, good stuff.

Flat out tasty. Pours to piles of fluffy foam. Releases a grainy scent that suggests the hop addition to the standard malt. Mostly sweet taste. If they served this on tap at my favorite Irish pub, the regular Guinness would never be ordered again.

Unexpectedly good for a Guinness. This is a bit of a taste of history, recipe isn’t supposed to have changed much for a century+. Roasty, malty, but with some hops. Bitter chocolate/coffee flavors, but very smooth. If you gave me a glass of this I would not think that it was a giant macro, but something very crafty.

April 2012 - Bottle at room temp as 'Guinness Foreign Extra Stout'.  Strong, tangy, syrupy little bit ashy but not as much as the usual stuff.  OK overall. (6-4-7-3-15=3.5)


February 2018 - Saturday Tasting at Leighton's, Hackney.  Bottle as 'Guinness Extra Strong Stout XXX', 1977 vintage.  Apparently this is the beer that developed into their FES.  Pours opaque black, foamy brown head.  Aroma is quite fruity – apple.  Taste is spiced liquorice, cocoa, dried fruits.  Not bad considering.  Just interesting to try a 40 year old Guinness.  (5-4-5-3-13=3.0)

Aroma is the most disappointing thing about it, a little coffee, chocolate and roastiness in general, but faint. Spicier and thicker than the standard Guinness, which is a welcome change. Combined with the higher ABV, this has a nice strong presence, a Guinness for hardier drinkers.
Earthy aroma.  Pours dark with thick, lingering head.  A little fuller bodied than standard Guinness.  A little bit of bite to it.  Not bad, nothing to write home about.

Pours dark brown, with creamy thick tan head. Smells of roasted malt, coffee, yeast, and a slight sweetness. Tastes a little sweet on the front end with coffee and bitter on the back end. Creamy texture a full bodied on the tongue. The alcohol is well incorporated. Delicious beer, Guinness never fails.

3/16/13 7.5% LOOK: very dark brown with mocha head NOSE: a little funk at first, then strong burnt coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, chocolate malted milk shake, just a hint of sweetness TASTE: VERY dry and bitter dark chocolate, cocoa powder, chocolate milk, very dark bitter coffee, almost like I’m chewing coffee grounds, strong tangy bitter coffee finish that’s lasts awhile FEEL: dry and bitter OVERALL: pretty dang good!!! ...Room temp ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is the best beer Guinness makes to me. Pour is black with a huge tan head that is full of peaks and valleys and it sticks to the glass.aroma is sweet,malty and to yes hops.full flavored with a ton of butterscotch and caramel flavors.

Bottle. From a neighbor, so not sure how old the bottle is. Pours a nearly black with tannish cream head. Aroma is roaste malt chocolate. Taste is interesting mix of dark fruit, burnt chocolate bitter, but smooth in the finish. A nice stout.

Bought at Asda. Aroma is raisin, mild hops, roasted malts with a slightly commercial gassy smell. The taste is dark dried fruits, sweet cream, roasted malts, and it has a gentle chocolatey bitter finish. It is full bodied, has a thick & creamy mouthfeel, but also has good carbonation and a lasting thick foamy off white head. Much better than the regular Guinness and good for a supermarket beer. I can’t believe this has been under my nose all this time!

Bottle 0,33l 7,5 ABV. Pours dark brown to black body with creamy foamy long lacing mocha tone head.  Aroma is licorice, plums, roasted malts, leather. Palate is oily, sticky flat with flat carbonation and mouthfeel.  Taste is bitter, dry , roasty malty and has that bitterness of raw cacao beans among other flavors. High ABV brings some warmth and sweetness. Finish is medium long and bitter, little edgy on the end. Overall, this is slightly unbalanced but still more than drinkable stout with high ABV.
12oz bottle.  Extra stout, extra good.  Tasty roasty flavor with a big bitter punch!  Not really ll that similar to the normal draught.  Normal carbonation,  medium body.

330ml Bottle. Black with small dark head. Roasted barley and a little bit  hoppy nose. Nice malty bitterness. Its like a guinness with bigger balls. Fan of normal guinness but this one surprised me as a big commercial producer beer

Mini stout variety night. Bottle. Black beer with medium mocha head, decent lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and raisens. The taste is burnt malts, raisens again, bitter coffee and a little creamy dark chocolate. Medium bodied. Much better than the standard draught Guinness that is available in the UK and Ireland. I do prefer the Nigerian version though, which is excellent.

Bottle from Total Wine, Sacramento. Pours dark brown with a foamy tan head and a bready treacle aroma. There is a thick dark molasses flavor that has a dry roasty finish that clings to the palate. The extra hoppiness is quite noticeable and adds a refreshing layer to the dark malt.

The aroma is burnt coffee and chocolate with notes of roast malt and brown sugar. The beer is deep black with a small but thick tan head. Bitter with most of it coming from roasted malt characteristics. Sharp bitterness in a smooth mouthfeel.

Black beer with brown head sticking to the glass. Aromas of roasted malt, fruity of cherries, coffee. The taste is similar, but rich and creamy. Also bitterness of burnt, chocolate, fruit cake and nice vinous acidity. A reference beer.
Pours thick dark black..brown head.. Aroma of raisen...taste is not what i expected..very carbonated. ? Coffee nut.. Decent

Black with a thick tan head. Floral and spiced aroma. Subtle hops with a hint of cola flavor. Robust brew, much better than your standard Guinness 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma of spice and barley with the traditional dark black Guinness pour, a taste of floral notes and mild hops with a subtle mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From the bottle.  Dark black pour, a light tan creamy head.  Aroma is sweet with some fruitiness.  Taste is bitter chocolate and sweet frutiness.  A nice brew.
330ml Bottle. Pours Black with a small head. Aroma of roasted barley. Good amount of malt bitterness on the first sip. Stronger than the other Guinness Stout. Good for a change

11.2 oz brown bottle. Imported from Ireland. I’ve been looking for this beer for over 10 years. I finally found it in a little dump of an Indian market. I bought both 4 packs I saw. I stopped by for some spices & saw it in a back cooler.
Anyway, it poured out a dark inky black color, with a scant mocha colored head. Aromas are burnt malts, brown sugar, some hops. Flavors are amped up chocolate malts, cocoa nibs, bittersweet chocolate. Slight sweetness in the background. Tastes a lot like scorched coffee.
Thick mouthfeel, rich & chewy. Alcohol is well hidden. Tasty stout overall.
Too bad it took me 10 years to find it locally.

11.2 ounce bottle-  pours out a wicked black with a huge brown head that lasted the entire glass and left copious lacing throughout.  Aroma was caramel and malt.  Taste was brown sugar and toast with a slight boggy finish.  Palate was a little on the thin side.  Pretty good.

Bottle purchased in St. Kitts.
Label reads:  Brewed under license by Carib Brewery St. Kitts & Nevis ltd, Basseterre St. Kitts & Nevis. Product of St. Kitts & Nevis.
Pours black with a fleeting tan head.
Faint aroma of dark roast malts and heavy molasses.
The flavor is lightly sweet tempered by bitter roast malts.
Full bodied.
Slightly ramped up version of the regular Guinness to me.
Wine glass. Deep dark brown with a light brown pillow top head. A little lacing. Smells sweet and delicious. This beer is much sweeter than I had anticipated.
Wonderfully toasted dark malt with a warming high gravity taste. Alcohol undertones are not overpowering. A well rounded full flavored stout.

This brewer has been making this for centuries.  It would be unfair to rate it as anything less than perfect.  All other stouts should be compared to this especially if they have not been doing this for type for centuries.

It is my opinion that many of the people comparing the taste to  ’like’ something have never tasted molasses.  Not only is the color similar but the flavor.  

This is my 1st or second stout ever.  Actually the only other similar drink was a hispanic ’treat’ called Malt Hatuey.  Hatuey was an Indian hero in Central American lore I believe.  But in Malt Hatuey you get this dark color and malt/molasses flavor too.  

This stout makes me feel connected with the earth and all the best she produces.  The first sensation is carbonation, rather intense from a bottle, second is sweetness, then malt followed by hop bitterness.  Buried in these intensities is alcohol.  I was barely aware of alcohol in spite of the fact there is more alcohol in extra stout then a pilsner for example.

For me this is probably going to be a wintertime treat.  Summertime will be something lighter.  Keep up the good work Guiness and be the standard bearer.

My favorite beer from all I have ever drank.  I only like dark stout type beers and after being surprised at Christmas with this Guinness variety I fell in love from the first fabulous sip. Absolutely outstanding....Thanks Guinness.

Pours a very dark brown with a decent light brown head. Obvious stout smell here as well as roasted malts. Really hits the taste buds with a great mixture of bitterness and texture. Has a slightly salty taste that is blended with malts and other bold flavors. Definitely a beer to enjoy slowly.
Pours Black with an excellent thick rocky tan head.  Aroma of roasted barley.  Good amount of malt bitterness on the first sip.  Much better than the regular Guinness Stout.  Lingering dry finish.
i buy this often when not going to a dark american craft beer. perfect roast level and smooth
