Pours a clean black with a light brown head. Just the smell let’s you know its not like a regular stout. You can smell the hops with the caramel. The taste is very similar. Hops with chocolate and a nice toffee behind it. A medium bitterness on the after taste but definitely more then normal for a stout. For an IPA drinker this is possible a very likable stout.

From a 330ml bottle on 20/1/2013. Pours black with a medium beige head. Has a quite nice roasty, chocolate coffee aroma. The flavour features lots of sweet chocolate and treacle, a touch of caramel and coffee, and a slightly medicinal roasty bitter finish, featuring a touch of aniseed. The texture is quite creamy. Very enjoyable.

Sweeter and smoother in aroma than what you commonly see in the States, Foreign Extra is not as dry, with delicious roasted notes.  It’s even great served near room temperature.  In my opinion, incalculably better than Guinness Stout, so much so that you wouldn’t in a million years think these beers were brewed by the same outfit.  Sweet, smooth, full and delicious, with a little bitterness in the finish.  A great beer!

Dec 20, 2012. 330ml bottle pours jet black with 2 inch tan head. Not as exciting as nitrogen ball in can but looks like a Guinness. Aroma is nutty biscuit malts and barley with slight grassy note. Taste is similar to regular Guinness with the addition of licorice for a stronger bite and a longer bitter finish. Palate is watery which was better suited for the other guinness brews but wished this had more depth. Silky mouthfeel and dry finish. A tad more hops or dryness than original but I prefer regular Guinness in the can.
Average stout, nothing to write home about, but dark like a guiness but with more umphhhh

pours a dark brown with a large khaki head, and good lacing.

smell is of cocoa, malt, and a tad amount of coffee.

taste is of sour malt, a little cocoa, and hops.  ends on the bitter side.
Bouteille de 500ml, robe noire, arôme de café et de pain grillé, goût de moka plus amère que l’originale.

Jet black, fluffy tan head.  Dark roasted malt in the nose.  Sweet on the tongue.  Liquorice, cherries and dark chocolate in the middle with alcohol slowly starting to dry the sweetness.  Nice hop bitterness closes.  A benchmark brew.
330ml bottle. A much tastier version of this stout. More robust, more body, plenty of roasty and coffee aromas. Quite smooth, quaffable, long and sweet aftertaste.
Not quite as strong as i thought it might be...a good strength though...flavorful and tasty...smokey

This is the Guinness Foreign Extra brewed in Ireland.  The back of the label also reads malt liquor.  Pours a pitch black color with a nice 2 finger mocha colored head.  Decent amount of carbonation streaming up reinforcing the head.  The nose is huge molasses sweetness.  There is a large raisin smell as well.  Taste is more of the same.  Sweet, molasses, raisin, slight roasted flavor.  I paired this stout with a piece of chocolate cake which seemed to bring out a slight coffee bitter flavor.  I don’t believe this flavor is present without a chocolate pairing.  Beer finishes dry.  No hint of the 7.5% abv.
Pours incredibly dark with little head and lacing to match.  Stronger than Guinness Stout but with more of a medicinal taste.  Interesting, but not for me.

Bottle best before 8/16/12...poop - Pours deep black with a thick foamy tan head. Nose is like a baltic porter...sweet and sugary. Lots of molasses. Taste is the same...tons of molasses, a roasty bitterness, and some dark fruitiness. A bit of heat on the finish. Pretty watery taste. Medium body and medium carbonation.
This is a good one! Has a chocolate taste with a slight bitterness. Also has a nice hop too it. This is a seriously great beer!

Pours pitch black with a good three fingers of sticky brown head that leaves excellent lacing. Aroma is burnt bread, molasses, and chocolate. Taste is molasses and dry malts with waves of hop and dark chocolate bitterness that leads to a good, full finish. This is a fine beer, and much better than extra stout or draught. Fairly priced for what it is.

This bottled brew from a grocery store poured a head of cascading foam finely sized light brown colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a and a thick foamy lacing. The aroma was brown malt roasted malt and dark malt. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish. The flavor contained notes of roasted malt brown malt and hops. A decent one that I would consider buying again.  Quite quaffable.

Odd aroma of cinnamon and milk. Very dark black color with nice lacing against the glass. Slightly smokey flavors of vanilla, toffee and oats. Overall, for what it is, it’s pretty good. a nice change of pace.
Bottle from Tescos.  Great beer.  Much better than the version of this brewed in Africa which sadly I am more familiar with.

330 mL bottle from Total Wine in Tucson AZ, served in a tulip. Pours black with a tall, dense tan head. The head remains and leaves lots of fine lace.  The nose has huge notes of molasses and roasted malts, along with chocolate, coffee, earth and a hint of anise. Herbal hops are more prominent than in the base beer. The flavour is moderately sweet with molasses, anise and espresso. This is balanced against herbal hops and earth, with pepper throughout. The finish is long, lingering roasted malts, espresso and molasses with hops and a touch of anise. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a silky smooth texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice foreign stout. Much more subtle and complex than the original, with much more nuance. 2012-03-14
Remarkably different than the standard Guinness draught, this one features a much greater sweetness than its dry brother, with a heartier body and mouthfeel and more noticeable alcohol notes.

Bitter after and very thick head. Not a big fan. I'll stick with the normal stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

120z bottle.  Pours black with generous foamy beige head.  Sweet malty aroma.  Roasty chocolate malt flavor balanced with just a bit of hoppiness.  Full bodied with thick creamy mouthfeel.  Very good.

Wow. Beautiful to a palate saturated with trashy lagers. Complex aroma that is unique to anything I’ve had before. Sweetened boozy malt, dark chocolate, coffee and nut. Pours pitch black with classic foam. Aftertaste is nice and bitter with a little sweetness. A potent package that puts the palate through several sensations. Bottle in Costa Rica.
bottle. near black with small head. seems to have a bit more hops than normal guinness, and just overall a bit more intense, perhaps at the expense of being less smooth.

Bottle. Dark coffee brown color with foamy brown head. Thick nose of malt and estery hop, both burnt sugar and coffee dominate. Heavy palate of brown sugar, roasted coffee, and caramel. Thick in malts. Did not pick the hops up as much. Bitter malt finish. Both crisp and bitter. Very nice.

Bottle from Wine Lord, Birmingham.  Having rated beers from 64 countries I’m amazed I haven’t yet rated one from just across the Irish Sea.  This pours trademark Guinness black with a lacey head.  Very strong sickly aroma - brown sugar, fruitcake, red wine, honey.  Not a big stout fan but this avoids being too bitter.  Nicely balanced bittersweet tang.  Long finish but not too dry.  Active mouthfeel.  Excellent.

Had this one when I was in Ireland in 2010,  Happy to finally have it here in the U.S.  pours  black with foamy tan head.  Roasted malt chocolate aroma.  Rich roasted malt flavor with dark chocolate flavors.  Some vanilla and smoky notes.  Hops in the finish.
Pours a dark brown with a minimal tan head.  Smells of roast chocolate malts and flowery hops.  Taste is a robust malt with a moderate balanced hops.
While on the surface this seems "tastier", it gives me a new appreciation of the regular stuff; the hop-forward approach here throws off the balance.

330ml bottle, purchased in Dublin, brewed in St James Gate. Pours thick coffee black with a big frothy tan head, excellent lacing. Sweet roast malt on the nose, along with some grain and notes of plum. More roast malt in the flavour, some oats, with a mild twist of hop bitterness. Quite thick and slick in the mouth. More carbonation than the draught, but still quite soft. Not overly complex but very enjoyable.

Thanks to Seymour for giving this one to me.  Pours pretty dark brown with a large soapy tan head.  The aroma has lots of cocao, fruit, ice cream, smooth roast and mild earth.  Medium smooth body with very soft carbonation.  Starts with charred heavily roasted malt, woodiness, dark chocolate, earthy hops and dark caramel.  The finish gets more bitter and a bit harsh.  Decent stout and a bit more forceful that I expected.

Struggling with this to be honest. Looks fine, has the most complex and forceful house character of the company’s offerings but lacking in that morish cherry core which was once this beer’s biggest draw. Sort of interesting  but where is the joy?
Deep black pour with a brown head. Very foamy. Aroma is roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate. Taste is roasted malt. chocolaye. Dry aftertaste. Great lacing. Very good beer.
Great lacing, chocolate,coffee, and deliciousness. As solid a commercial stout as there can be.enjoyed it.
This beer is beautiful with a head that reminds me a root beer float.  Great roasted malt flavor with great counter bitterness.

I think this the best Guinness has to offer. Nice roasted malt aroma. Really cool dark brown color with a thin head that briefly laces the glass. Strong malt (almost with a hint of coffee) and hops hit you first. The flavors blend well with the roasted malt filling the mouth the longest. Finally, this is relatively easy to find. Alcohol covered well.
Pours dark black with a small tan head, berry and malt aroma, malty chocolate taste with a hint of blackbery some liquorice. Silky mouth feel, very good.

11.2oz bottle 11/11/12 (Dominicks-Part of Winter Selection Variety Pack)-42° in Snifter-Pours black with a one finger tan head. Aroma of hops, chocolate, malt, and coffee. Taste of the same with more hops and a nice chocolatey finish. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and I believe better than the draught. Nice job.

330 ml bottle purchased at the Westmere Beverage Center (Albany, New York) on September 18, 2012. Dark brown, small head. Sweet malted barley aroma, fudge notes. the taste is the same, with a touch of alcohol, bitter coffee. This is way better then the Draught!

Bottle. Pours and almost black color with a moderate off-white head. Not a lot in the smell of this other than just a little bit of malt. Taste has a healthy bit of bitterness, which isn’t quite what I expected.

Pours black, with a lovely light tan head. Aromas of roasts, plums, berries and toffee. Soon the alcoholic scent smothers everything elese. Chalky texture, very grainy, with a strong alcohol flavour, too overwhelming for the other roasted flavours to manifest. Alcohol is not subtle, even masking the bitterness. Far from being among the best stouts. A strong beer, still a good guinness, but the regular draught version is much superior than this.
cok guzel bira cok.. cidden.. U2 irish pub istanbul’da kesinlikle denenmeli.. turkiye’de bu birayi icebileceginiz en güzel yer.. kesinlikle içmeli, içmeden olunmemeli..

Pours a clear dark black color with a brown head that dissipates quickly. On the nose you can smell a mix of red and black licorice. Taste is of cocoa and coffee and finishes impressively dry for such a sweet smell.

Rich black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, & some coffee; Flavor of roasted/burnt malt, caramel, hops, and chocolate; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, quite good - better than the draught version for sure.

Bottle. Been wanting to try this forever, finally available.  Black and opaque. Strong carbonation.  Rich, roasty aroma.  Wow - this was worth the more than 15 year wait from hearing of it to trying it.

Found in Scrooge’s Spirits in Anderson, SC for $8/ 4-pack

A: Pours a pitch black color with a soapy caramel color head. Retention is decent.

S: A little subtle, but big roasty aroma, dark fruits (raisin, fig), and lots of molasses. Light hop character as well.

T: Tons and tons of molasses, some dark fruit, coffee and a huge roasted malt flavor. Hops are there too. Decent bitterness as well.

MF/D: The feel borders on medium/light, carbonation is a little prickly for my liking, but still real nice. Finishes dry. Alcohol is there only in a warming sense.

Notes: Nice to have this in the US now, hopefully it’ll be readily available. Really nice from Guinness

RAC out tonight. Flat battery. No petrol. I know nothing about cars but I know that is not good. So, embarrassing trip to the petrol station, an £80 battery and all is well. Except it is not, is it? It works, but needs more attention. Mrs D already looking for a new car online. I’m taking solace in this Guinness. The thing I find most worrying is I try so hard to talk to mechanics, etc, but they can clearly see I know nothing. They probe my understanding to make the situation worse. Spark plugs, coils, immobiliser, oil, engine...ask me about obscure African funk bands and I’m away though. Check out the Nigerian Police Force Band...brilliant.
Pours black with a thick head. Aroma has a bit of chocolate and fruit to it. However, it tastes like cardboard and burnt coffee. Pretty shitty.

Bottle at work. Cleaning up some interesting styles lately. Pours clear black, thin tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is ashy, nutty berries, lots of smoke and creosote. Flavours are bittersweet, lots of berry, cough drops, more ash. No. Just no.
A nice big beer, more flavorful and a bit more intense than "normal" Guinness. Higher ABV too.  Has some burnt grain, cofee, and unsweetened chocolate notes to it with a dry roasted bitterness.

Black body, thick tan head. A fairly subdued aroma of roasted malts, sticky dark fruits and burnt coffee. Coffee, dark fruits, treacle, milk chocolate, caramel and a hint of cola in the taste. Rich and creamy mouthfeel. A go-to beer.

Bottle at home (BOE) 11/10/12 (birthday beer #2 !).
Irish brewed bottle.
Mid black with a big frothy coffee/tan head that subsided after a few minutes but retains well. Decent lacing ensues.
Big roast malt nose backed up with a good dose of barley, some toffee notes, slightly medicinal/TCP, a little wood and a puff of smoke.
The medicinal and smokey tones immediately hit you in the taste. Roast malts are more secondary.
Medium bodied with a little spritzy carbonation leading to a slightly smokey dry finish. The alcohol is fairly well disguised.
Better than bog standard bland Guinness but wouldn’t actively seek this out in the future.

Bottle, Irish version. Dark beer with brown consistent head. Great aroma with notes of rosted malt. Great taste. A top class beer. 7-4-8-4-17-40. 20/09/2012

Bottle. Pours almost black with a huge brown head. A bit warm. Aroma is sweet, roasted, toffee, olive, light alchool. Flavor is roasted malt, smoke, again some light olive, creamy & sticky mouthfeel. 7-5-8-4-16-40. 11/10/2013

Pours a blackish brown, retention reeling alive, legs crawling down the brim. Nosed balsamic vinegar, soil, smoke and burnt plastic. Tasted molasses, hops, charcoal, spices and yeast; an obvious nutty flavor at swallow followed by vegetation, chocolate and skim milk. Thanks, Guinness.

Appearance was clear black with creamy tan lasting 2 finger head, spotty lacing. Aromas are roasted burnt chocolate malt with tannin-like slight aclohol. Taste was thin bitterness of coffee, chocolate toasted oaky malts. Palate was soft creamy CO2 with meduim body, then tinny bitter average length off finish. Best before date was 7/6/12 maybe that why the flouvor is off...
Burnt coffee flavours balanced with  warm mellow alcohol glow.Christmas after a few of these would be  a very happy day! The head of the Guinness family and no mistake.

Opaque black, creamy mocha head. Huge aroma of sweet, roasty, milk chocolatey malts. Soft mouthfeel, soft carb, you can really taste the original recipie, but its fuller, thicker and way more robust. Loads of sweet, sticky, roasty, soy laden malts. Medium bitter finish, with a solid roasty aftertertaste.

Opaque Black with a dark brown head. Aroma of chocolate/cocoa, roasted malts, barley and slight hoppiness. Taste of barley, chocolate, yeasts, mocha and roasted malts. Fairly light body and smooth feel thanks to the low carbonation. Overall an excellent stout and beer in general.

Cant believe I’ve not rated this one yet.   This one is imported from Ireland and is a month past its "best by" date.  Bottle pours a dark brown with a full and dense light tan head.   Light roasted aroma with tootsie roll and milk chocolate.  More bitter roasted flavor but with plenty of sweet cola and chocolate again. Slight metallic trailer at the very end and some residual smokey bitter.   Hides the 7.5% pretty well.
Very dark brown black with a nice light brown head. Aromas of cocoa nib, dried fruit and black coffee. Rich palate with lots of anise and black coffee flavors. Not my thing, but well made

Nice dark cola color with a nice tall tan head. Scent is some roasted chocolate and coffee, taste is similar with coffee taking over the chocolate, pretty good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Looks chocolate brown when poured and has a medium head that laces the glass for the duration of the beverage.  The aroma is big.  Coffee, caramel and malt are a big presence from three feet away.  The flavor is all of that, a rich, hearty roast, and more hops than I expected.

Poured a pint at pog mahones queenstown, thick brownish head, dark black colour but i think everyone knows that. Tastes classic guinness, smooth smooth slightly malty/hoppy coffee flavours, altogether nice draught beer but maybe a little overproduced
Good thick mouth with a beige head that dissipated fairly quickly, possibly due to a bad pour. Great flavors; coffee chocolate slight bitter but wonderful full taste.

Pours black with a thick, dark tan head.
Aroma is locorice, chocolate, cream......coffee.
Taste is rich coffee bitter, silky and creamy....nicely roasted.
Perhaps the best version aside from on tap..(while in Europe)
Well done.....a great beer.

I was excited to find a 4-pack of this at Whole Foods in Alexandria, VA for $9.99.

A: Wow. This looks quite a bit different than the Guinness I am used to seeing. The liquid is a deep, rich, impenetrable black shade. The head is two inches of thick beige head that has long lasting retention. As it gradually subsides, it coats the sides of the tulip glass with sticky lace.

S: The aroma is considerably weaker than one would expect, given the appearance of this stout. Cream, milk chocolate and malt are the primary scents. Honestly, it doesn’t smell much different than a regular Guinness.

T: I am a fan of Guinness beer, as it is one of the first craft beers I ever had the pleasure to taste. I would definitely say that the Foreign Export Stout is a better beer than the regular variety so commonly found at the local bar. It is richer

M: Smooth and creamy, but not as much as the regular version. Foreign Export Stout feels more carbonated and a step closer to a double stout.

D: I am really enjoying this beer. If you’re a fan of Guinness, you should definitely try this.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-15-2010

330 ml bottle. Brownish black with a long-lasting beige head. Tastes like chocolate, roast, ash. Nice coffeeish bitterness, with some roasted notes. Thick and visquous. Weak carbonation. This, my friend, is the epitome of Guinness.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a nice dark brown foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt with light sweet notes is pretty good. Taste is a nice mix between some solid roasted malt with dry notes and some light sweet undertones. Body has somewhat of a creamy texture with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. This is definitely a step-up from the regular Guinness.
Bottle at Howard Hotel in Taipei. Bottle matches the picture. Overall not bad at all. Seemed a little "raw" if that makes sense? Nice but could be better balanced overall.

Musky, dark cherry pit, licorice, dark chocolate. Campfire, chocolate, and cherry dominate. Deep, rich flavors, over a smooth, slightly oily body and a bitter-tart finish. Delicious, a real surprise. Reminds me of Hercules Stout. 3.9.
Bottle. Almost black with medium beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and liquorice. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, liquorice, little coffee, medium sweet and a little acid.

This is an awesome beer, quite strong and may be hard to stomach if you dislike guinness... worth trying as it is much closer to the orginal style of guinness than the modern nitrus-fused creamy guinness; this one takes on a much darker, rougher and carbonated style... Pours a thick black colour with a soft brown thick creamy head... aroma highlights sweet chocolate... taste has similar guinness characteristics but is much more like a burnt chocolate with a smokey aftertaste. For me this is a lovely beer, a nice enjoyable ABV and a nice kick in the taste, in terms of style I love the history and background of this particular version of guinness!
The extra stout is a decent variation. Not for those who have a hard time with Guinness stout.

330ml bottle. Black beer with cappucino-bown head. Aroma of cocoa and roasted bread. Flavour is rich roasted dark chocolate, grain and notes of smoke. Well balanced sweet and bitter medium to long aftertaste with some alcohol. Stronger carbonated than most Guiness.

Pours oily black with tan head. Aroma of earth and banana. Taste of caramel and coffee with a bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
a tasty brew. Roasty goodness, slight bitterness, not too burnt, dry finish, thin body, easy-drinker for 8%. Such a refreshing change from the standard draught Guinness while living in Ireland.
Pours jet black with a tan head and thick lacing. Aroma is deep chocolate and licorice. The taste is more chocolate with tobacco and a touch of whiskey. This is quite complex.

Blah. Had this at Guinness brewery ( the tourist one in Dublin ). Couldn't finish it. Way to hoppy for a beer like this. Tasted like an old shoe

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A strong black stout with a toffee coloured head. The smell is glorious - chocolate, malty and of toffee. It has a bitter sweet strength which encourages a slow consumption, it never allows you to ignore the fact that this stout packs a punch. Very satisfying, enjoying a bottle at home in front of the TV, the best place to enjoy a drink like this.
Great tasting stout, long and smooth. For a strong stout, tastes surprisingly light. Best at room temperature

Pours pitch black with a small beige head. Sweet, creamy chocolate aroma with roasted malt. Taste is sweet but with a bite from hops. Bitterness and sweetness balance pretty well.  Finish is smooth but the aftertaste could be better. Pretty good foreign stout overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
What’s to say about this beer. It’s absolutely lovable. Beautiful color, aroma, head, lingers on the palate, absolutely amazing taste. I freaking love this beer.

Pours thick deep black color with a thin tan head that retains very well. Sweet charred malt aroma.  Flavors of smoke, chocolate, coffee, and toasted malts add to the mild hop profile.  The mouthfeel was smooth and fairly dry with full body and moderate carbonation.
black color, aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, flavor is the same, dry slightly bitter finish,

This is, without question, one of the best beers I’ve ever had. The only part about it that was less than fantastic was the bottle was only 11.2 oz. It pours a deep dark, opaque brown, nearly black. Smells roasty, almost, but not quite like coffee. It’s hoppy, and strong, smooth on the tongue. I can’t say enough. This is truly a special beer.
Flaska (Irländsk) I stort sett svart öl med brunt skum. Doftar av rostade toner, mörkt socker och mörka frukter. Rostade toner, kaffe och choklad i smaken tillsammans med en viss alkoholsötma.

Das Bier ist schwarz nur ein kleines bisschen dunkelrotes Licht fällt hindurch wenn man es gegen das Licht hält. Die Schaumkrone hält 3min und ist braun. Starke Kaffee Geruchs- und Geschmacksaromen, röstmalzig und bisschen lakritzartig. Der Nachgeschmack bleibt schön stark. Fazit: Muss man mal probiert haben, interessanter Test, möchte ich zwar nicht immer trinken, ist aber eine tolle abwechslung. Ein Schaumkranz bleibt am Glasoberrand hängen.
	
Test vom 8.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 13,12,10,12,12,12 - 11,80

Bottle consumed late at night in a lounge bar in Belize. It pours black, with a thin tan head. The nose is roasted malt, coffee, burnt notes and bitter chocolate. The taste is rich roasted malt, very bitter coffee, bitter chocolate, liquorice, ash, burnt malt and some underlying sweetness, with a bitter finish. Medium-full body and moderate carbonation.  It’s flavoursome, but perhaps a bit rich. The classic foreign stout.
Dark brown color and slowly settling thick foam head. Leaving lacing on glass and sticks to lip. Sweet smell, but also chocolate. Taste like guinness, unique. (Ufa 201202)
11.2oz bottle: Appearance is pitch black with tan head. Aroma is of roasted/burnt malt. Taste is much heavier than typical Guinness and also filled with roasted malt and chocolate tastes.

Backlog, bottle in Rome
Black color, brownish foam
Medium/ full body & complexity
Very enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Molasses and dark fruit aroma. Black brown with a small tan head. Dark roasted malt, molasses, chocolate, coffee, ash flavor with a long lingering bitter finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Sum of the parts make up to a little less than hoped. Satisfying roasted malt.

Carib it would appear turn their hand to anything and everything. This product is one of their best.

275ml bottle (like all Carib beers), best before May 2009, drank June 2008.

Poured into a half-pint tumbler on the hotel balcony. Looked just like a normal Guinness, dark and with a good deep tan head.

The aroma, taste and mouthfeel all seemed overly burnt. Dry and bitter with some caramel trying to be heard in the mix.

Rich, but not creamy, burnt malts ruled the brew and for some could have ruined it too.
Bottle. Pours an appealing black with a tan head. Sweet burnt sugar and a light fruity aroma. Flavour is liquorice, burnt sugar and treacle. Initially sweet before a strong bitter finish.

Bottle. Pitch black pour with thin tan foam. Aroma of burnt grain, coffee and licorice. Torrified molasses. Taste is rich, kind of sweet with a bitter burnt flavor in the finish, some alcohol warmth. Palate is rich, with medium carbonation. Lingering coffee finish. Quite potent, good, but not outstanding. If I was in Africa however, I can picture how this could become a life saver flavor-wise.

33cl bottle. Pours deep, thick black colour with a huge billowing brown head - lots of thick lacing. Aroma full of molasses, toffee, woody smoked notes, treacle. Taste again full to the brim with deep flavours, molasses especially, hints of coffee, chocolate, smoke, roasted barley. Satisfyingly full and silky mouthfeel with a lingering bitterness. A solid FES.

Bottle.  Black with a massive lasting, thick foamy, deep tan head and lacing galore - looks awesome. Dark chocolate, dark roasted malt, nutty, liquorice, vanilla, basement aromas.  Moderately sweet, at least moderately bitter - nice flavour. Medium body, soft carbonation, astringent slightly burnt dark chocolate finish. Very likeable.
Bottle from Mane Liquor. Reminds me a lot of Coopers Best Extra Stout but with a touch more carbonation and spritz. Good, solid stout

Poured into a glass stein. Absolutely pitch black with two fingers of tan head. Looks perfect.
Rich molasses smell and some vanilla bean.
Tastes like molasses also. A balanced bitterness throughout with a burnt malt at the end.
Thick, almost creamy body with low carbonation.
Wow. Calling it a benchmark. Guinness has brought it strong on this one.
330ml bottle from Alko. Pitch black colour with huge brown head. Aroma is  malt, sweet, dark fruits, chocolate. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, hops.

33cl bottle. Black with a tanned head. Nose : tart , toffee, chocolate notes. Herbs , fruity citrus notes . Pine. Sip : Medium density with low carbonation. Almost full body with sweet, black chocolate taste. The bitterness is a well balanced mix of bitter chocolate and strong fruity hops. I’m thinking cascade. Overall it’s an exciting Guinness. Well Done !

Bottle.  Pours dark, dark crimson, very nearly opaque, with a 3-finger creamy and meringue-like light brown head.  Long retention and blebby lacing.  Aromas of toffee, raspberry, and caramel, with cream and mocha as well.  The flavor is sweet toffee and burnt sugar, sugar cane, and roasty and bitter coffee in the finish.  Medium carbonation, a bit prickly, with full body.  NIce.  [1020]
Unique aroma, but pleasant, with character.  Taste is complex a cornucopia of compounding flavors.

33 cl bottle @ O’Connel’s, Tampere.

Originally rated on 20090215. (7+4+7+4+15)

Pours pitch black color with medium off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, very sweet dark ripe fruits and sugar candy. Flavour of roasted malts, dark chocolate, ripe fruits, dark berry notes, caramel and toffee notes.

4316

A: Pours an almost solid black body with an incredibly foamy 3-finger mocha colored head, that features stupidly high retention and lacing.

S: Chocolate, coffee, caramel, subtle fruitiness, and some smoke. All in all, smells great.

T: The body opens with a nice, chocolaty sweetness from the roasted malts, while the finish is a bit smoky, and surprisingly piny. Generally, hoppier stouts aren’t quite my cup of tea (see: Sierra Nevada Stout), but the hop profile here is executed very well.

M: A bit thin-bodied, to be honest, with nice dryness in the finish. It also extracts the piny bitterness without being oppressively sticky or palate ruining. Lowish carbonation.

O: It’s not perfect, but it’s genuinely impressive, especially next to regular  Guinness Draught. The thin body lets it down a tad, but this is still a great stout that I will be on the lookout for in the future.
Bigger, badder and stronger than the original. If this was a boxing match extra foreign wins hands down
Pours like a nice dark stout with an everlasting head.  Looks and tastes the part.  An unexpected and pleasant surprise.  Good beer.  Much better than the Labatts stuff.  Strong and rich.
This is  the old school Guinness Extra Stout prior to the Labatts contract for US export. Second to none.

Bottle.  I wasnt expecting much but I loved it from the first sip.  It is a bit overpowering on the coffee taste.  Rich and creamy with a slight bitter finish.  I hate drinking coffee but this is a very nice beer.

Bottle: dark pour with large tan head.  Aroma is chocolate powder with a sour grainy wood.  Flavor is bittersweet grain and oat, chocolate with a tart funkiness in between.  Overall, liked it.  A lot of flavor and complexity to process.

12 oz. bottle. Solid black. Has a more bubbly brown foam than the Guinness Draught, what with no widget. Smell is just a little heady with notes of treacle and coffee. Taste is sweeter than the Draught, and does have a good thread of alcohol to it. Thicker than the Draught. Almost like an Imperial Stout. Tough of the Guinness essence (slight sourness). A crunch of hops comes in at the end, with an almost American aggressiveness.

Black with tawny port notes in the dimple of the glass. Good carpet of mocha coloured head. Aromas of pumpernickel, molasses, licorice, thick black coffee and sweet caramel. Just about one of the sexiest smells there is. Velety and silky texture with tiny, brisk carbonated bubbles on all areas of the tongue. What a treat. Wonderful flavours of molasses, date pudding and even dark chocolate. Seriously good beer.

Pours black with a pale light brown head. Warm rich aroma. Slightly bitter in taste but with malty, chocolate flavours with alcohol taste for depth. Being Irish I rate this over any bottle or draught  I’ve had from Guinness before, actually it wipes the floor with any other Guinness!

11.2oz bottle.  Pours black with a short lived brown head and some lacing.  Aroma is of roasted grain, bready malt and some chocolate.  Body is full, smooth and oily.  Roasted grain, chocolate malt, some dark fruit and a lot of earthy hops fill the mouth. The finish is long and bitter.  I can’t say I enjoyed this brew.
Black colour with an off white head. Coffee and dark malt aroma. Roasted malt, coffee and licorice flavour.

11.2 oz bottle into a pint glass at room temperature. St. Patrick’s day review...

A - Pitch black body with a massive light khaki head. Dies down to a neat cap with nice lacing and retention.

S - Bittersweet milk chocolate, roasted malts, and some dark fruits. The finish has a bit of alcohol heat.

T - Similar to the nose. Sweet milk chocolate and roasted malts. Ends abruptly with some bitter and mineral notes. Alcohol is well masked. Mouth feel is light to medium with low carbonation.

O - A massive improvement over the draught. High drinkability with a pretty high ABV. Its a damn solid beer, nothing too complex or over the top. Just a clean and simple stout....which makes its $10/4 pack price seem a bit excessive.

Bottle. Bready,  mild chocolate aroma. Midnight black in appearance, with a nice pillowy head and nice lacing. Interesting balance between the hops and malts, with sweetness at first with a bitter finish. Thick, creamy texture with soft carbonation. Overall, much better than draught and a step up from stout. Hop-Heads should try this offering from Guinness.

Bottle. Pour jet black with a very slight ruby haze. Huge lumpy tan head which lasts and lasts... chocolatey smells, bready smells. In the mouth, theres more chocolate, a slight alcohol kick, some banana, stewed fruits and a nice bitter hoppiness. There’s a caramel and bitters finish which is really pleasant.
Bottle at a Togolese shop in Paris.  Dark brown, thick beige head.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is creamy coffee with a Hershey’s bar in it.

Very pretty dark brown pour with a dense, lasting tan head.  Smells chocolatey, a little bready.  Not a very strong aroma.  Moderate chocolatey roasted flavors, some tartness, like sour fruit, toffee, dark dried fruit.  Rather harsh on the finish, very boozy, nicely balanced bitterness.  This is miles better than Guinness Draught, but not really in the upper tier of stouts.

Bottle. Pours black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma is nice chocolate, sweet caramel and marshmallow note with a light roast, touches of dark fruit , earthy hops. Flavor starts sweet with the same candy note, light roast and burnt note, sweet cocoa and roast, nice hoppiness towards the finish to help out with the strong sweet and lightly sticky note. More dark fruit and a crisp finish. Medium to medium full body and a crisp carbonation. Very nice beer.

Picked this up for $5.99 at a beer store. Best before 4/07/12 and poured into a Newcastle glass. I’ve heard really great things about this beer.



A - Poured a dark brown to black out of the bottle. In the glass, it’s nearly pitch black. I got a 5 finger head of tight creamy bubbles that were coffee / chocolate color.



S - This is a fairly weak smelling beer. I’m getting dark malts, earthy malts and some breadiness. Standard Guinness scent and nothing special. 



T - Whoa. Delicious. It’s a guinness but improved taste and overall palate. More hops it would seem, more carbonation and less dry.



M - light bodied believe it or not but maybe it’s the high carbonation leading me to think that. Nice Guinness linger, easy to drink. I can’t taste the alcohol at all.



O - I drank Guinness a lot when I was younger. This is that times 2. It’s really delicious but lacks in scent.

While visiting the Guinnes Storehouse tour I was able to get a special tatsing with Guinness employees in the Snig bar on the fifth floor. About 10 other visitors were able to get a special tasting of three products   The Guinness draught is very common but the Foreign Extra Stout is not.  Some fellas from Cork had never had this version of Guinness.  This stout has higher levels of alcohol and hopping for distribution around the world.  The dark black stout had a thick tan head and aroma of smoke and coffee.  The roasted malts and higher hop levels create a very complex stout. The stout has average carbonation  and some chocolate notes at the finish.  I will look for this in the US.

Nice balance between hops and malt. Very tasty with a nice bitter after taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sweet, light roast aroma, a bit of wood and wiskey notes.  Black with a pillow tan head.  Roasty and sweet with all the characters of the aroma.

Note: At St. James Gate visit!

Solid black with a slight brown tint. Thick bubbly lasting creamy tan head. Smells of malt, smoke with a light sweet chocolate caramel. Full oily body. Flat. Deep soft smokey roast taste. Lasting smokeyness on the tongue. Sweet butter chocolate start with a dark roast black chocolate bitter finish. Keeps me coming back. Delicious. But a little burnt.

Guinness Malt Liquor? Better than any other. The right amount of alcohol and flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark black with deep ruby highlights at the edges. Nice large, rocky head sits on top and shrinks to a creamy cap. Roasted aroma upfront blends into sweet malts with creamy coffee hints. Flavor is roasted malt bitterness - burnt and bitter flavors linger.

This one obtained from Binny’s.  Poured with the same darkness as regular Guinness, and a less than average head.  The malt profile was breadlike with a little more mineral (gypsum) taste than regular Guinness.  This was not a defect.  Very good mouthfeel and palate.  The hops were a little more prevalent than in the regular product, and were of an herbal nature.  Alcohol was fairly well hidden, but makes its presence felt later.  A beer I’ll go to in the future for a change of stout pace.

Tasted from 11.2 oz bottle into nonic pint, thanks zielimac! Brewed in Ireland. Appearance, aromas, flavors, and overall impression just like regular Guinness, which is to say miraculous, but this one had an even thicker head, stronger hops aroma, and was a wee bit more robust. Alcohol was very well concealed, but could be felt, and became slightly more pronounced as it warmed. Tart, bready, roasty, with even a little unexpected sourness in the background. Full-bodied, creamy, chewy mouthfeel with a little chalkiness. Delicious, and definitely something I’ll be purchasing again and again.

Head: Pours with a thick tan colored head that stays for some time. 
Color: Black; not transparent.
Aroma: Chocolate, lightly roasted with the scent of alcohol present on the nose
Taste: Dark Chocolate is the most potent taste with bread and roasted coffee following. Alcohol is noticeable on the back of the throat. 
Finish: Dry roasted finish lingers for some time. 
Overall:  More pronounced version of Guinness Draught in each category. If you like Guinness, you’ll love this beer. If your not a fan, you can skip this one. Not something you could drink many of in a night but defiantly glad to try it.

From notes.  First reviewed 1/25/2011.  Poured from an 11.2 oz. bottle into a pint glass. Part of a side by side with Guinness Draught and Extra Stout.

A great big beige head almost makes it difficult to keep in the glass. Great head retention and sheets of lace on the glass. Worth noting that this is the only Guinness I saw leave lacing. The color is nearly black, with a few tints of ruby here and there.

There is a full roasted malt aroma, with molasses, cocoa, and roast coffee. The raisins are in there, but definitely seem to take a back seat in this version.

The taste starts off sweet, with molasses leading into roasted malt. Cocoa, then a coffee flavor leading to spicy, earthy hops and a firm bitterness. Some smoke steps in and the finish is left somewhat bitter. The bitter coffee and hop flavors really accentuate the roasted malt to snuff out the sweetness at the end of the sip. 

This body steps it up even further over Extra Stout. A full bodied stout, this is also creamier. Some lightly astringent feeling on the tongue. Some hop residue hides behind the lips. 

This is solid. I really enjoy the flavors that continually reveal themselves in more complexity. Well done, and at 7.5%, it provides a nice kick without getting destructive.

Fairy rich chocolate aroma, with roasted barley and some tart carbonic gaseousness. Mild hop character, soy sauce, coffee. Dark brown-black clear, opaque, with creamy cocoa-colored lacing head. Medium to heavy body, with medium carbonation. Starts fairy dry, with big roasted barley, chocolate, and coffee notes. Molasses, with sugar-carbonic acid tang. Medium to full roasted bitter finish, with hop bitter finish and after. Tasty and mildly tangy, a nice stout.

GFE is fantastic.  I love Guinness and I love the draught, but this is the real treat to look for.  Pours black with a fantastic tan head, smells great, and has flavor that is out of this world.  It’s like the draught but with the flavor turned up; malt, bread, with a touch of booze.  Get this if you can and enjoy it.

bottle  bb feb 12   pours black with a thick tan head . very sweet aroma  with medium carbonation and body .  sweet taste to start before roasted malts and a long bitter finish rounds it off nicely . A decent beer .
aroma, had on a cruise ship, some deep malts smokey, color, drank from bottle, taste, smoke then the maltness comes out, overall, better that their classic, but not a reg for me
Bottle. Deep black color, Smells of malt, bread and some booze. Extremely flavorful compared to all the Guinness’ I had. Probably my favorite one.

seems to be my favorite variety and the hardest to find in the US  I like the taste better than that from cans or  the longneck bottles.  This  seems truer to the taste of  pub-draught guinness and with 7.5% abv  stronger  than the  normal bottled  brew.  Well Done, harp brewery!

Very nice aroma, the floral notes from the hops is pleasant to the nose. Color dark black with tan head made of small to medium size bubbles. Taste is bitter from the extra hops and differentiates it from its brothers.  On the palate, it is full body thick with a flat long finish. Overall a nice surprise, kudos to my daughter & son-in-law for sharing with me.

341ml bottle purchased from a convenience store in Haiti. Apparently the locals insist that you should drink this from the bottle? Perhaps next time. Pours with a humongous creamy beige/tan head.  Strong retention even after some time there’s still a thin cap, lacing is very minor and spotty.. Appearance is dark brown. Aroma is roasted caramel malt and chocolate chocolate,  alcohol is noticeable but not dominant. Taste is very sweet upfront with a dry finish. Reminds me of Lion Stout but not as complex. This is pretty balanced though and well made. Nice!
Bottle. Had this one on Grand Turk. Love it! Wonderful balance. Great dark amber brown. Aroma of nutty, toasted molasses. Taste was a toasted malt with a great balance of hops. Good stuff.

(bottle) pours an almost completely black colour with a frothy light brown head. aroma of canned peaches, herbal hops, buttered toffee, straciatella and light roasted grain. flavour is mostly the same, quite sweet, with lots of toffee, some grass and a slightly alcoholic, light roasted-bitter finish. medium to heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

330ml bottle poured into a pint glass.

The beer pours pitch black with a one finger dark tan head. Great head retention and lacing.

Aroma of sweet, spiced rum along with some coffee and dark chocolate. Also some dark fruit along with that sourness typical of guinness.

Flavors of rum come in first closely followed by coffee. Roasted barley follows along with more cocoa. Finally, there is a slight hint of dark fruit along with a moderate bitterness/sourness reminiscent of regular guinness.

This is really a great beer. It is quite rich and fulfilling all without being too heavy or overbearing. A top notch stout that I will return to again and again.

I enjoy Guinness beers a lot but I find myself thinking no special taste, I found this in pathmark supermarket and I must say the taste is good. Stinger the regular and smoother with sweeter taste, so far my fav Guinness. I can where people would rank it high due to its smooth flavor, if you can find it then I’m sure will find you. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Flasche) Die Farbe ist sehr, sehr dunkel, braun und so undurchsichtig, dass man eine Trübung nicht sehen könnte. Der bräunliche Schaum ist leicht cremig. Das Aroma ist warm, leicht schwer, süßlich mit einer leichten Röstnote. Geschmacklich ist es vollmundig, leicht malzig, röstig mit einer minimalen sauren Note, wie vom Apfel, im Abgang. Die Bittere ist breit, nicht stark und langanhaltend. Zusammengefasst sollte man ein anderes Bier frühstücken.
Liquid toffee with roast flavor. Not a pleasant aftertaste. These guinness beers just aren’t good.

Bottled, 330ml from Sainsbury’s in Banbury. Black with tan head. Initial muscovado molasses type sugary note, syrupy but with a background of dark malts, fruity, never gets crisp as advertised but reasonably drinkable.

A dark brown, almost black coloured beer with a creamy, beige head. The aroma is roasted malty with notes of coffee, chocolate and peanut. The taste is hoppy bitter with a hint of coffee and dark cocolate. The aftertaste is long and bitter-sweet.

Currently drinking while typing. After pouring you are greeted by strong smells of brown sugar, caramel, burnt and toasty malts in a depth of sweetness. Great appearance! A suitable beige if not lighter brown bubbly foam that floats on top of a deep chocolate brown almost black vessel of Stout. Tastes of sweet sugars initially that calm into a subtle bitterness with an embracing burnt aftertaste. A mix of burnt toast, earth, smoke, sugars and a gentle hop finish. Great feel in mouth, very full and big along with being creamy and having a soft warmth at the back of the throat. Good Stout with a great feel to it along with rich flavours, can’t argue with that!

Dark fruity aroma. Pitch black with a healthy two finger head. The head is more bubbly than the traditional Guinness which is like foam. Dark fruit hops are prevalent with a roasted malt background. Does have a crispness to it. Some bitterness but is balanced off with the sweetness from the hops. This is for those who would like a little bite than the traditional Guinness Draught

deep thick dark brown/black liquid. pours a tanned foamy head. aromascape is full of dark chocolate, cream, toffee and caramel, herbs, bread.. taste is dark sweet with a low bitter kick, supported by the mild spiky sourness. works pretty well but does not manage to create a unified character. the palate is rather dry and a bit too watery, although not watery in overall character.

We bought a case of this almost 2 years ago. The taste was much as I anticipated, good strength,very nice strong hops, good color, small head.
We could not take the bite, It was very rough on the palate. We left it alone until just before Christmas last year and were amazed at how good it had become! Always remember that a strong beer of this sort will often improve a lot with aging..
Bottled. Pours pitch black with a big brown head. Smells roasted malt and abit boiled vegetables. Tastes roasted malt and abit bitter with a similar finish.

chocolate, coffee, earthy, banana, raisin, smoke, soy sauce, skunky, leather, black, cloudy, tan foam, minimal head, medium sweetness, very bitter, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish, bitter,
Great beer. Carbonation was not bad. Taste was that of a Guinness with a heavier alcoholic pitch. Smooth and enjoyable.

Jet black with a thick beige head. Heaps of roasted malts, peat. Much more of an intensive aroma than the original masterpiece. Silky with low carbonation and quite fruity on initial sip. Again the malt is intense and there is a hoppy bitterness quality. Creamy, silky gorgeous Guinness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

11.2oz bottle - pours motor oil meets frothy seaside pollution (in a good way) with noticeable lacing.  Nose is roasted coffee, plums and alcohol.  Aroma is roasted malty goodness.  Fairly sweet and ends roasty.  The pour looked like this would be full body, but it’s actually closer to medium that full.  Texture is slick/sticky.  I used to hate Guinness, but have opened up to it and its derivatives.  I’m surprisingly appreciating this one.

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Inky dark brew with persistent tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, molasses, dark fruits. Taste is a fine blend of sweet and bitter: sweet malts, dark fruit, caramel offset by roasted grains, bitter coffee, and dry hops tastes. Smooth and creamy palate. This reminds me of the Guinness I remember from 40 years ago.
Bottled. A black beer with a large and creamy beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and vanilla. Flavor is roasted, sweet and bitter, notes of coffee and chocolate. Milky texture.

Bottle.  Pours black with a fluffy brown head and a lot of lacing.  Smells of roasted malt, mild coffee, and some caramel.  Taste is thick, slightly bitter, and the finish is chewy and lingers on the tongue.  This is the star of the Guinness line in terms of taste.

I am finally getting around to sampling this renowned beer.  I have seen it on and off on the shelves in the past, but just never picked it up each time due to various reasons.  The pour was deep brown coming out of the bottle, but in the glass it looked very black.  The head that formed showed the classic cascading action to grow to four or five fingers thick before settling down to a large mass crowing above the rim of the pint glass.  The aroma was roasty and robust with a generous helping of coffee, brown sugar, and toffee.  The taste was excellently balanced between cream, chocolate, coffee, and molasses flavors.  Not as aggressive as many newer variations of the style, but very approachable as a result.  A little thin in the mouthfeel, but the carbonation made it feel silky smooth.  From my reading about the history of Guinness, this is probably closest to the original recipe from last century than the watered down mainstream variant sold today.  People had it better back then.

the beer of the brand which does the name guinness proud. Much more substance than the over markets and now not so special guinness draught. great pour, rustic brown sugar colour head which stays for long time like a big fluff. perfect head.! aroma is of roasted malts, banana coming though with slight caramel and coffee. Taste is burnt,roasted,chocolate with soft carbonation. nice bitterness on the finish and overall very smooth. stronger stout but cant notice the str.engh in the beer which is a credit the product. One of the great beers and the day this is marketed in draft will be the re-birth!!!!  throw me another john!
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is butterscotsch, roasted malt. Flavour is dry, butterscotsch, hop, caramel, roasted malt. Too much butter.

Very dark, almost black in colour with a dark tan head that contrasts sharply with the snowy white on the nitro keg standard strength. Aromas very smoky and vinous with black treacle, roasted chestnuts and dark chocolate. Sweet molasses on the tongue to start becoming smoky and really bitter on the aftertaste - so much so this beer left me thirsty. Full bodied and very very tasty - the guinness to go for.
Black in coloer with a decent beige head. Aroma is of chocolate and roasted malts. Tate is of roasted malts, a little ashy, dark chocolate, bitter coffee.

Bottle. Almost black with a creamy head. Aroma is heavily roasted malt and dark chocolate, burnt bread, some vanilla, some faint coffee, tobacco, wood, caramel, liquorice and hops. Full body, oily mouthfeel, low carbonation. Roasted bitter-sweetish taste, long and bitter finish. Roasted bitterness with an aftertaste of dark chocolate, some grassy hops and wood, accompanied by the warmth resulting from the quite high alcohol content. Very classy brew.
Rich and complex aroma of dark chocolate, deeply roasted malt, faint coffee, smoke, lightly burnt, sugary sweetness,   raisin-like fruit in the background

Wow.  This is really good and not sure why it took so long to get to the States.  Pours a gorgeous thick oily near black with a frothy tan head with good lacing.  Flavor is so thick, rich and full of depth, burnt popcorn, nice hop kick, grassy, so full, fruity, oily, touch sour, faint butter, purple fruit, perfect alcohol, just so slick and oily with tiny fine little tickling bubbles.  Lingering bitterness that is a bit astringent.  Like an old ale and a stout, really enjoy that.   Plenty sweet though.
Taste-wise it borders between an irish dry stout and an imperial stout. It’s alcohol content is similar. A good choice for Guinness fans who want something stronger.

Malt Liquor straight from Ireland. haha.  I guess more extra than stout (or Guinness).  Pretty harsh...knocking off points with each additional sip.  All you are really left with is off bitterness (poor hop extract?) the fully burnt parts of the malt, and the harsh edges of the alcohol.   Nice lacing.  Halfway through and it has already lost 1 full point.  Really thankful this was carbonated with CO2 as the nitrogen mellowness would have left all this harshness.  haha - leaving the review open as it looses a tenth of a point per sip, this is bad...macro brewed to 7.5% and the word "extra" in the title.  Better left in Ireland.

7.5% very dark with a thin but lasting brown head, slightly sweet Guinness aroma, bitter sweet roasted liquorish taste, better than ordinary Guinness.   I am not a fan of stouts but this was very drinkable.

Pours a dark black color with a nice tan head and good lacing. Aromas are strong chocolate, alcohol, it smells like a strong Guinness. The taste is creamy and thick chocolate, roasted malts, raisins, and alcohol, This is a very good beer and I’m glad I decided to try it.

Bottle. Black but brown. Tan head. Milk chocolate nose.  Quite particular. Taste is of sweet alcohol. Nice texture. Roasty raisin hit. Difficult to drink at first but increasingly palateable as it went on.
From bottle. Strange aroma, some chocolate, cream, metallic, can’t pit my finger on it. Taste has licorice, chocolate and something else. Smooth creamy texture with a bitter finish. Didn’t like this
330 ml bottle from gormelys centre dear enough at 2.50. nice stuff tho and good carbonation I prefer it to the regular Guinness. now where can I get large amounts cheap hmmm.

1 pint 6 oz bottle from Fred Meyer, N.Salem. $4.59
Very black body as far as i can tell with a nice frothy thick tan head..creamy in consistency.
Wonderful roasty,toasted malt aromas..dark coffee, figs, chocolate..nice
LOvelly dark toasty malt taste..semi bitter coffee..and creamy chocolate.Dark fruit after taste. 
Fantastic mouthfeel..cannot fault it..very slick yet not boring.
Overall a very nice stout indeed..will buy more.

Bottle. Black body. Big, frothy beige head. Sweet aroma with notes of roasted malts, charred wood, chocolate, vanilla. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. Taste of smoke and char alongside hints of molasses and licorice. Bitterness lingers. A little too much burnt taste.

Bottle from Csakajósör. Poured black, with a firm, creamy beige head. Caramel, licorice, molasses in the nose. Honey, molasses sweet start with pleasant hoppy taste, which finishes with an erthy, ashy lasting bitterness. Very nice one.

Jet black pour with a khaki head.  Lots of chocolate and roast in the nose.  Not dissimilar to the Guinness Draught, but this one packs a bit more of a punch.  More roasty and you can tell the alcohol is present in this one.  Very good overall, would buy again.

APPEARANCE: Black tar, big thick classic head and lacing; AROMA: molasses and tar and coffee, toasted wheat and a hint of fruit and chocolate; TASTE: sweet-ish and bitter; PALATE: big body, creamy, long finish; OVERALL: Pretty solid, prefer the draft in Dublin though.

From notes: from bottle, pours teh familiar black, but the head was thicker and darker tan, with less of the famed "cascade".  Aroma is chocolate with roasty notes and a touch of bright citrus in the background.  As compared to "regular" Guinness, the body is a touch thicker and heavier.  Flavor was mostly roasty, but deeper and darker than the "regular".  Very slight but bright note of citrusy hops in the finish.  Liked this a lot.

0,33l bottle form Csakajósör, Budapest. Beautiful black nontransparent stout with medium brown head, witch disappears quickly. Chocolate, coffee and caramel aroma with some yeasty cheese and butter. Spicy hops also appears. Medium bitter, dry taste with some hiding sweetness. Full body with creamy oily texture and lively carbonation. Long bitter-sweet finish, a bit like coffee. As it get warmer, I can feel the sweetness more intensively. The taste become richer, and more delicious. It’s a very nice spicy stout, a real classic from Guinness. I recommend to drink it not too cold, so you can feel the real taste.

Nagyon-nagyon mély sötétbarna színű főzet, enyhe rubinvörös beütéssel, tetején egy krémes barna habbal, amely vastagon kicsipkézi a poharat ill. ujjnyi vastagon megmarad.
Illata édes-savanykás.
Száraz jellegű, karamell maláta alapú aromáját étcsokoládés és aszalt gyümölcsös ízek uralják , enyhe alkoholos aláfestéssel, testessége sűrű, szirupos és kissé ragadós.
Befejezése hosszan tartó és száraz, édesgyökérrel és melengetően likőrös jegyekkel, amely egy enyhén füstös utóízt hagy maga után.
Élvezetes, remek ser.
The strong stout smell is a foreshadowing of flavor that is just as strong.

British Store, Budapest. Színe tökéletesen fekete, és igen komoly, krémes világosbarna habot fejleszt, ami lassan apad, és egy vékony folt erejééig végig kitart. Illata egészen vörösboros, sőt kissé likőrös is, tanninos, fás, alkoholos és gyümölcsös, édeskés is egyben, eléggé markáns. Íze kezdetben kissé csípős, és szintén érezni a tanninos, fás és gyümölcsös vörösboros jelleget, amely mellett kávés és pörkölt malátás, na meg komlós, klasszikusabb stout-ismertetők is felvonulnak. Egészen testes, alig szénsavas és jó száraz stout. Ugyan nem az én világom, egy üveg számomra bőven elég (a vörösboros, tanninos jelleg hamar eltelít), de egy igazán jó, különleges sörről van szó.
From a bottle poured a black color with a fair amount of head.  Strong toasted malty flavor with a lingering finish.

Very strong aroma that I found to be pleasing, it is lively almost fizzy on the palate. It has a nice full flavor the hops are perfectly balanced so the flavor is tangy with a kick but does not linger. The finish is soft almost sweet.

12 oz bottle

Aroma: fruity, coffee, roasted malts, slight sour note

Taste: roasted malts, coffee, yeast fruitiness

A very enjoyable beer. Glad I had this one.

This is what Guiness should taste like. None of that watery riduculosly frothy draught stuff here. This is black as the ace of spades and has a resonable head. It smells and tastes like coffee! One of these from time to time is "good for you"!!
Black color/ lasting tan head. Black licorice, dark fruit, tobacco aromas. Rich, smooth mouthfeel. Black licorice flavors with astringent tobacco juice, dark fruits--

Pours nicely, but not nearly as creamy as the regular stuff. head is slightly more dissipated.  Smells of roasted barley, english hops, light caramel.  Taste is drier than regular Guinness and flavors are more pronounced.  Does not seem as well made however.  More lively and a lot less sweet than the original.  More of the roasted porter flavor that I am not so much a fan of.  I can see why Guinness has a cult following, this one, I wanted to like more.  Other stouts available like Bell’s and Left hand are better.  I am going to be prejudiced here and say, what else would you expect from Africa and the Caribbean?  Here’s to the original!  Drinkability 3.5/5

Csak a jó sör, Budapest.
Teljesen átláthatatlan, mélyfekete színe van, habja vékony, krémes, világosbarna és kitartó. Illata likőrös, kissé édeskés, aszalt gyümölcsös és medvecukros. Ízében is hozza ezeket a jegyeket, amikhez társul, fekete csoki, kávébab, szilvalekvár, gyógyfüvek, egy adag pörkölt maláta és finom komló is. Olajos, nehéz teste van és nem túl buborékos. Utóíze keserédes, bocskorszíjas, gyógyfüves és kissé száraz. Ahhoz képest, hogy milyen magas az alkoholtartalma, nem túl édes és erős. Finom.
4-pack of this stuff, product of Ireland. This is the stout that deserves the reputation that Guinness has. Rich, roasty, slightly bitter.  Flavorful.

From a metric 12 oz bottle into a coffee cup.  Pours with some thick damn head!  It never goes away and leaves tons of frothy lacing.  Aroma of sharp cheese, coffee and wood.  Mouthfeel is moderate to light and crisp like the regular Guinness.  A bit too much carbonation but not a big deal.  Taste is pretty sour with the usual coffee, molasses and bark.  ABV was totally hidden.  Overall, I was expecting something better.  I would drink it again, I just wouldn’t buy it.

A: Black body with an inch or so of khaki head. Not quite as creamy looking as Guinness Draft, but nice looking with a healthy coating of lacing.

S: Milk chocolate, roasted malt, and quite a bit of that classic Guinness scent.

T: Like the nose, a healthy blast of milk chocolate, roasted malts, a bit of caramel, and a hint of smoke. Very much like some higher ABV milk stouts.

M: Medium to full bodied. Upper end of effervescence for a stout. Like bitterness in the finish.

O: A nice brew... I can see why it got quite a bit of attention prior to arriving in the US. Can’t say its a great stout, but I enjoyed it.
almost black color with light brown head. roasted malt and little chocolate with a very thin coffee in the aroma and in the flavor too but for me it’s a little bit thin body. good one

0,33 l bottle, Csakajosor.

Black as a deep cave, beige creamy head that melt down slowly to a small lacing one. Aroma of caramel, some licorice, molasses, coffee, toffee, plum. Oily body, espresso coffee, caramel, molasses, roasted barley. Nice!

Sample at KC Beerfest 10-22.  Comes black with a nice tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate and malt.  Taste is malt, coffee, molasses, dark fruit and chocolate.  Some hops come through.  Smooth and creamy.  Very good.

Black. Off-white head with staying power. Plenty of lacing left behind. Big roasted barley aroma with hints of coffee and chocolate. Creamy coffee flavor. Creamy mouthfeel. Milky smooth. The epitome of what a stout should be. Way better than the other offerings.

11.2oz bottle from Pick’s poured into a snifter. Pours black with about 2 fingers of dark tan head. Aroma of sweet chocolate, toffee, light coffee and tootsie roll candy. Taste is lightly bitter with a good bit of chocolate candy sweetness. Nice hop flavor there too.  Medium bodied with a thick, almost chewy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. I’m glad I bought the 4pack for 9 bucks, because I’m going to enjoy every one of them.

Am I right in thinking "original" Guinness is not as well hopped as it was in the 80s? This beer reminds me of when Guinness had more flavour and less fizz, Deep, dark malty sweetness and dark chocolate with dark treacle flavours. Lovely bitterness & a silky mouth feel. The initial nose gives the impression of a fairly high abv,, perhaps more than it actually has (7.5%).

330ml bottle.  Rich and complex aroma of dark chocolate, deeply roasted malt, faint coffee, smoke, lightly burnt, sugary sweetness, black bread, earthiness and cream along with a tinge of dark, raisin-like fruit in the background.  Impenetrable black color with a lasting, foamy, light tan head.  Flavor is a satisfying blend of roasty, grainy bitterness, dark, sugary sweetness, wood, earthy hop, dark chocolate, cocoa and toffee, finishing dry, roasty and with a latent hint of dark, dried fruit that lingers.  Smoothly effervescent and somewhat sharp on the palate, substantial and coasting, with a fairly full body.  This product is pretty new to the area, and I certainly hope it sticks around for a little while.

Good thick head and a dark almost black appearance. Starts out with some great roast aromas with a light hint of chocolate and toffee notes. Flavors include the same but with a slight added root beer flavor as well. Very good dark sugar flavors and very complex. Leaves a slight malty lingering bitterness.

Aroma was pleasant and the appearance of a guinness is always appealing. I found the taste to be too sweet. Even what I felt was extra hopping it did not balance it too well. Sharp on the palate. Overall this wasn’t offensive, I just prefer a subtler stout or a dry stout.
Pours dark, opaque with small beaded beige head.  Aroma is sweet roasted malts.  Taste is sharp roasted malts with nice sweetness on the finish.  The best offering I’ve had from Guinness.

Would be the best beer I have ever tried, but luckily for me, I tried Avery Mephistopheles Stout the same day!  The coffee bitterness, sourness, and maltyness that you would expect from Guinness Extra Stout only better (not to mention the higher ABV!)

It’s really great when you can take a classic and make some improvements on it (except for the butterscotch thing which I just can’t abide). Poured with a mammoth, thick, foamy, frothy, fluffy, billowy, light tan head that lasts forever and lots of clingy lace. Color is an opaque black brown. Aroma is a complex array of roast, malt, acid, butterscotch, masculine scents. Flavor is similar to nose with very little sweetness; bitterness and tang dominate with some butterscotch, malt, roast, barest hint of toffee and sweetness. Man, this is dry irish stout! Body is perfect and so is carbonation for the style. Finish is like flavor and some coffee and cocoa show up - fairly long. An alternate to a world classic for the far flungs markets of Diageo.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Good - expected deep black colour with minimal head. Roasty aromas, nice bitterness on finish, wears alcohol level well. Better than the standard Guinness, but a style that the micros will make so much more interesting.

330ml bottle.  $8.95 for a four pack at the navy exchange.    A mite expensive, but ultimately worth it.    Almost candy-like aroma of dark malt, coffee, and chocolate.   Body is smooth and thick, and chewy in the mouth.   Flavors of dark malt, coffee, sweet dark chocolate, toffee.  excellent alcohol wallop that you can’t taste at all.  The bitterness is offset by more sweetness than in the regular extra stout.  In fact, this is what the regular extra stout should have been all along.   Quite excellent to drink, enough complexity to keep your attention, but an easy drinker, and yummy in flavor.   If I ever catch this on sale I’ll fill my garage.

This was a remarkable little brew. I thought the garish abv might not be carried over well, but in the Irish tradition, they manage the balance between flavor, body and alcohol exceedingly well. As ever I don’t like to bore readers with the traditionally drab way of reviewing a beer, so I’ll lay it out as ever; The appearance of both the bottle and the brew when poured is uber cool. You don’t come across many brews that look so badass without trying hard. The smells were ecstatic, there was a BIG toffee note, followed by coffee bitterness and those roasted bitters. Taste might not be so toffee like, but is more on the traditional coffee side of things, but with definite chocolaty notes, like a heavy chocolate milk, there was a hint of a fruit, like a really sugarless raisin, that’s just sweet enough to notice. The astounding thing, though, is how phenomenally well the abv is carried, in smell and taste. It’s definitely there, but piggy backs effortlessly on the backs of those bitter notes, and carries better than say, an Innis and Gunn. I don’t believe in giving anything perfection, but this is close enough. Slainte!
Bottle - Black (reddish edges in light) Tan head. Full bodied. Roasted malts. The usual black chocolate and licorice.  Quite a sharp bitterness. OK but there are so many better stouts.

Bottle.Pours black with a big creamy off-white head.Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, butterscotch and molasses.Flavor is sweet and roasted with some licorice, warmth and wet cardboard.Medium body, average carbonation.Nice but a little stale

pours very dark brown, almost black, with a nice medium dark beige head, good retention and lacing. nose is chocolate, roasted oak and big hops, light booze. taste is bittersweet chocolate, very nice roasted profile, complex - woodiness. sweetness is greatly balanced by big english hops. lively than soft, medium to full body, long lingering pungent finish.

Probably exactly what you would expect, a sort of concentrated Guiness. Had this shortly after "Profanity" stout, and while the "Profanity" is more complex. this has a slightly less challenging roasty, biscuitiness to enjoy.

This brew poured up a jet-black colored body with an insanely huge mocha-colored bubbly head with amazing retention and lacing. Aromas of rum, slow roasted robust coffee beans, and toasted malts. Flavors of the same but filled with good hits of the citrusy hops and then mellowed out with the sweet malts. Medium-bodied with a very dry finish with lingering notes of hazelnut. For me this brew seemed a little “thin” for a stout but still a good brew nonetheless. Would pair up nicely with some of my decadent burgers!

Ar: Molasses and some cherry, sharp burnt notes with some fruitiness. 
Ap: Pretty close to black - opaque even up to the light, though some ruby highlights on the edges - light mocha colored head with wonderful retention and a thick wall of lacing.
T: Dry, roasty, and slightly acidic up front - not sweet - bitterness is firm, and mixes with dry roastiness to really dry this out on the finish - there is a very deep burnt quality, slightly metallic. 
P: Oily body with medium carbonation - really dries out on the finish.
O: A stout-drinker’s stout - I really like it - this beer has great depth, but its roasted flavors are very pronounced, so watch out if you aren’t a stout lover.

Pours black with beige/brown head. Nose is roasted malt, dark fruit (which surprises me), and a lactic milky chocolate aroma. And yes there is a bit of barbeque in there, smoky. Interesting. Taste is roasted malt, smoky, barbeque sauce, bit of dark fruit (prune) and chocolate, coffee and some hop bitterness on the finish. Didn’t expect a Guinness to be this interesting on the palate. Surpassed now by so many imperial and foreign stouts, but this is a pretty good original.

Hm I was pleasantly suprised by this excellent brew. Pours pitch black with a nice big fluffy tan head that leaves quite a bit of lacing. Aromas of coffee and dark chocoalte. Flavors of bitter roasted dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee and dark fruit. Mouthfeel was maybe just a bit too thin but oily with a bittersweet finish. Definitely Guinness’ best beer.

Bottle. Pours black with a couple of inches of oatmeal foam. Not much on the nose. A bit of maltiness on the tongue. A rather subdued hoppiness on the finish. All things being equal I prefer a jar of Guinness stout at my local.

A: The pour is almost black in color with a finger of dense khaki head.

S: First thought that comes to mind is barbecue.  Smells like roast and fire.  However, there’s an odd buttery quality to it.  Sweet malt and graham cracker follow these strange aromas.  A lot of dark fruits, especially prunes.

T: Very heavy on the roasted malts, almost smokey in flavor.  Somewhat bitter as a result of this.  Only a light sweetness to this one and not really much of the dark fruit that was present in the aroma.

M: Medium bodied with medium carbonation.

O: Not sure what all the commotion was about with this.  I didn’t like this at all.

solid black pour with a big tan head which lingered, loads of lacing .  aroma is slightly sweet. loads of chocolate and a dash of alcohol. taste has some roasted beef in there! along with a good mix of chocolate, malt and hops.
infinitely better than standard Guinness.

(bottle at Jack Quinns 12/17/10). Black color. Medium tan head. Aroma and flavor of moderate sweet malt and light roasted malt and light hops. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Bottle from Asda, Elgin....Black with mostly diminishing frothy light brown head. Fair lacing.

Aroma of roasted malt, toasted bread, bit of wood and alcohol.

Flavour of toasted malt, dark bread, chocolate, molasses, dark toffee, liquorice, hint of wood, slight port with some alcohol. Moderate sweetness and bitterness. Fairly complex.

Medium to full body, soft carb, syrupy mouthfeel. Roast malt finish warming and dry.

Different drink to standard Guinness. Flavours are more concentrated and richer. Comes close to an imperial stout, but with a bit less flavour and body. I like this.

Pours like a stout, completely black, with an off white head. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolates, some oak, and some nice hop character. Taste is exactly how it smells, with the hops really coming through in the back end. Slightly watery finish but the bitterness still lingers on. Tastes like a bulked up version of the their standard stout, duh. I like this, alcohol is masked very well, and it represents everything a stout should be. Solid.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Almost pure black with nice tan colored head and some lacing.

Aroma: Sweet molasses, caramel, licorice, smoke and cream. The roasted notes are lighter than expected - just a touch of chocolate and coffee.

Taste: More smoky, roasted (coffee and chocolate) and dry than the aroma indicated. Some just barely sweet molasses, licorice and caramel are noticeable before a fairly bitter hop and roasted bite at the finish.

Palate: Moderate carbonation with a somewhat full creamy body and a very dry finish.

Overall: Now this is a Guinness! Best Foreign/Export Stout I have had.

A thick, brown, pillowy head with a rich, dark liquid.  The aroma is faint but consisting mostly of the roasted barley.  The flavor is dominated by the roasted barley with a little bit of hop bitterness.  The nitrogen makes for a smooth and interesting palate.  One of my favorite Guinness products.

Bottle 33 cL. Pours opaque black with thick brown head. Aroma is faint with notes of caramel, malt, coffee and chocolate. Alcohol is also present. Taste is filling with heavy bitterness but also some light caramel sweetness. Palate is smooth, velvety with medium carbonation. Finish is caramel and licorice. An absolute favorite stout.

Found this hiding in a small local beer store. Not sure how it got there. Poured black as ink with a big tan head.  Nose of chocolate, roasted malts, and cherries. Bold body and a smooth creamy mouthfeel. The flavor is very rich and loaded with good tastes, with chocolate dominating. The finish is nicely bitter. Far and a way the best of  the Guinness brews.

Guinness Foreign Extra has an extremely thick, creamy, beige head and an opaque, dark brown appearance. The aroma is of dark chocolate, dark-roasted barley malt, clean water, dark chocolate, and cherries. The taste is the same, but with some licorice, milk, and pretty strong hop bitterness at the back end of the sip. The alcohol taste doesn’t really show up much here. Mouthfeel is thick and heavy, and Guinness Foreign Extra Stout finishes rich, velvety, and heavy. This would go great with vanilla ice cream as a float. Overall, this is an outstanding beer. If it has any flaws, I’m not aware of them. I rate this super high. RJT
dark brown black coloured body with a off white head a roasted malty herby hoppy aroma a herby roasted hoppy malty fruity bitter taste with a spicy little alcholic bitter finish

Pours a dark Black with tan head. Very bitter very roasty. Good level of carbonation. Creamy Coffee, toffee , bitter hops. Extremely well balanced, its just a well put together beer. Pretty good stuff, but in the price range there is much that beats it. I will have to try extra Stout again to remember how it compares.

Nice stout from guys who normally pervert the style to no end.  Pours pretty, growing black in the glass with a lengthy, mustache-inducing tan head.  Tastes of coffee and blackened malt, mild dark chocolate sweetness, with a navigable bitterness that gives the brew a needed dry finish.  The alcohol is a tad heavy but not annoying.  Always heard this bottle is the "good" Guinness-- I’m willing to agree.
While I personally prefer the Draught, this is still a very nice beer.  Honestly haven’t had it in a little while as I’ve been focusing on domestic crafts, but still a phenomenal beer.

330ml bottle. Pours a black colour with a pillowy tan head. Aroma of dark malts, coffee, chocolate and a little oak. Flavours of espresso coffee, dark malts, some chocolate and caramel. Mouth-feel is rich and thick. Nicely bitter with moderate carbonation and a little CO2 prickle. Long roasty, espresso finish. A very enjoyable beer. Espresso coffee bean after-taste also. I forgot about this one to be honest.

Bottle. Pours black, thick and opaque, with a frothy, lasting and beautfil brown head. Roasted aroma with notes of burned malt, toasted bread and vanilla-sugar.Opulent sweet and bitter in the mouth, a little plummy with vague notes of oak. Quite sticky texture - after this you need to clear your palate with a straight, hoppy and refreshing beer.
Molto probabilmente il miglior prodotto della famosa fabbrica di Dublino, bella di colore, d’aroma e soprattutto corposa e non stancante...

Shared 33 cl bottle brewed by Guinness Cameroon. Bought it at African House in Copenhagen (across the street from Mikkeller Bar). Fingerthick, creamy brown head on a clear, deep mahogany body verging on black. Caramel, maple syrup aroma. Sweet, acidic and burnt bitter. Medium body. Flavors leave the mouth quickly leaving only a long mild bitterness. Not a very good drink.

Toasty, rich, and verbose in its bitterness, this Guinness offering puts the hammer to your tongue with big, buttery chocolate notes and hints of velvety cappuccino. Definitely more earthy than I expected. This extra stout also has an aromatic bakery quality to its nose. Practically sublime.

12oz bottle. Perfect amount of tan head, filling the entire bulb-glass. Loose, sheety lacing. Very bitter. Smoky, oaky, a bit warm. Carbonation, a bit thick, but good texture and aftertaste. Satisfying stout.

Pours dense black with a tall, chunky tan head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing, looks great, beginning to end. Aroma is sweet syrupy molasses, dark fruit, roast, nut skins, vanilla and odd hints of spice.
