Flavor is more sweet molasses (I like molasses, but I could see many people not liking it so strongly represented in a beer), roast (a little bitter on the roastiness), dark fruit, burnt toffee, espresso, burnt oats, and planty, woody hops. Finishes with planty bitter hops and a lingering sweetness, almost like ti has stevia in it or something. Palate is medium bodied, creamy and a little slick on entry , moderately carbonated and finishes a little slick with a lightly chalky feel. Tasty, the first couple of sips seemed better than the last, a beautiful beer if nothing else.

Pours a deep ruby nearly black with a pillowy tan head. The Aroma and taste are bitter chocolate and coffee with a little dark fruit and licorice, way better than the overhyped crap we get. It’s so much thicker and creamier than regular Guinness, this is more of a sipper but it’s quite smooth. Why can’t I get this on tap instead of the mediocre Guinness Draught?

When Americans think of Guinness they almost always associate it with their flagship Draught Stout (you know, the one that’s nitrogenated with a pure cream-like head and cascading bubbles?). But did you know the Foreign Extra Stout is actually the highest-selling version globally? Why it’s never been sold in the United States until recently is something of a mystery. This is a stronger version of traditional Guinness to be sure, but those expecting major differences or more complexity might be a little disappointed. It’s a good beer, but nothing more than that.

I poured a 12oz bottle into an Irish tulip stout glass.

Appearance: Just like regular Guinness, this beer is pitch black and just a hint of ruby red shows when held up to the light. It forms a huge, dark tan, sponge-like head that lasts seemingly forever and laces the glass well.

Smell: A generic stout aroma for lack of a better description. There’s a slight oaty quality and some roasted malt with a touch of black licorice, but that’s about it.

Taste: Much like the appearance and aroma, the beer tastes like a generic, conservative stout - only a little stronger. The first half is quite mild with some sweetness and a dairy-like flavor commonly found in milk and oatmeal stouts (although this is an Irish Dry Stout). The second half kicks the palate with dark-roasted malt akin to the robustness of a French roast coffee. Guinness FES is also noticeably more bitter then regular Guinness and dries out the palate faster too. 

My only beef with this beer is that it doesn’t offer anything original. No chocolate or coffee flavors, just a hint of black licorice in the aftertaste. 

Mouthfeel: Despite the higher potency and robustness, I was surprised the beer was on the lower end of medium-bodied. Low carbonation and a soft, gentle texture on the tongue.

Drinkability: Almost as good as regular Guinness as it slides across the palate like water. There’s a dry aftertaste which gets a little annoying, but is easily tolerable. The 7.5% ABV seems high as the beer drinks and feels like something more in the sessionable range.

Overall, this is a good beer but nothing particularly special. There are many other options for stouts with the same potency, higher complexity and similar price range. Still, I’d take it over Guinness Draught Stout any day, and you should too.

Rather upset that this isn’t easily found in the states... Had my first one in the Caribbean (of all places I know..), and I was very surprised.  This one puts the normal draught we are accustomed to here to shame.  Slightly thicker than Guinness draught, yet loaded with hints of espresso, chocolate, and a nice charred taste that leaves a sweet, smokey aftertaste.  Almost no carbonation, except for the small mocha-colored head that formed.

Another great beer from Guinness.  Pours dark brown/black with ruby red hues and a medium sized mocha colored head.  Aroma of unsweetened chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor has a slight bitterness with a deep rich, chocolate and some coffee character.  Look forward to trying this one again.

Bottle. Cameroon edition. It pours a clear-looking almost black body with a dense, light beige head leaving lacings. The aroma is very buttery, with a good dash of heavily roasted malts and chocolate. The flavor isn’t much more interesting, quite butterscotchy like the aroma. Some hints of wet cardboard, and a good dash of licorice. Roasted, quite bitter finish. A quite decent one, but at the same time a big disappointment. 110708

Bottle.Pours black with a big creamy off-white head.Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, butterscotch and molasses.Flavor is sweet and roasted with some licorice, warmth and wet cardboard.Medium body, average carbonation.Nice but a little stale .

Bottle 330ml @ Geokkjer

Pours black with a light tan head. Aroma has notes of licorice, roasted malt, butterscotch. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Wieder so ein mythisches Bier. 
Im Vergleich zum Extra Stout ist das Foreign ein Spur säuerlicher, von walchoderartiger Fruchtigkeit. 
Meine Version hatte 8% Alkohol, die jedoch erst im Abgang minimal zu Tage traten. 
Ein Spitzenbier!Test vom 5.12.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche

330ml bottle. Pours thick and black like oil and holds a firm head of deep thick latte coloured foam. Dark bitter chocolate in the nose with some sweet maltiness underneath. Very weighty in the glass witha chewy roast malt that clings to the inside of your mouth.
Definitely an upgrade over the regular American extra stout.  Sweeter, less bitter, a little bit tart I daresay.  Generally more complex.  Not amazing but not bad at all.

11.2 oz. pours black with a small white head looks nice. Smells like coffee with vanilla maybe some chocolate. Taste: coffee, cream a little caramel sweetness. A thin mouthfeel with a long bitter finish. A good beer but I prefer American stouts.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with a medium off white head. Huge nose of smoke and dark fruit. Sharp carbonation and roast bitter on taste. Quite good.
Bottle 33cl. Pours a dark brown clear filtered brew with huge brown head. Roasted malts, raisins, nuts behind a smooth alcoholic burning. Good brew!
Almost black with a brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate and vanilla. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted bitter finish. 280406

Pours a nice pitch-opaque with luscious light caramel/brownish/dark tan head, about a fist thick. NIIICCCEEE. Thick, bubbly and creamy, very nice retention. Good sticky lines of lacing.

Good dose of toasted grains/barley, and alcohol. Very noticeable grainy alcohol presence, almost sulfur-like. Mmmm...

Pleasant mouthful of toasted grainy barley, alky presence and very nice hop bite. Smooth, silky sweet yet bittered with a nice hop kick, which is a big plus. The rubbing alcoholish alcohol presence is noticeable here as well. Pretty solid medium to slightly thick body, with fairly high carbonation. Very good.

By far the best Guinness of any style/kind I’ve had. The hop bite due to the extra hops used is an added welcome and big plus. I’m so glad it finally made it here in my area, hopefully it stays and can get more. This is what the other Guinness brews should be.

12 oz. bottle in a shaker.  Opaque black pour with small tan head.  Rich roasted nutty aroma with hints of coffee and cocoa.  Much more flavorful and aromatic than it’s draught version.  Probably couldn’t enjoy as many of these as the regular, but this one is definitely better all around.  Would likely not appeal to the masses as well though.

Roasted malts, coffee, toffee aromas.  Taste is the same with a subtle sweetness coming through  Great pour as Guinness ought to be.  Smooth and medium to full bodied with a burnt finish.  My go-to-Guinness product now that it is available in my area.

12oz bottle. Pours thick, black, fullbodied. In true Guinness form, a tan creamy head caps this beer, and fine lacing in the glass to the end. Very firm hop bitterness for a stout, but complements the strength and sweetness nicely. Dark roasted graininess, chocolate and coffee overtones. Has a minerality reminicsant of an oyster stout. Would pair nicely with steak, oysters, lamb, or maybe even some spicy thai food. A very good example of what a foriegn extra stout should be.

Bottle.  Near black pour with a large, creamy tan head.  Chocolate and roasted malt aroma.  Great flavors.  Milk chocolate, vanilla, deep roasted malts, and a hint of ripe fruit are all here.  Slight alcohol presence in the finish.  Creamy texture and well carbonated.  Would definitely buy this one again.
Dark brown with a big brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Taste is pretty bitter and very malty, medium body, thick feel, soft carbonation, bitter finish.

THOUGHTS: I wanted to try this for a long time. Glad to see it back in the U.S. Not quite what I was hoping for, though. I’ve had way better foreign stouts, but this was way better than regular Guinness and even better than the Extra Stout. A little more bitter than I like a foreign stout to be. If I pretend that styles don’t exist, it’s a pretty nice beer.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was looked nearly opaque black in the glass with a large, tan head that mostly diminished, but left excellent lacing. The aroma had moderate grain, roasted and burnt malts along with dark chocolate and cocoa; light to moderate herbal and earthy hops; light Guinness yeast; slight alcohol; slight dark fruit; and last but not least hot cocoa mix. The initial flavor was lightly sweet, slightly bitter and lightly acidic; while the finish was light to moderately sweet, rather bitter and moderately acidic with an average to long duration. There was roasted malt, chocolate syrup, cocoa powder, coffee grounds, hot cocoa mix, a little dark fruit, dark chocolate, burnt malt, metallic and herbal hops and Guinness. The medium body was sort of oily but also a little sticky on the lips with fairly soft yet lightly tingly carbonation and a lightly astringent and slightly chalky finish.

Excellent!!  Bottle at Patrick’s Pub in Crescent, PA.  Dark black body with a light brown thick foaming head. Aroma of caramel and coffee  Probably not as smooth as the Draught version.  However, I believe it is more flavorful and less dry.  As a foreign stout, the bitter flavor comes at the finish, but doesn’t linger.

Not as good as a regular Guinness due to a slight sweetness in flavor.  Not all bad though.  This has an interesting banana smell, but overall this is a very satisfying alternative to a plain old Guinness.

Pours from the 11.2 oz bottle an extremely dark brown (almost black) color with a giant, thick, foamy tan head that conjures up images of a root beer float.  Can only guess at the carbonation level at this point, since there’s no seeing through the darkness.  Aroma is of dark unsweetened chocolate & black coffee, but it’s surprisingly and somewhat disappointingly faint.  1st sip brings a smooth, creamy gift of the aforementioned chocolate and coffee, with a dose of heavily roasted (almost "burnt") malt.  there’s also a hint of smokiness with a heavy dose of hops bitterness on the back end that lingers on the swallow.  Mouthfeel is smooth and robust without being overly heavy.  Overall, a beer that is well worthy of its legendary status.

I had this while on St. Martin during the Disney Cruise with the family.  This was a pleasant surprise after drinking some pretty mediocre beers in the islands.  Taste is similar to Guinness but with a bit more bitterness and maybe more chocolate than the original.  I wish I would have poured this into a glass, but I was on the beach and wasn’t able to fully capture the nose and appearance of this one from the bottle.

Whoever said that this has what the Extra Stout lacks (a nicer, thicker palate) hit the nail on the head. This beer packs a hell of a punch. It is very bitter and you can also sense the coffee, chocolate, and a smokey, woody touch that added to the general aggressiveness of this beer. It is somewhat carbonated, somewhat dry, and a texture that definitely separates it from its lesser siblings. I should add that I could tell it was of a relatively high ABV before even knowing that it exactly was. I have honestly had beers with a higher alcohol content that did a better job at concealing it. 

This is a great beer, and if you haven’t had anything this strong before, you’re in for a treat.

Very dark with that Guinness brown.  A thick creamy tan head that slowly fades leaving thick lace.  A pleasant sweet dark fruit, rich malt, and anise aroma.  The flavor is similar but with some hops that add bitterness and liveliness.  There is a bit of chocolate, too.  This is an excellent beer and much tastier that their standard draft.

Black with a tan head that is initially thumbs sized & bubbly before settling to half of that size. The retention is about average.

Gives off similar aroma to Guinness Draught but with a stronger smell of coffee and the roasted malts. It isn’t as pleasant a smell as the Draught variety it must be said, with the overpowering coffee smell not being to my liking.

A mixture of warm coffee and roasted malts & barley upfront with a long, lingering coffee aftertaste. Again similar to standard Guinness Draught but a lot stronger. You can also detect a taste of alcohol in the background.

Smooth and quite warm on the palate with little evidence of carbonation.

Quite a nice flavoursome beer but one that is far to strong for my liking, especially with the coffee, roasted barley & roasted malts. - - - - 

1001 Beers to Try Before You Die(abarwithnoname.wordpress.com)

Liked this more than I anticipated I would.  Nose is mostly coffee, roasted malt + a touch of caramel.  Big foamy head, gradually recedes and leaves a thick lacing pattern.  Taste is initially vanilla and cola, then dark chocolate, with a bitter dry gritty followup, with an oaky finish.  Really good, lots going on.
Pitch black body with a light brown head. Aroma of caramel and coffee. Very little carbonation, bittersweet flavour with brown sugar.

Bottle - poured onto a nice thin head. Forms light lacing at the end. Smells bitter, the usual Guinness coffee aroma, but with some spice added. Maybe that spice is the higher abv, but through tasting it you couldn’t tell. This beer provides what the Extra Stout was missing, some body to counter the sharp bitterness. It is rather balanced with some nice carbonation and bitterness, but the roasted malts and higher ABV provide a spicy, almost cinnamon like character to this particular brew. To be enjoyed in small batches, in numbers this could do some damage ;-).

Thanks to drabmuh for the bottle. Shared with family and tasted side-by-side with a can of the Draught. Served in a snifter.

Pours near black with a mocha head and some good lacing. Really good retention overall. The nose brings quite a bit of roast and chocolate with a hint of buttery diacetyl, though this never reaches an unappetizing level. The taste is more roast with a nice, dry coffee character. There is a touch of bitter dark chocolate in the background as well. Dry roast is what really sticks with me. Impressive in that this is fairly complex, though I’ll say that the feel did not really help the flavor, as the finish was too dry for my liking. It left me parched, which is a good goal for the brewer, I suppose.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-29-2010
Bottle. Black colour with large creamy brown fully lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate. Sweet flavor with notes of chocolate. Creamy palate.

The aroma has its positives and negatives. The positives are floral notes and a cherry jolly rancher. The negatives are simply dirty feet. Dark black in color with a bubbly tan head. The lacing is very awesome. Watery taste for a dark beer. Taste like cheap chocolate. There is a hint of cooked broccoli in the taste. It has an oily texture with a bitter finish. Overall i thought the extra stout was better.

Deep dark color with a large brownish tan head. Very roasty malty flavor with a hint of coffee and an earthiness. The alcohol strength is well hidden. Nice, though lacking in the creaminess of a Guinness draft.

Bottle courtesy of Kevin and Molly who each brought back bottles from Ireland.  Rating #644. Almost completely black, but there is a little light showing through throwing of a little dark red with a light brown head leaving a bit of lacing behind. Sweet malt aroma, like light molasses. Kind of thin, pretty big roasty flavor, but it was still a little watery. (1618)
Very dark pour with small tan head. Malty aroma with a bit of dark fruit. Taste is roasted burnt malt with a hoppy aftertaste.

Fully opaque black color with a big dark tan head.  Aroma is sweet burnt malt and licorice.  Taste is immediately bitter and sweet simultaneously.  Thedark roasted malts proide the bitter, yet  the sweetness of dried dark  fruits is there as well, along with hints of licorice and dark cocoa.  Quite similar in taste to the traditional extra stout, although a little more assertive and with a little higher ABV, of course.  It’s good, but nothing extraordinary.

Pours a deep dark brown with a creamy tan head. Has a very litle aroma, moslty roasted malt. It has much more flavor that regular Guinness, more hoppy and more alcohol. Aside from that thick creamy head from the classic Guinness this is a much better beer.

Guinness & Company--St. James Gate Dublin--Guinness Foreign Extra--Genuine Quality Stout--2010 11.2 oz. Bottle.  7.50% ABV.  65 IBU’s.  (2.25 / 5.0)  Big dense lacy rocky rich espresso 3/4" lasting head.  Black pour & opaque obsidian jet black color .Sweet roasted dark fruit fig plum raisin mild hop front.  Roasted crusty slightly creamy sweet burnt dark fruit toffee body.  Sweet mild bitter hop hot hint end.  Sampled 3/17/2011.  Purchased 4-Pack for $8.99 at Fred Meyer--Ballard, Seattle on 11/9/2010.

11.2 oz. bottle- Pours brown to black with red highlights when held up to the light, the head is frothy and tan, lacework is very good. The aroma is chocolate malt, very faint and light. The flavor is rich and complex, the first word that came to mind was wow, that was good. It has chocolatey flavors and dark roasted malts dominate, mild bitterness in the back of the tongue, especially after the swallow. There is a alcohol burn as well, but is not overbearing. The body is medium to full, carbonation is medium as well, overall a full flavored stout, and is the best guinness I have ever had.

Appearance: black with burnt browns along the edge. Tan woody head fades bubbly and moussey. Swirls with bubbly lace. Dark.


Nose: burnt and roasty. Espresso, black bakers chocolate, pure cacao, burnt woods – charred black and crackling. Whole black cherries with skins and stones. Black roots, black earth, and dark stone fruits – prunes. Vanilla bean cream in the back, subtle and supple.


Palate: full medium-bodied mouthfeel, lightly froth with a burnt butter finish of ash, charcoal, cherry pits and cherry skins. Black root and black licorice root followed by vanilla bean and burnt cream. Tingly tart black fruits on the back top of tongue with a slight tannic character. Ashy finish – white hot charcoal.


Final Thoughts: easily the best Guinness readily available in the USofA right now. I’d happily drink the Foreign Extra any day, any time.
I was OK with this one.  Tastes like a flat Guinness draught with sugar added to it.  High points - very smooth drinking for a beer > 7% abv.

Poured pitch black with a tan head, a bit rocky with spotty lace.  Aroma is a mysterious hodgepodge.  I’m getting some molasses, tar, acidic chocolate, and maybe a touch of tobacco.  Flavor is a bit more simple, but its a good thing.  Taste is smoked malt with a bit of tobacco, oak, and light burnt chocolate notes.  End is bittersweet with recognizable Guinness wet peat flavor.  An extreme Guinness, tastes all of its 7.5% and I appreciate the boldness both in alc. and flavor from a mega brewer. Not too shabby in of itself, either.  Not the best $2.50 for a 12oz, but a surprisingly good stout either way.

600 ml bottle, from a corner shop in London. ABV is 7.5%. Black colour, moderate tan head. Moderate roasty aroma, hints of tar, coffee and cigar box, also a touch of burnt rubber. Roasty flavour, notes of coffee, a certain acidity. Hoppy and roasty bitterness in the finish. Later note: Also sampled the version brewed in Cameroon (shared by abemorsten), which is not listed as a separate beer (same name and ABV, no special grains mentioned as ingredients). To me the aroma seemed more sweetish with notes of caramel, and the flavour was also somewhat sweeter than the Irish-brewed version.
Pours black with typical tan head. Aroma is roasty malt and chocolate. What differentiates this is the slight alcohol aroma and a bit of hoppy bitterness toward the finish.

Bottle from Grand Turk. Pours a very dark brown with a medium tan head that lasts awhile leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is roasted malt, oak, and alcohol. Medium mouthfeel with a bitter malt and chocolate with a nice lingering bitter finish. Alcohol present but not overpowering, really enjoyed this one.

12-oz. Pours a faded black with a dense and creamy tan head that really sticks around, leaving plenty of sheeting lace on the way down the sides of the glass. Mild chocolatey nose showing some lacto sourness. Creamy, chalky, fairly flat body with aluminum and lacto sour competing with chocolate and roast for the mid-palate. Chalky, milk-sour finish that lingers for, frankly, hours. Real potential here but falls into the old bad habits.

Definitely the best guniess Ive had. Malty yet flat. Has a dry finish that’s it as far as the hops go. Dark pour, tan head. The Head faded and left little rings spotting the surface of the beer. Kinda wierd...almost looked like instant mold, which it wasnt, just looked strange. Palate was horrible. Watery, no body really. But drinkable and overall tasty.

Bottle. Irish version. Notes are taken from a sample BJCP Scoresheet. The numbers in this rating reflect Ratebeer’s hedonistic scoring system and not my actual judging numbers. 

Aroma: Cocoa, tobacco, leather, vanilla, dry grainy character. Medium esters, slightly lactic quality. Roast, coffee, nearly a bit oily. Slight hint of diacetyl, some light alcohol heat. No hop presence (as usual). Light nutty notes and a touch sulfury. 

Appearance: Very large tan head that lasts and leaves extremely strong lacing. Bubbles are medium sized and spaced. Body is black with brown highlights. A very good looking beer. 

Flavor. Taste is slightly lactic throughout. Roasty and tobacco in the finish. Roast flavors are rich and complex ranging from oversteeped coffee to dry tobacco. No hop flavors. Medium to light esters in the mid palate (pear). Finishes a bit astringent and burnt from the roasted barley. 

Mouthfeel. Full bodied and creamy carbonation. Thick. Astringent, nearly acrid notes from a liberal use of roasted barley. Warmth is medium to light given the style.  Roasty duration is quite long. 

Overall impression: This was not tasted blind. If it were I’d question as to the possible start of an infection. Guinness is unique both on its own and within this style. I know it is a classic example, but it doesn’t even begin to scratch the surface of Foreign Extra (export) Stouts. Personally the combination of lactic notes and astringent/acrid roasted barley doesn’t appeal. On the other hand the thick and creamy mouthfeel is extremely pleasant. A different kind of beer.

This is the bet version of Guinness you are going to get in the U.S.  Pours pitch black with a full thick fluffy head. Laces well. Smells of heavy roasted malts, chocolate, espresso, and licorice. Tastes of sweet chocolate malts, bitter roasted coffee. The finish is long, bitter, and dry.
Has a bit of a milk stout aroma to it.  Lots of smokey taste followed by a little bit of grain.  Really smooth.  Not getting the hop bite that is on the label but it is good.

The best Guinness I’ve had to date.  I tried this for the first time last week. Has much stronger flavors/aroma that the draught and extra stout.  It is predominantly full of burnt roasted malts.  There’s even some dark fruit and slight tart as well. It leaves a dry moderately bitter finish.  Say what you want about being a victim of effective marketing... but this is an enjoyable stout with unique characteristics.   I already bought another pack.

I never would’ve thought I’d rate a Guinness this high but this was a great beer. Aroma was strong and full of caramel. Something I wasn’t expecting from such a dark beer. Smelled like a liquified caramel candy. Pour was a nice deep dark brown/near black with a rocky 2 finger tan head. Taste was delicious. Strong caramel backbone with a drying roasted malt flavor bittering the top of the mouth. Nice strong carbonation. I can say without a doubt I’ll buy more of this beer.

The best Guinness beer. Way more full than the classic Guinness stout, and with everlasting palate. The aroma is pretty much the same coffee-like-carbon aroma as is the foam. But you’ll definetely appreciate it if yoy want something more intense.

Dark brown basically black pour with tan foam on top.  Laces pretty well.  Aroma of chocolate, roast, light sour malt twinge.  Flavor is mildly bitter and dry, strong roast bite, light chocolate and coffee, some malty sweetness.  Nice that it actually has flavor.  Probably my favorite variation of guinness, although that doesn’t mean much.
IT is better than the watery drivel that is guinness, but not by too much. It has much more caramel sweetness.

Bottle from the Arden BevMo in Sacramento, CA. Can this be the old brew that had layers of grutch in the bottom of the bottle? Pours really black with a creamy/foamy 3 finger tan head. Aromas of oatmeal, burnt malt, and bread. Full bodied (due to creamy carbonation?). Flavor is really black dark burnt malt. It’s very astringent. It has some smoke, and there does seem to be oak - perhaps because of the astringency. Puts the non-foreign to shame. This is a really good drink.

black, light body with minimal head. slightly roasty body..dry..stone, grass and bitterness all over. flavor is earthy and dry. some semi-sweet biscuity malt..pretty lame and homebrew-esque..thin, thin, thin

11.2 oz. pours black with a small white head looks nice. Smells like coffee  with vanilla maybe some chocolate. Taste: coffee, cream a little caramel sweetness. A thin mouthfeel with a long bitter finish. A good beer but not great i would probably have it again.

Pours pitch black with a full thick fluffy head.  Smells of heavy roasted malts, chocolate, espresso, and licorice.  Tastes of sweet chocolate malts, bitter roasted coffee.  The finish is long, bitter, and dry.

Jet black with an enormous light brown head, nice thick film and lace that cascaded down the glass throughout. Aromas of burnt toast, roasted coffee, and hints of dark liquors. Modest citrus hops flavors followed quickly by much stronger coffee/bitter chocolate malts. In the background are suggestions of dark fruit and warming alcohol. Full bodied, minimal carbonation, thick mouthfeel, and a long finish of roast and toast. A quintessential stout.
It pours a pitch black color with a decent off white head. The aroma is roasted malts, nuts and coffee. Taste is roasted malts, nuts and coffee.

Pours deep black, though with slight ruby edges, topped with a firm tan head. The nose is sharp tobacco, dark roast coffee and a light touch of spice. Tastewise strong espresso coffee,, with an extra to go with it, the background is a smooth, silky chocolate. Firm bitter bite in the long dry finish. Lovely beer, why this isn’t the standard Guinness is beyond me.
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours opaque black with dark brown highlights small tan head.  Good lacing, good carbonation and silky body.  Taste is strong dark malt and coffee.

Bottle.
Black brew with tan head.  Roasted malt and coffee aromas - tastes much better than the canned Guinness Draught but there are much better stouts out there.

11.2oz - Nice thick looking liquid under dark tan head of good size.  Roasted notes on nose.  Palate was hops and malt, and the finish was a little astringent.  Tasted fined, aftertaste lingered badly.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours oil black with a small tan head. Nose is smoky, burnt malts. Taste is full of alcohol, oily, a bit of chocolate, somewhat harsh and tangy.  Body is fairly thin for the style. Big bitter aftertaste. Overall decent but one per sitting is definitely enough.

bottle - Pours black with a nice, lingering tan head.  It smells of dark roast malt and coffee.  The flavor is that dark roast malt in big supply with coffee, chocolate, and a well rounded bitterness.  It’s a more full flavored beer than the usual Guinness stout or draught.  Really good brew.

good beer, good color, good head retention, drinks smooth and finishes good also.  the 7.5% is tasted but not too badly.  the glass i got it an at the flying saucer in kansas city is a very nice glass with an embossed logo.

Tastes similar to the Extra Stout, it has a little bit of coffee, roasted malts, a little funky acidity, and smooth to drink.  Has a little similarity in taste to Guiness Draught too, only not as thin.  Overall, a good stout.

Bottle. Pours inky black, large mocha head with a consistency somewhere between standard Guinness and, well...other beers. Holds throughout. Nose is somewhat chocolatey, with the burnt barley really coming strong. Slight coffee, caramel presence. Surprisingly good.

As expected, my bottle of mud pours deep and black, with a thin chocolate head that held steady throughout the serving. Without the nitrogen pour, the bubbles were a little bigger, of course, but the lacing was still generous. A little fuller in body, the hoppy bite was noticeable, relative to the standard U.S. Draught version. There’s a little alcohol heat and a nice lingering sweetness, balanced by the hoppy bitterness. 

While I like this better than the typical draft, Guinness is still a far cry from any number of the HUGE assortments of stouts and porters readily available in nearly any local brewpub or brewery. All in all, while this is a very serviceable quaff, I’d prefer to drink local and fresh.

330 ml bottle. Product of Ireland, called a malt liquor on the label.  Pours a lasting tiny bubbled mocha head, with attractive lacing, over a clear red tinged brownish black (SRM 40) body......nose is heavy roasted malts with light coffee, bit of chocolate, molasses, bit of beef, some Marmite....taste is lightly sweet to start, then light beef, yeast, umami arrive finishing with a nice lingering bitter finish....mouth feel is medium and lightly sticky, carbonation makes a lovely creamy sensation. This is a much nicer Guinness. The layers of aroma and flavor make it a "junior" Imperial Stout, and the mouth feel sensations are delicious. BJCP 7/3/14/5/7

330ml bottle from the Cayman Islands. Pours a dark black with a huge tan head. Smells dry, roasted malts, and grains. Somewhat bitter on the palate, creamy and full bodied. Definitely the best guinness I’ve had.

It’s got that light roasted coffee, tinder dry aspect to the roast malt with a touch of subtle creaminess plus the raisiny/plum, all the right elements. More to the roast than the others in the flavor. Incredible head and conditioning. Pretty flavorful. Dry, roasty, burnt dark malts. Good!

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors 

It pours a very dark black with ruby highlights and a cream, light tan head.  Great head retention and lacing.  There is a ton of caramel in the nose with aan undercurrent of raisins, dark fruit, and a hint of roasted malt.  The flavor is very malty and robust.  Lots of roasted malt, a slight burnt note, caramel, and a lenghty roasted bitterness.  Much bigger and more flavorful than it’s popular cousin.  Medium to rich in body with medium carbonation leading to a medium to long, slightly burnt tasting finish.  Very tasty.
A bit stronger and with a smokier taste than regular Guinness. Very dark brown with a medium-sized light brown head. Toasty aroma.
600th rating for this brew! Very tasty stuff.  Very dakr brown pour with good brown head.  Sweet and sour aroma, almost like a faint flanders red.  Flavor has a bitter tartness. Very enjoyable.

Bottle.  Finally getting around to rating this.  Nose of sweet roast, syrupy berry.  Blacker than Coke pour with a large rocky dark brown head.  Taste is bitter with a charred, black tar roast that lasts forever.  Very little sweetness, definitely surprised by that, and no real sign of alcohol.  Aftertaste is long, bitter, dry, and ashy.  Very full body, prickly carbonation, again dry and well-attenuated.  More brutal than a ton of stouts I’ve had, this squashes the common version like a grape. [2011.02.19: 4.0]

Not as dry as I remember (even the aftertaste has some mild sweetness), but the other notes are all there, even the distinctive berry nose.  [2018.01.28: 3.8]

Bottle pours black color with creamy tan head.  Aroma of roast and dark fruits.  Taste unique combination of caramel, oak, dark malts, roast, licorice, dark fruits and even a little sour sneaking in.  Long somewhat dry finish of roast and hops, not unpleasant.  Creamy carbonated mouth feel.  Alcohol not apparent.
Very interesting ans well balanced beer, I can only imagine what it will taste like as it ages.  I have to give Guinness credit.
Bottle sample purchased at Premier Gourmet. Pours very dark with a decent tan head, not much lacing to speak of. Aroma is of carmalized malt. Taste is also of malt and coffee finish.

09 vintage that i brought back from el salvador, consumed 2011. wozsa, this is amazing. reminiscent of westy 12 and may great old ales and quads in certain ways. terrific brew, tons of figs and prunes and dark fruits. mostly malts, has a huge profile that is not burnt at all, subtly roasty, but mostly sweet, dark fruits, thick dusty old cloths, hints of licorice and mollasses, amazing stuff. this is a gem, and is fdefinitely different from the recently imported 2010/2011 vintage that hit the states, as i had one of those last week. drinking this in a blind tasting you would never guess it was a guinness.

Black, super thick dark tan head.  Dark bread, yeasty aroma.  Taste has much dark roastiness with more dark bread flavor coming though.  Well carbonated with a finish of slight burnt bitterness that lingers for quite a while.  A very fine stout.

Bottle, served in regular ol’ glass. Guinness foreign extra. Everything the draught is but more of it. Heavy flavor of malt, hops, and chocolate or coffee. Very bold flavors with a good amount of bitterness, but less offensive than the original extra stout. Overall a very good beer.
Bottle.  Dark brown pour,small tan head.  Dark roasted malt, light chocolate, dark fruit, and a bit of off diacetyl flavor.  It’s actually not bad, and I do want to hate this beer.

Pitch black body, chocolate froth head. Sweet roasty nose, butterscotch/diacetyl and caramel. The body is medium roast with an unbalanced oakyness and buttery diacetyl quality that detracts. Burnt coffee finish.
ANOTHER GREAT STOUT FROM GUINNESS, THIS ONE HAS A LITTLE MORE ALC. CONTENT. IT POURS DARK RICH BROWN NEARLY BLACK WITH A CREAMY BROWN HEAD A NICE CHOCOLATY SLIGHTLY BITTER ROASTED COFFEE FLAVOR.
Bottle, courtesy of my friend who offered up this to me a few weeks ago. Poured a black color with a dark tan head. Aroma was malty, sweet, with notes of chocolate. Hops were pretty mellow. Nice!

Poors dark with rocky and persistant tan head. Aroma and flavor give off hints of passion fruit and brown sugar. Body is thick and the finish is bitter. Pretty good but not something to drink all night.

Finally available in the states! Pours an oily black with a thin tan head. Aromas of dark roasted malts, molasses and a bit of chocolate. The flavor starts sweet then takes on bitter and sour notes, the 7.5% abv is very well hidden. This version of Extra Stout just has more...more aroma, more flavor, more body and more alcohol. Very good stuff!

11.2 oz bottle into snifter. Pours an opaque black with a thick tan head that sticks around forever. Leaves nice lace. Aroma is anise, dark chocolate, molasses, raisins. Taste is nice and sweet in an English/U.K. way. Some bitterness and sour in the finish. The relatively high alcohol content is hidden extremely well. Carbonation and body are medium; has a creamy mouthfeel. Much better than Guinness Draught.
Toasted aroma, black-ish hue with a large off-white head, toast, wood, nuts, coffee, super thick palate, rich chocolate aftertaste, excellent stout.

Slight roasted aroma, with the bit of sourness that stands out about Guinness.  Pours an opaque black, with no ruby highlights, with a thin dark tan head.  Full flavor on this, with roasted notes, coffee notes, and the touch of tartness.  Very long roasted finish.  The alcohol is not noticeable, which can make this a dangerous drink.  Overall, I was quite impressed, and glad we can get this in Ohio.

bottled. pours dark brown with a medium tight head. aromas of roasted malt, toast and grass. it is earthy and makes me think of burnt oak. it is not overly heavy and has lasting bitter finish.
decent.
Bottle.  Pitch black pour with huge pillowy head of brown bubbles.  Big roasty nose.  Taste of burnt toast, marmite, and gravy granules.  Rich mouthfeel, with a bitter, astringent palate.

Clean, coldwater, slightly sour roast aroma - not much different from the Extra Stout as best I can recall.  Good modified US 12 oz longneck - embossed, tapered waist.   Black beer with a two-toned tan and eggshell head, which dissolves into a mousse that looks like frogs’ eggs. This may be a bit more coffeeish and sour than the Extra Stout that we get in the states.  Has a sour fruitiness to it, and without so much sweetness. The body is pretty heavy, the aftertaste is tangy.  I have overlooked this beer - Guinness was my gateway beer to quality brew -- it’s great stuff and I don’t actually buy it much anymore, though it is a guaranteed good session.  Some of this 4-pack is going into my chili cookoff entry - wish me luck.  Market Square Liquors.  Subsequent NOTE:  Do not use this a substitute for Extra Stout in recipes - it imparts way too much bitterness.

A black beer with a small but good head. The aroma has some roast, root beer, vanilla, and chocolate bready notes. The taste is roast, bitter bakers chocolate, and alcohol. I heard some good thing about this but was not a big fan.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Deep opaque brown/black body, thin clumping cream head. Toasty, roasty, woody nose with burnt sugars and salty leather. Dry body with soy, roasted barley, wood, and medicinal notes, perhaps a tad oxidized, with a woody, thin, almost tart finish. A little harsh.

Had this in St. Lucia - this tasted so much better than anything else they had there and so much better than the regular Guinness you get in the States.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee - sweet malt.  Sweet flavor with a tan of a bitter after taste.  I enjoyed it.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Appearance: A tall tan head sits on top of a thick pouring and very dark black body with deep garnet highlights. The head hangs on well and maintains a small covering on top of the beer as I drink. The glass holds on to some nice lacing as well.

Smell: The aroma has dark roasted and toasted malt notes. Within this I get a hint of coffee, some sweetness a touch of something fruity and a very slight boozy note.

Taste/Palate: Its aroma comes alive here on the tongue. The dark roasted malt brings a full bodied hit of toasted barley notes with sweet touches of toffee that play well off the slight sweet boozy notes. Holding the sweetness in check are some dark roasted coffee notes and mild hop bitterness. The palate has a creamy, slightly slick and full mouth feel and soft carbonation.

Notes: Why did we have to wait this long to get this here in the states? This beer brings it! lol

First rating
33 cl bottle on Majesty of the Seas cruise ship in the carribean somewhere, among other days I drank this on January 25, 2011
Dark brown to black color, big lasting light brown head. Sweet, malty scent. Sweet, raissin, roasted taste. Raissin aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.
7/4/8/3/15=3.7

Rerate
Bottle thanks to Ingo! Sampled on July 31, 2015. BB 01/11/08.
Black color with dark brown in it, tan head. Sweet, malty, chocolate, dirt cellar scent. Berries, dark fruits, dirt cellar taste. Port, dusty aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Dry finish.
7/4/7/4/15=3.7

Rerate
Bottle thanks to Ingo! Sampled on July 31, 2015. BB 06/02/11.
Black color with dark brown in it, dark brown head. Sweet, alcohol something reminding of Highland whisky, cocoa, berries scent. Sweet, smooth, light roasted taste. Berries aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.
8/4/8/3/16=3.9

330 ml bottle in Sudan. Poured a dark black with a two finger brown head. Aroma of liquorice, citrus and roasted malt. Flavor was sweet and nutty. Palate was nice and mellow with overtones of the flavors. Nice stuff.

Little background first of this one bottle (review is midway down).  Bought one of these at a market our 1st day in St John US virgin islands where we were for a week.  I horded this beer until the very last part of the trip.  packed it up w/the left over ice from the Villa we checked out of at 10AM . Nursed in a dark plastic bag filled w/ice and dripping everywhere while we sat at the beach bar next to the dock getting our eat and drink on.  About 85 degrees out--not to bad for a late January late morning/early aft.  Lisa and I left the beach bar after a long lunch that included a ribeye wrap, chicken burrito, a 12 oz bottle of red Chimay, 1 sierra Nevada pale ale, 1 virgin islands mango pale ale, and a bushwacker with a chocolarte drawn smily face skull and cross bones on top--YIKES we did a #!!!.  After lunch boarded the Red hook from St John going to St Thomas to catch our flight back home.  w/ the leaky shopping bag that had the foreign stout in it--I thought phuck I hope this is worth the effort...It surely was--a great beer!   

Poured in 2 cups and split with Lisa.  Dark close to black appearance with a brownish prevelant head.  Great ABV at 7.5 that is well weaved in.  Nose was very roasty and smokey and nutty.  I could tell this one was going to kick ass as soon as I whiffed it.  The taste was just like identical to the nose with great balance and flavor--smooth rounded finish.  We both REALLY enjoyed it and agreed we would love to enjoy it w/the some BBQ food (props to Lisa for calling that one out).  Wish I could get this here.  A great beer we enjoyed on the boat from St John to go home which was an awesome toast to a amazing week vacation!

Black in color with brownish tinges. Tan pretty decent head. Clings to glass well. The smell is chocolate, malts, burnt, coffee,  not bad. The taste is chocolate, slight malt sweetness, coffee, burnt malts, and roasty.
Pours a nice dark brown with a dense head.  Creamy malt aroma.  Taste is smooth with more malt and less cream than regular Guinness.

Pours deep and black with an immsense head. Two-stage pour due to copious foaming.  The head lingered too, delaying my enjoyment of the beer quite a while.  I enjoyed the nose of chocolate, roast, and coffee while I waited for the rocky head to subside.  Hints of sweetness give way to a fairly bitter finish, firstly from the roast and coffee notes and then a lingering bitterness from the hops.  There’s a bit of dark fruit amongst the other flavors on the palate.  A good brew but there are many others in its ABV range and style area that I much prefer.

Bottle. Pours black with a gigantic brown head that leaves lots of lacing. Aroma is woody, cocoa, instant coffee. Flavor is super woody, rich, roasty, sweet. Reminds me of sumatran coffee with a block of wood dropped in.

Review from notes sampled 11/29/2007
Got this in a trade with jspruit, thanks for the opportunity.
The beer pours a solid black with a slight dark ruby highlight on the edges. I might have poured to quickly, but this thing had a full 2+ inches of head and I had to swallow the last little bit out of the bottle. The head faded slowly to a thin layer on the surface of the beer and laced all the way down the glass. Smells of chocolate and an almost wine like soury fruity funk in there. Taste is a soured chocolate with a slight alcohol sting. Definitely has that signature Guinness sourness to it. Creamy and smooth to drink, I wish I had let it warm a bit more. Very nice stout, I wish I could get it more easily!

Bottle. Almost black with a rocky, lacing resilient khaki head. Aroma of roasted malt, butterscotch, and wood. Taste is semi-sweet, bitter, very roasted and slightly woody. Body is full and pretty thick, but still fluffy, and softly carbonated.

11.2 bottle:  Pours a dark ruby (Hold it up to a light! This beer is not black!!!) with a thin tan head, roasted grains (slightly burnt) and light coffee in the aroma, full bodied with a slick mouthfeel and grainy ending.

Bottle...  Poured jet black with a thick light brown head.  Nose some roast, oak, dark fruit-like esters.  Thick foamy palate.  Oak, dark cocoa, definitive yeast notes.  Good amount of roast, sweet malts, and a creamy, milk chocolate finish.

Pours black into an English Pint.  Mocha head with excellent retention recedes leaving spot lacing to skim surface. Dark chocolate aromas. Thin, bitter soy upfront turning to chocolate and espresso in the lasting finish.

Pours jet black with a full, frothy, tan head; great head retention and lacing. Smells of roasted and malted barley. Tastes hoppier than regular Guinness and just as malty. Full-bodied with a creamy texture and less than average mouth-carbonation, Guinness Foreign Extra Stout finishes smooth and rich.

Black pour, with a tall, rocky, tan head.  The aroma is roasty and dry with some slight raisiny sweetness, a touch of brown sugar, oatmeal, a little semi-sweet chocolate and some peppery noble hops.  The flavor is mildly sweet with a sort of muddled blend of dark fruits, semi-sweet chocolate, and oatmeal with a slightly bitter roasted malt finish.  Very smooth a creamy body but a little on the thin side and the carbonation is soft but plentiful.  Vast improvement over the terrible Draught.

[330ml bottle, The Bottle, York] Dark black, thin white head. Deep fruity malt aroma, rising bitterness on the nose. Creamy malt on the palate, kick of alcohol on the aftertaste, with a bitter, dark chocolate finish. Overall it’s quite chewy, got a great body to it. Good stuff, and thankfully very different to their regular stout [15012011]

Bottle. Dark thick pour with some tan head. Thicker body, fuller flavored stout, nutty malt, chocolate, some light roasted coffee tones. Well done, wish I could drink this in place of normal guinness.

5th March 2008 
 Pours with almost no head. Not as thick as normal Guinness. A bit of a raspy stout but the cream is there in the undertone. Dry finish.

Had this one bottled, thanks Jim! Thick, opaque black pour with a thick, tan head, a wonderfully oaky and smoky nose, hints of sweetness give way to lots of bitter chocolate and coffee notes, but with a light, almost milky mouthfeel.  Finishes strong.  I am finally impressed with a Guinness product.

Bottle from kegs and barrels.  This beer pours black with a thick tan head.  The aroma are light citrus and chocolate with a little coffee mixed in.  The mouthfeel is slightly watery and quite bitter with a medium to heavy body.  Way better than what we normally get for Guinness on this side of the pond!  Cheers!

Nice answere to American Imperial Stouts, bigger with more hops, thin oily pour if not used motor oil, little head, some hops and a nice juniper note.  Not just an answere but its own unique offering.  Cleaner for sure

Bottle poured a clear dark brown with a lasting creamy tan head. Aromas of licorice, roasted malt, coffee and light cocoa. Palate was light to edium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, coffee, bitter chocolate and light licorice with a smooth roasty finish.
Bottle 330ml. Masterpiece. Aromas of milk chocolate and liquorice. Taste has a bitter bite, and very long length. Palate is creamy, and full bodied. Black, with a frothy off-white head.

Paid quite a bit for this and what is the difference between this and the other country guiness f extra stouts? Smells pretty good. Nice black pour with a foamy alabaster head. Pours like a nitro from the bottle. Yep, quite bitter but not as bitter as some of those other foreign stouts like lion. Decent stout yet has lots of personality, not for your average mild stout lover. Bitter medicine feel to this stuff. Much more robust flavor than I was expecting and much more than I care for. Rather rude at times and certainly approaches impy stout territory without any problem. Barely any CO2 but much more than the thingy can or nitro stouts.

Pours dark black into a creamy tan head which slowly dissipates into lingering heavy lacings that hang on the glass then fades into lingering heavy lacings on the side of the glass. Carbonated bubbles rise from the bottom of the glass into a pool of creamy swirl in the center of the glass. Aroma of creamy yeasty hops and roasted chocolate malts and barley. Initial flavor of buttery dark chocolate fading to a dry smoky finish. A Guinness on tap is always preferred, but even the bottle is of this gem is hard to find. There’s NOTHING like a Guinness!
11.2 oz bottle from Tournament.  Black pour with a creamy tan head.  Flavor and aroma both have awesome notes of roasted coffee, chocolate with a dry & roasty finish.

(330ml bottle thanks to blutt59) dark brown pour, creamy/soapy dark tan bubbles. Nose of creamy cocoa, nice sweetness, mild umami. Taste is bitter bakers chocolate, creamy cocoa, cola root, and a creamy body.
22.10.2007. 0,33l Bottle. At the george hotel, Bishop Stortford, England. Dark brown colour. Malty aroma with dry hops and very nice bitterness.

This has been an elusive beer for me.  Heard about Guinness Foreign Stout about ten years ago and always wanted to try it.  Found a 4-pack @ Joe Canal’s for $8 (but got a two bucks back from mail-in rebate).   Foamy tan head, black bodied, sweet from alcohol, oak, and roasted malts.   Higher alcohol content was a bit hard to hide.   Glad I am able to buy Foreign Extra Stout locally.

Pours dark brown/black with a large tan head that leaves very nice lacing as it collapses. The aroma has notes of marshmellows, anise, vanilla, chocolate, and of course, roasted malt. The flavor is very rich and bitter with lots of dark chocolate, coffee, and a very nice spicy quality that puts this in a higher class than most stouts in a similar range. A great sipper at a great price. It is a bit challenging for a beginner due to the strong bitter, roasted finish, but highly reccomended!

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - 11.2 oz bottle. Black tar pour with a sticky khaki colored head that leaves excellent thick lacing. Aroma is pleasant, but subtle. Pick up some brief traces of coffee and licorice. Flavor is slightly bland, some unsweetened dark chocolate, a hint of coffee and lots of rich black earth. Mouthfeel is nice and chalky. Overall, a solid classic.

Poured from an 11.2 ounce bottle into a nonic pint glass.

Appearance: Pours a dark cola brown color, almost black, with a 1 finger creamy dark tan head. Decent lacing.

Smell: Roasted malts and cocoa with just a hint of rubbing alcohol.

Taste: Toasted bread up front followed by mildly sweet notes of cocoa and toffee in the middle before a punch of bitter hops at the finish. Aftertaste is quite bitter and lingers. The alcohol is well-hidden. This is not your normal Guinness...and I like it.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Goes down very smooth.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. You could knock back a few of these on a cold evening.

Overall: Very good beer overall. I’ve never been too impressed by Guinness before, but this one is a good stout. I would recommend checking it out.

pours black with thick tank head. aroma of roasted malts, raisin, light oak, vanilla, and coffee notes. medium to full body with lots of chocolate and roasted malt flavor. Bitter on the end, with a oak, vanilla, and taffy flavor. Im catching some flavors i cant figure out in it as well.
Mild bitterness, much better than regular Guinness, malty and sharp, I can tell it has a much higher ABV than the regular version, and I think I have enjoyed it much more.

bottle.  pours black with a 1 finger light tan head.  really nice nose with lots of roasted malts, some raisin, fig, light oak and coffee notes.  medium to full body with big layers of chocolate, coffee, dark roasted malts and light oak flavors.  dynamic finish with more coffee, dark fruit notes and a solid amount of bitterness.  this is damn good.

Aroma is roasty, alcohol, raisin, oak. Appearance is dark brown almost black with one finger dark tan head that dissipated slowly. Taste is malty dark sweet, coffee, chocolate, roasty, oak. Much hops aroma and bitterness. Malt and hops are both very pronounced but balanced. Complex and direct. Palate is full. Burnt roatiness lingers with hops bitterness. Overall an excellent beer.

Appearance:  opaque dark brown with a light brown head (1.5 fingers) that slowly shrank to a hefty collar; good lacing.  Aroma:  dark roasted malts, whisper of dark fruits, hint of dark chocolate; there is some good hoppy character as well.  Taste:  very roasty, slightly sweet, with a sharp (yet somehow mellow too) blast of dry-seeming hops over everything.  Finish:  long, medium-bitter and nicely dry, with the hops fading more quickly than the roasty, toasty malts, which linger longer.  Notes:  Full-bodied palate and big flavors, yet very drinkable as well.  Better than the regular Guinness, and a bit better  than the Guinness Extra Stout we have in the States, too.

An aggressive pour into my Lost Abbey Teku glass produces a four finger thick, lightly browned, tan colored head; the head disappears somewhat quickly, though it does leave some thin, layered lacing on the sides of my glass.  The beer is quite dark, an almost black color and it is quite opaque when held up to the light.  The aroma smells of burnt, slightly fermented prunes, somewhat acidic espresso and also has a touch of nostril warming alcohol towards the finish.  It is quite interesting how fruity this smells, it is really quite amplified, but it also some how smells thin, if that makes any sense.  If you really dig there are notes of darkly toasted whole grain bread in the finish that adds some much needed complexity, but you really have to dig to find these notes.



Lightly sweet up front, but this is well balanced by the roast character.  The roasted notes start out soft and smooth, but pick up some bite and bitterness as it flows across the tongue.  The finish sees the burnt bitterness lingering in a nice way as well as having a roasted coffee / bread character to it.  The beer has some viscous heft to it, but it actually seems a bit light for what I was expecting for some reason; the overall dryness and ample roast flavors certainly help to thin the effect of this beer out too.  The fruitiness from the nose isn’t quite so noticeable in the flavor (the ample roast character in the flavors certainly tempers this), but there is still a note of lightly tart plums in the finish that mixes with some warming alcohol notes that also accentuate the soft fruit character.



For some reason I was expecting great things from this beer; I feel quite a bit let down, but in all honestly this is a more than serviceable stout that I am able to settle in to and enjoy.  I wish it had a bit more chewy malt balance to it and the nose is a bit out of whack with its fermented prune focus.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a lasting creamy tan head. Burnt smoky taste with a nice bitterness throughout. Very different from the Guinness we are all used to and much better than the previous version of Guinness FES I had tasted while traveling in Asia.

bottle.  Pours pitch black body with big fluffy brown head.  Aroma is dark chocolate, roast, chocolate syrup, some coffee.  Flavor is rich chocolate roast, with smoked coffee bean finish.  This is quite good, really exceeded my expectations and heightens my respect for Guinness.  A great stout.

Poured a dark brown color with a brown head that was very thick and frothy, retention aplenty and decent lace.  Aroma had a good roasted malt note and some good chocolate note along with a slight smoke presence. Flavor had a good roast profile the some bittersweet flavors balanced out the heavy malt note.  Finish was dry.  Good Beer!

bottle from a four pack. Best damn 9 bucks you can spend.  Pours dark, might as well say black with a modest head thats sticks around for a while.  Smells vaguely of chocolte nbut mostly roasty barley.  Very complex flavors in this one.  Tastes stronger than it smells thats for sure.  quite a bit of bitter with a nice dry finish.  Its the finish that really sets this one apart.  Try a bottle.

Bottle.  Aroma-a nice heady smoky smell.  Appearance - a nice dark brown, practically black, just a trace of tan foam on the pour.  Taste - a delicious combination of the smoky flavors with the smoother woody flavors.  Palate - Pleasant and thick, but not overly so.  Overall - A very good dry stout from Guinness.  Would recommend.

Bottle from BevMo. Black in color, with hints of ruby at the very edges. Sweet toffee aroma with maybe a little anise. Roasty bitterness along with some sugary sweetness. Some burnt coffee. Smooth mouthfeel. Pretty tasty.

Poured a beautiful Black, with a Tan foamy lasting head. Smell of burnt coffee, earthy and a touch of hops. But then I tasted it, Actually creamy start Medium Body and dry finish. But the overall taste is something I can’t figure out. Maybe it’s the "oak"? Kinda Grainy, reminds me a little of the 250th yr. Guinness, But not as bad. This is drinkable, But I don’t see myself buying it again.(Actually, this was given to me....thanx D.Kurtz)

I’ve waited a while to try one of their Export Stouts! Pours black with a big tan head and sheets of lace. The aroma is roasty with some malty sweetness, some charred wood, and some molasses. The flavor is very roasty with a light tart twang. There is a bit of burnt toast and a light bit of pie cherry fruitiness. Licorice shows up quite a bit as it warms. The palate is full bodied and slightly slick.

Pours a dark black with a thick 2-finger frothy head. Aroma is sweet molasses with some coffee and a touch of oak. Flavor is definitely oaky. Strong coffee with a nice tang at the end. Very well-balanced. The bitterness creeps in at the end. A rich body. Without a doubt my favorite Guinness.
Black color with a large head quickly falling to nothing.  Light tart chocolate aroma.  Dry, acrid flavor.  Heavy on burnt and roasty qualities.  Fairly bitter.

Bottle. Poured into a glass a dark brown color with a big fluffy tan head of about 2-3 fingers. Not having the widget or on a nitrous tap, this does not cascade like a normal Guinness would The head slowly settles to form a nice coaster and laces the glass as it settles. The aroma has a nice sweetness to is along with some dark fruit, tobacco, and slight leather. More sweet smelling than anything else though. Medium mouthfeel. Milk Chocolate, sweet, some dark roast notes. Ends with a slight bitterness with a touch of sweetness. Not bad. Way different than any Guinness I have had before. Pretty easy drinking.

I have been curious about this one for a number of years and finally they export it to the US. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a large creamy-foamy brown head that lingered forever and left great lacing - beautiful. The aroma was cola, cherry and faint notes of wood and smoke. The flavor was semi-sweet and malt forward with moderate notes of cola, pepper, oregano, cherry and wood. The finish was long with cola and oregano lingering. Medium body but quite smooth. Interesting.

Jet black pour, tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, coffee and a little ginger. Toffee and burn caramel flavours with a splash of coffee and dark chocolate. Long, lingering after-taste of coffee with a slight bitterness.

I have wanted to try some type of Foreign Stout from Guinness for years. I found this in a local grocery store when I wasn’t even looking for beer. The body is as black and blocking light as anything I have seen. The thick creamy head was light brown sugar colored. I would think this dense head would be from nitro if I hadn’t poured it myself. The nose was malty with lots of biscuit and some light roasted coffee. There is also a hint of tobacco and musty leather. The taste is nice and roasted with lots of coffee mixed with a little bit the tang of fresh fruit, like apples. There is also some nice depth in the finish like salty leather. The after taste is ashy with some woody notes. This is pretty good, other than the aftertaste.

Aroma: Smoky, sour malt, roasted coffee, yeasty.

Appearance: Dark brown-black pour, with a monster-sized, foamy tan head. Really great pour.

Taste: Roasted barley, smoke, sour malt, tangy, nicely hopped finish with a good level of bitterness.

Palate: Soft, gently carbonated, well-balanced.

Overall: Excellent. I really enjoyed this and will certainly try it again. I grew up on Guinness but don’t drink a lot of it anymore, as I find the standard draught just so-so and the extra only slightly better. The FES is definitely going to find it’s way into my fridge again.
Bottle, so that unique Guinness pour is a bit lacking. So much hoppier than the original. I like it, but not as much as the standard Guinness. Taste is even drier and bitterness is very high.

Pours a dark black color with a very hefty, creamy, deep tan head. Aroma has a hefty roasted barley, more chocolate malt nose than Guinness Extra Stout and finishes with a mild raisin sweetness. Flavor is very full with notes of chocolate, dark roast, raisin, slight sour lactose sweetness and finishes with a mild roasted bite. The beer as a very smooth, creamy texture with a fairly hefty body that hides all alcohol presence. Overall a tasty brew and a far different offering that Guinness’ other brews.   Definitely would prefer this over their other offerings at times.

Bottle. Black bodied with a tall, thick brown head. Aroma is sweet with toasted caramel, roasted malt, and light chocolate notes. Taste is bittersweet chocolate, ashy malt, roasted malt, and bitter coffee. Sort of lactic as well, like a milk stout. Body is medium with a creamy carbonation. Ends with more sweet malt, roasted malt, caramel, and bittersweet chocolate. Much better than Guinness Draught.

Pours black with a two finger tan head. Aroma is roasty malt, chocolate, and a light smokiness. Flavor is sweeter than I expected. Roasty, smoky malt, chocolate, with a lot of hoppy bitterness toward the finish.

Large brown head, fair retention with spotty, stringy lace, tight beaded. Black in color. Nose is funny, medicinal with some bandaid notes then a bit smoney. Body is medium, over carbonated? Lightly oily and a touch tart? Light cocoa and roast flavors develop as it warms, more smoke, burnt malt notes, caramel and some burnt sugary notes, vanilla,  light medicinal again. Dry finish, roast, cocoa and patent malt notes. hmmmm. Bottle purchased  @statelineliquors.

That’s about as good as a beer can look--nice pour, persistent, 2-inch, light mocha head. You can smell the bitterness--like a chocolate bitterness. Not much coffee in the nose. Like a fuller, warmer, wetter, sweeter Guinness (still has that baseline of earthy, burnt bitterness so characteristic of the regular stuff). Still maintains drinkability. Not overly chocolatey/sweet--great balance. Dries the mouth out a bit towards the finish. Medium creamy mouthfeel. Excellent beer.

Bottle.
Pours a rich, thick motor-oil black with an aroma of hot chocolate, chocolate pudding, and roasted cocoa beans.  Flavor is roasted cocoa coffee, chocolate bitters, nutty malt, and roasted hops.  Aggressive and lingering on the tongue.  Another excellent Guinness brew.
Black as coal with a  tan head.  You can smell and taste the roasted barley and hops, coffee.  This is a very good brew.

12 oz. bottle from Old Town; shared with my Boo for her #100 tick. Aroma: Moderate raisin brandy; lighter oats, coffee roast and caramel. Appearance: Near black with a thick mocha head that settles into a healthy, bubbly cap. Flavor: Much the same as the nose; raisin-lead and has that fruity raisin presence throughout; up front it’s paired with oats and light chocolate; towards the finish there’s more caramel than chocolate. The finish is abrupt and pretty dry. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, very soft carbonation, abrupt finish. Overall: A pretty nice, readily available stronger stout that’s a little more accessible than many of the stronger stouts on the market; also a bargain at around $2 a bottle locally.

11.2 oz bottle (Irish Version).  Pours a dark black with a nice 2 inch light brown head that lasts.  Taste is of smoke, malt, caramel, chocolate, dust, dirt, pine and hops.  Similar aroma.  Has a good dryness and bitterness in the finish.  Has a nice, light, oily body that coats the mouth.  Very pleasant and enjoyable to drink.  Worth picking up again.

Bottle. Pours opaque black with a huge brown head that never left any openings in my glass. Aroma is roasted coffee to start, then some hops, a bit of cereal malt, and then sweetness at the end, chocolate and toffee. Flavor is sweeter than the aroma, also creamy and more hoppy. Palate is excellent, just a hint of very fine carbonation. A truly excellent beer.

Bottle. Pours very close to black with dark beige head. Aromas of toffee, coffee, campfire, pumpernickel, spice, herbs. Flavors of toffee, caramel, toast, coffee, cocoa, pumpernickel, peat, dark fruit, herbs. Dry finish with lingering hop bitterness. Salty, hop derived, character that is not there in the draught. Full body with creamy, foamy mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.
Pours black with thick creamy foamy tan head and lacing.  Notes of expresso, dark chocolate, and roasted nuts.Balanced taste with a bitter finish.  Smooth and creamy palate.

Bottle from Ireland ... Black pour tan head .... lots of roasted and sweet malt/chocolate in the aroma ... roasted and sweet chocolate malts a tasty regular guinness on steroids ....  abv hidden well bitter hop finish .... compared to regular guinness way more aroma and flavor good stuff

Bottle brought back by a friend. Dark brown pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of roast, a bit of diacetyl, dark chocolate and some ash. Chocolate flavor with an almost oaky tark fruit and a hint of diacetyl before a very bitter and roasty finish.

poured from 11.2 bottle - Finally!  I have been anticipating trying this ever since I found out Guinness had these "other’ stouts out there.  As far as I know, this became just recently available here in Ohio.  Was it worth the wait ( and expense for that matter)?  Not sure.  Little thin on the palate.  Nice aroma and of course jet black appearance.  Quite dry, some coffee, dry malts.  Not bad, but not worth a $10 for 4.

Irish version according to the bottle, pours opaque black with a nice tan head, sweet, malty and woodsy, very smooth considering the 7.5% ABV. Great, great, great... just like everything Guinness brews, cheers!

Bottle.  Pours opaque with an average, creamy and frothy brown head, long retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (chocolate, coffee, roasted, burnt), light hops (earthy, herbal), and average esters (fruity) with notes of lactic and smoke.  Flavor is heavy malt (chocolate, coffee, roasted, burnt), light hops (earthy, herbal), and average esters (fruity) with notes of lactic, prunes, and smoke.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation, low creaminess with a dry finish.

I have heard a lot about this beer, lets see if it lives up to my expectations. 

The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma is roasted malt with a lot of sweet, sugary notes. The flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, some dark fruit and a little bit of bitterness. There is also a sweet, fruity medicinal taste that I don’t really like. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. 

Better than some of the the other Guinness beers I have had, but nothing special. It is certainly not as good as I was expecting it to be. Just a slightly above average stout here.

This brew just started to come around my way and is a pleasant surprise. nice roasted malt aroma, packs a nice bite on the palate, sweet roasted malt-chocolate taste, a bit bitter with a med/full body. very nice...

(11.2oz bottle, Irish version, courtesy of blutt59)  Pours a dark brown body with creamy beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, nuts, coffee, and subtle anise notes.  Flavor of roasted malt, tobacco, earth, coffee, and smoke.
A real winner from Guinness. What can’t they do? Might be hard for me to go back to the standard Draught... no it won’t!

11.2 oz. bottle poured to a Czech-pils glass at Lunar Brewing Co. with a cascading effect that slowly turned to a rich, black/brown color, plenty of light brown, creamy to rocky head foam, and thick, ultra clingy, ribbons and patches of lacing. The aroma, however, presented some funkiness, and almost cardboardy, packing material scent. The flavor was very roasty, with good body, but also extremely dry, with light hints of smoke and wood. Past the initial display, I was not thrilled.

Beautiful brew.  Almost black with thick, bubbly light brown head.  Noce roasty aroma with clear coffee notes.  Flavor supports the dark roasted malts and has a nice dry finish.  Not too astringent at any point.
Shared bottle with Chalsk and echo his sentiments.  Thicker and more roasty then normal version.  Higher in alcohol but still exceptionally easy to drink.
bread, chocolate, nuts, roasty, leather, earthy, raisin, black, frothy, medium sweetness, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish, fruity

Been wanting to try this since it was first announced.  Bottle shared with Leafs93 at Cloverleaf.  Pours a black color with off white foam head.  Has a bitter, roasty taste.  Has a thicker body that the traditional Guinness.  Thin to medium still, but thicker.  Some nice chocolate notes on the finish with hints of burnt malts lingering.  Some nice gentle bitters to balance it all out.

From 11.2 fl. oz. bottle no. 15124. The pour is very dark brown to about black with a thick and silky head up top that sticks around.  The aroma is like burnt malt and butterscotch.  The body is on the medium side.  The taste exhibits a chalky malt characteristic with a sharp bitterness.  The higher alcohol is noted when compared to Guinness Extra Stout (regular). I would not say it is overpowering but it is more notable than its sibling.

The aroma is like burnt malt, coffee, and a touch of chocolate. The appearance is dark brown almost black. The taste is like the aroma with a burnt bitter finish. The palate is a bit thin. Overall a pretty average stout.
dark and tasty. not what we’re used to at the  time.  brings a roasted flavorful malty presence, good tasty and only slightly bitter. still its worth having.

11.2oz bottle pours black with big reddish brown head.  Aroma is toasted malt and hop resin.  Flavor is toasted malt dark raison chocolate and a little woodiness.  Body is creamy and very bitter good feel.  A little alcohol warmth

smell is a musty chocolate. Black in color. no light getting through this stout. a nice dime sized head that dissipates quickly. medium carbonation. taste is bittersweet. smokey with a chocolatey bitter finish. absolutely love this beer. a bit costly for a 4 pack though. overall a great part of the guinness family.

Pours dark inky brown, light only penetrates the edge of the glass, two finger dark tan head, fine clinging lacing.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee, toffee, banana bread, figs, and pine.  Medium-full body, lively, crisp, lightly dry.  Mild initial sweetness, some citrus sourness midpalate, medium bitter finish.  Good stuff.

Dense, beautiful foam that is typical of GES and the aroma is a deeper, more intese version of the Extra Stout.  Bitter chocolate, iron and tobacco show themselves in the flavor.  I’ve waited almost 10 years to taste a Foreign version and I’m not disappointed.  I certainly don’t plan on paying the 12-14 bucks/4 pack again though.  The GES will do just fine.

Pours black with a thick tan head. Good lacing. Aroma is very sweet and malty...chocolate...some wood. Full bodied. Lots of roasted malts. Coffee and chocolate. Sweet and slightly tangy. Reminiscent of regular Guinness but definitely stronger. Creamy with a subtle (and pleasant) lingering burnt grain finish. This is really good. I’m surprised they took so long to sell it here.

Bottle. Pour is black thin and oily with a big dark kahki head that lasts. Aroma is watery malt and dried fruit prunes rasins. Taste is creamy and malty with some good dark fruit in there as well. Palate is full and creamy with a chewy chaulky finish. Pretty good!
Awesome stout-Guinness amped up with more coffee and dark chocolate. Doesn’t have the smooth texture of Draught- but better in some ways. Certainly more flavorful and less dry.

Pours black in the glass with a creamy cola head.  Roasted malt aroma with some yeast and alcohol mixed in.  Roasted malt flavors, bittersweet dark chocolate & some licorice notes.  Overall, this is very nice.  Its a bit sweeter than the regular Guinness Draught and definitely more complex.

Takes all the wonderful characteristics of Guiness Draft and amps them up. Full bodied and roasty, Guinness Foreign Extra stout pours midnight black with a thick creamy tan head that leaves oodles of lacing on the sides of the glass. Aroma shows dark chocolate and burnt toast. Aftertaste is long and starkly bitter.

Little dark chocolate aroma with oily espresso bean and some barnyard earth.  Jet black, creamy sandy head, little fizzy bubbles.  Oaky base, burnt dark grain, assertive without being pushy.  Almost chewy.  Love it.

hope this is the right place.  poured black with a tan head.  thick roasted malts, chocolate, and slightly lactos like a milk stout.  creamy palate, smooth roasted malts, slightly milky, chocolate/coffee finish.

Dark pour with a nice frothy light brown head. A lot of lacing on this one.  Roasted malts on the nose, chocolate and coffee. Smells basically like a coffee infused Guinness.  Very light taste to start, roasted malts and caramel. Strong coffee finish. Very dry and bitter to tie it all up.  Much lighter than I expected.
Pours a medium black with a creamy brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and bread.  Lighter body than expected and a little dry, there are mildly burnt malts and a little bitter.
Bottle pours a black beer with a brown head. Scent is roasted malts and bread. Taste is sweet malts and roasted coffee?

Pours near-black with a small brown head and good lacing. Nose is roasty as expected but has a lot more sweet malt depth to it than most stouts, and an almost brown sugary quality. Flavor is potent and extremely bitter on both front and back, so much so that it overwhelms the roasted barley/oats. Malt is definately bigger than in the regular American Extra Stout, hence the higher alcohol content that shows through strongly. Finish is long and bittersweet. Good but a little more bitter than I like roasty ales to be.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malt, roasted grain, slight hops, and slight chocolate.  Poured pitch black in color with a huge, creamy, foamy, rocky, frothy, loose, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is slightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of roasted malt, roasted grain, light chocolate, slight wood, slight tar, light hops, and some coffee.  Medium body.  Creamy, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Roasted malt, roasted grain, slight tar, and slight wood finish is dry.  7.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Imported from Ireland. Black, big foamy tan head. Lightly sweet, fruity aroma. Weird not to be gettng any coffee or chocolate in the aroma. Flavor is drier than the aroma would indicate. Woody and lightly sweet.

Pours black with a big foamy tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and light earth. Taste is rich with chocolate, deep roasty notes, light coffee, some earthy nutty notes in there also. Rather solid.
Wonderful chocolate nose and pretty in the glass, but much too dry, almost like a West Coast stout.

Nice dark, creamy pour from the  12oz bottle. Big, fluffy, thick head. Good retention. The aroma and flavor isn’t really different from the original Guinness, maybe a little bit creamier but that’s about it. Still a good go to beer though.

11.2 ounce bottle.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown with about an inch brown head.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, molasses, dark chocolate and coffee.  The brew tastes like roasted and burnt/charred malt, coffee, dark chocolate, and some hops.  Finish is mostly roasty and bitter, but some sweetness kicks in as the beer warms up.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, it’s creamy and a bit coating, and it’s also well carbonated.  Drinkability is good, it’s very smooth and goes down easy enough.  I think this is a solid brew, it’s worth trying.

Pours pretty much black with a brown thick head.  Aroma is mainly of malts with some molasses and nuttiness.  Flavor is of big time malts with some roastiness.  It’s similar to regular Guinness but without the chalky malt flavor.

Bottle from the BA gathering bar. Poured a deep black body with a huge foamy beige head. Aroma of tar, tobacco, burnt malts, slight alcohol, uncooked raisin bread. Palate is nice with a medium/full mouthfeel and lively carbonation however the aftertaste could be roastier and longer lasting. Flavor of dough, burnt malts, tobacco, tar and soy sauce. Solid but either this was waaaaay overpriced, $13.99 a 4 pack, or mispriced, I think the later.
Bottle from the Majestic on Eastchase.  Black pour with a huge tan head.  Aroma is a lot like Guinness, but with a stronger dark fruit presence.  Taste is a little sour, roasted, and very dry.

Bottle courtesy of Fratto. Heavy brown color with some bubbles on the head. Aroma is roasted malts, sweetness and dry chocolate. Flavor is dry and chocolaty with a fair amount of roastedness. Easy finish. I like it.

aroma of dark chocolate coffee and roasted malts,bit oaky as well..looks like regular guinness head slightly more tan good lacing..tastes like the aroma..dark chocolate coffee toasted malt sweetness  maybe even like a dark fruitiness and a bit of a hop tingle at the end..easy to drink with a lasting finish brings more of the hop character out,pretty much same texture as regular guinness will be buying again probably often

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market, Charlottesville, VA, opened 10/1/10. Pours pitch black with a large tan head. Good head retention and lacing.
